quote_or_scene: Mrs. Overton: 'Whatever they think Travis did, I think he did it.' Detectives arrive at his apartment to find him dead. Later: 'Why not Travis Hall?' 'Because he OD'd a week before she was killed.'
notes: Travis Hall was a suspect in Tracy Henderson's murder due to his parolee status and connection to the literacy center where Tracy volunteered. He is found dead in his apartment (OD'd a week before Tracy's murder), proving his innocence. The exposure was minimal—detectives went to question him, neighbor assumed guilt. No evidence of public accusation beyond the neighbor's comment. Severity 1: private suspicion, cleared before any public exposure or formal action.

quote_or_scene: Ridley during interrogation: 'It's not mine. It's name is Tracy Henderson... That's why I want my record accurately documented... for posterity.' Benson: 'Mr. Henderson, I am sorry, but the man we have in custody is not your daughter's killer.'
notes: Ridley is a confirmed serial killer who murdered 18 prostitutes over 31 years. He is arrested and interrogated for Tracy Henderson's murder (the 19th), which he explicitly denies and is later proven not to have committed. He is innocent of THIS specific murder accusation. The detectives apologize to the Henderson family for the misidentification. Ridley was interrogated privately; there's no indication of public exposure regarding the Tracy Henderson murder specifically. His arrest for his actual 18 murders is separate. This entry tracks his innocence regarding Tracy Henderson's murder only. Severity 2: arrested and held for a murder he didn't commit (though guilty of 18 others).

police_conduct_quote: You'll ruin my rep... What a cliché. Shaves his head to look different but he makes himself look more ugly... Does this turn you on? It's dangerous for you to be around these helpless doughnuts... You'd better talk to us cos we're looking to you for rape-homicide.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Maggio at his workplace (doughnut shop) in front of his employer. Employer responds: 'Oh, the crook. He's baking in the back. Does he committed sodomy. You'll ruin my rep.' Maggio proves innocence by showing severe scrotum scarring from prison acid attack that renders him physically incapable of rape: 'They gave me a welcome bath at Elmira. Soap and sulphuric acid. I can't even rape a freaking ant.'
notes: Maggio is a paroled sex offender with prior sodomy conviction. He had been prosecuted by victim Fitzgerald. Squad confronts him publicly at his workplace in front of his employer, explicitly mentioning his sodomy conviction and current rape-homicide investigation. His employer's reputation concerns show the public nature of the exposure. Maggio is proven innocent through physical evidence (severe genital scarring from prison assault rendering him incapable of penetrative rape). Despite being innocent of THIS crime, his prior conviction and public workplace confrontation qualify as consequence severity 2 (public exposure without formal sanction in this case).

quote_or_scene: Witness (Mr. Levin) identifies Dussault from photos as 'Labor Day rapist' who ran into him and 'called me a Jew bastard on Labor Day.' Squad investigates: 'Jean Dussault, Canadian. Deported.' Later: 'Desault's dead. Canadians found him colder than a witch's boob in a shack in Moosonee, Canada. OD'd on skag.'
notes: Dussault was identified by witness as the 'Labor Day rapist' (similar MO to Fitzgerald case). Had been previously deported from US. Found dead of drug overdose in Canada before current investigation could question him. His death and the squad's pivot away from him as suspect strongly implies he was not the perpetrator of either the Labor Day rape or Fitzgerald murder. No evidence of public exposure or material consequences from THIS investigation, as he died before being located. Prior deportation was not a consequence of this accusation. Included for completeness but minimal harm from current false accusation since investigation never reached him.

quote_or_scene: Detectives bring Steven Hale in for questioning about Seth's murder. His boss William Langdon had no idea about the relationship. Wife alibis him: 'The wife confirms he never left the house after he got back about 12:30.' Detectives acknowledge clearing him: 'We send Steven Hale home.' 'With apologies for the inconvenience.'
notes: Steven Hale works for William Langdon, a prominent anti-gay activist. Detectives question him about Seth's murder in front of his wife and child ('Daddy! Let's go!'). His secret sexuality is exposed to his family during the investigation. Wife provides alibi clearing him. Receives only partial apology ('apologies for the inconvenience').

police_conduct_quote: 'One month and back to your old tricks. Think you'd throw'em by switching to rooftops? Same excessive force to beat your victims to a pulp, just like Seth.' 'Did you even know him?' 'It was pathetic, him trying to pump up that puny body of his.' 'What happened? Did he hit on you or did you start to like'em puny?'
quote_or_scene: DNA tech: 'I ran a couple of test results through the data bank and got a hit.' 'Ray Gunther.' Detectives arrest Ray violently in motel with girlfriend Cindy present. Later: 'The lab got the full DNA report.' 'And it ain't Ray's.' Tech explains: 'This came from the mitochondrial...It only narrows it to bloodline. So while it's definitely not Ray, you are still looking for somebody from that family.'
tags: wrong_ID; tech_db_error; arrested; ruined_physically; ruined_in_family; db_error
notes: Ray Gunther, the 'Parkway Rapist' (notorious serial rapist from the 1980s), is falsely accused of Seth's murder due to preliminary DNA match that only indicated bloodline, not individual identity. Violently arrested in motel room in front of girlfriend. Subjected to aggressive, degrading interrogation by detectives who assume his guilt based on his criminal history. Cleared when full RFLP DNA testing proves it wasn't him but someone from his family (his brother Jesse). No apology given. Though Ray is actually guilty of orchestrating/manipulating the murder, he is innocent of the direct sexual assault and killing that detectives accused him of.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives show him photos of himself and Andrew Harlin together, including nude photos, while at his workplace. Detectives threaten: 'We won't [tell your wife], unless it's absolutely necessary.'
quote_or_scene: Charlie Poe works at boat charter. Detectives confront him there with photos showing him with Harlin. He says: 'If you tell my wife... I never did anything, I swear. It wasn't me.' Detectives reply: 'We won't, unless it's absolutely necessary.' He explains he accepted money from Harlin for his kids' education in exchange for sex. He is questioned publicly but later cleared when real killer identified.
notes: Charlie Poe questioned at his workplace with nude photos shown. Clear public exposure in front of coworkers. Threatened with exposure to wife. Had sexual relationship with Harlin but innocent of murder. Later cleared when Alexander Strizhov confesses.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives threaten: 'We want to talk to Katya. You have her get in touch with us or find out where she is. By tomorrow.' Later: 'We know you're illegal. We're not Vice... if you're not at our office by 9:00 a.m., Immigration will be at your house by 9:05. That I can personally guarantee you.'
quote_or_scene: Sonya's fingerprint found at crime scene. Questioned multiple times, including at nightclub workplace in front of patrons and boyfriend/manager. Threatened with immigration consequences. Later murdered by Alexander Strizhov (along with her aunt) because she knew too much about the Harlin murder. Strizhov confesses: 'I told Sonya... sometimes you make stupid mistakes. I didn't want to kill her, but I had to. I know she called you.'
notes: Sonya innocent of Harlin murder but fingerprint at scene led to suspicion. Publicly questioned at workplace (nightclub). Threatened with immigration action. Her contact with police and knowledge of events led to her murder by Alexander Strizhov. Ultimate consequence of false accusation pathway was her death.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Benson threatens Katya: 'We know you're illegal... if you're not at our office by 9:00 a.m., Immigration will be at your house by 9:05. That I can personally guarantee you.' Later: 'You have the right to remain silent. You are under arrest...' Benson also insults her: 'Who are you? some sex machine with a cash register between her legs? Or maybe you're just too afraid to get involved... You make your living sleeping with guys. You should sleep with men more... trust me, it would help you. You wouldn't be such a mean bitch.'
quote_or_scene: Katya was Harlin's girlfriend, sued by him for $2M. Fingerprints at scene. Questioned at hotel in formal gown before event, threatened with immigration. Later brought to station and nearly arrested. Benson verbally degrades her. Katya admits to tying Harlin up and inserting banana as prank but denies murder. Alexander Strizhov confesses to killing Harlin out of obsessive love for Katya. She is cleared.
notes: Katya questioned publicly at hotel before formal event. Threatened with immigration action and arrest. Subject to degrading insults from Detective Benson about her profession. Admitted to being at scene and pranking Harlin but proven innocent of murder when Strizhov confesses. Lawsuit against her dropped after Harlin's death.

quote_or_scene: Judge: 'Remand the defendant to the Department of Corrections.' Lawyer to press: 'Judge Abrams' decision to remand was simply wrong-headed.' Captain Cragen to Stephanie: 'I was wrong, Miss Mulroney. Please accept my apologies to your family.'
tags: arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; remanded_without_bail; public_humiliation; powerful_family; political_pressure; wrong_ID; serial_killer_case
notes: Member of prominent political Mulroney family. Arrested for murder two after detectives conclude she lured victim Dean Woodruff (college acquaintance from alleged past sexual encounter) to his death. Held without bail despite family's objections. Second identical murder leads to confession by Arthur Prewitt, proving her innocence. Captain Cragen formally apologizes in chambers. Major media coverage throughout. Episode ends with Munch suspecting the powerful family orchestrated the outcome but having no proof.

consequence_detail: arrested, arraignment, perp_walk, media_circus, remanded_without_bail, public_humiliation, reputation_damage
quote_or_scene: Arraignment scene with press. Mrs. Mulroney: 'Staggered. It's simply beyond me how...' Rumsey: 'Judge Abrams' decision to remand was simply wrong-headed.' Judge dismisses case after Pruitt confession. Captain to Stephanie: 'I was wrong, Ms. Mulroney. Please accept my apologies to your family.'
tags: arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically; wrong_ID; fabricated_claim
notes: Stephanie Mulroney was publicly arrested and arraigned for murder of Dean Woodruff. She was remanded to Department of Corrections without bail. Major media coverage with press questioning family members. Theory was revenge for alleged date rape years earlier at Barrett College. Arthur Pruitt later confesses to being serial killer responsible for Woodruff and other shootings. Judge dismisses case and Captain Cragen formally apologizes. Severity 4 due to arrest, jail remand, massive public humiliation, life-altering media exposure for prominent family member. Proven innocent when actual perpetrator confesses.

police_conduct_quote: You climbed up her fire escape... you take it out on her... You're the one that did the rape... Same as putting a bullet through her.
quote_or_scene: Carlos arrested on street with Alfonso for drug possession, then interrogated about rape. 'You the one who raped her?' 'That's sick. I didn't rape no old lady!' DNA test clears him. Held at Rikers for days.
notes: Carlos was arrested, jailed at Rikers, and accused of rape during interrogation. DNA evidence proved him innocent of rape (though guilty of robbery). Exposure remained within law enforcement—no public accusation of rape outside police custody. Consequence severity 3 due to arrest and multi-day detention at Rikers, but no public rape accusation beyond police.

police_conduct_quote: You look nervous to me, Alfonso. Why is that? You the one who raped her?
quote_or_scene: Alfonso arrested with Carlos. Detective: 'You look nervous... You the one who raped her?' Alfonso: 'That's sick. I didn't rape no old lady!' DNA clears him. Attorney mentions 'last three days in here' at Rikers.
notes: Alfonso arrested and held at Rikers for 3+ days, accused of rape in interrogation. DNA proved innocence of rape (guilty of robbery). 17 years old. No public exposure of rape accusation beyond police/jail. Consequence severity 3 due to arrest and detention, but rape accusation contained to law enforcement.

police_conduct_quote: An elderly woman is dead. She was raped. And you and Carlos used to hassle her... Tell us, or you could tell the judge.
quote_or_scene: Emmanuel questioned at school (pulled from class). Detectives: 'An elderly woman is dead. She was raped. And you and Carlos used to hassle her.' Emmanuel provides alibi (methadone clinic with sister 8am-11:45am), which is verified.
notes: Emmanuel questioned as potential suspect based on past association with Carlos. School principal pulled his file. Detectives confronted him about the rape with veiled threat ('tell us or tell the judge'). Alibi immediately verified—at methadone clinic during crime. No arrest, no public exposure beyond being pulled from class for questioning. Severity 1: private questioning with implicit threat but no material consequence.

police_conduct_quote: You two were having an affair, she wanted to break it off, you'd lose her as a client... You killed her to protect yourself.
quote_or_scene: Weber admits to kissing Sylvia outside her room Saturday night but denies affair/murder. Detectives accuse him based on bartender witness and motive (losing client). DNA test clears him. He resigns: 'Brad Weber's DNA came back negative. He's also resigned his post as manager of the endowment.'
notes: Weber was working closely with victim on college endowment. Bartender witnessed them drinking together Saturday night. Weber admitted to kissing her but denied sex/murder. He was interrogated as prime suspect, gave DNA voluntarily which cleared him, but the exposure and investigation led to his resignation from managing the endowment. The accusation was delivered in private interview but became known to Dr. Hadley and college leadership, constituting workplace exposure.

police_conduct_quote: We've got a dead, raped woman, and you look pretty good for it... 'Boxing the clown' in woman's underwear? That's pretty freaky. And to us, 'buddy boy,' it's a short stretch of road between that and rape/homicide.
quote_or_scene: Fenwick arrested during hotel burglary. Detective Jeffries confronts him: 'That's our collar.' Detectives accuse him of escalating from burglary to rape/murder. Fenwick provides alibi (burglary at Soho East hotel during murder timeframe). Alibi confirmed: 'A guest at the Soho East reported a break-in on Sunday. Amongst the stolen goods was a diamond-studded dog collar.'
notes: Fenwick was a serial hotel burglar with sexual fetish (masturbating in victims' underwear). Matched description from earlier burglaries. Arrested during active burglary, interrogated for Sylvia's rape/murder. Alibi at different hotel confirmed his innocence of the SVU case. Exposure limited to arrest and interrogation setting with his lawyer present and competing detective task force. No evidence of broader public exposure beyond the arrest itself.

police_conduct_quote: You little snotnosed son of a bitch, you're going to tell me what I want to know. Now, you got that?! / Someone comes to me and wants to store illegal stuff in my garage, he's either my best friend, or I'm getting something out of the deal.
quote_or_scene: Keith's workplace scene: 'Keith. That son of a bitch.' Detectives arrive at his workplace and publicly confront him. Stabler verbally threatens: 'You little snotnosed son of a bitch, you're going to tell me what I want to know. Now, you got that?!' Keith eventually admits Waters stored files on his system without his knowledge of full illegal content.
notes: Keith was storing Harry Waters' illegal files on his computer system as part of their pornography business arrangement. He was initially presented as suspect but proven innocent of Waters' specific predatory crimes. Publicly confronted at workplace with colleagues present. Detectives used verbal threats and intimidation. Keith admits to participating in revenge porn business but was unaware of full extent of Waters' pedophilia activities. His computer was the storage location for Waters' criminal files.

police_conduct_quote: Take off your pants please... The oldest perv trick in the book. 'You want some change? You want some candy? It's in my pocket.' Only it's not coins or peppermints they find... it's your willy, Bruce.
quote_or_scene: Elderly witness screams 'Cut it out! Somebody help!' A man runs over and puts a full nelson on Bruce. Bruce is arrested on the subway car. Later, Captain tells psychologist: 'the police aren't going to charge you with the rapes. They know you didn't do it.' Seven rape victims fail to identify Bruce in lineup.
notes: Bruce Abbott was publicly wrestled to the ground on a subway, arrested, and his case was covered by reporter Nick Canzner (media exposure implied). He admitted to inappropriate contact (rubbing against a woman while lonely) but all seven previous rape victims failed to ID him. He was released when the real rapist (Sal Avelino) continued attacking. Police acknowledged he didn't do the rapes. Police used degrading language and coercive tactics during interrogation, calling him a pervert and demanding he remove his pants. The apology was only 'partial' - psychologist tells him 'they know you didn't do it' but no formal on-screen apology shown.

quote_or_scene: Arraignment scene: 'People v. Daoud Tarzi. One count attempted murder, second degree, one count rape in the first degree.' Defense: 'Not guilty on both counts, Your Honor.' Cabot: 'Your Honor, this was a particularly brutal crime. The victim was raped, stabbed, beaten, and left to die. We're asking for remand without bail.' Judge: 'The defendant is remanded without bail.'
notes: Tarzi is innocent of the attempted murder and stabbing (committed by Jaleel Amir). However, he did have consensual sex with Nafeesa who was a virgin, which he admits. The rape charge appears to be based on her being a virgin and possibly statutory/cultural issues. He was publicly arrested, arraigned, and remanded without bail. While partially involved (consensual sex), he was wrongly accused of attempted murder, stabbing, and forcible rape. The episode shows him being publicly exposed at arraignment with probable media coverage. His import-export business would be affected. Tagged as 'partially_involved' because he did have sex with her but did not commit the violent crimes.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Hamoud at apartment, initially thinking he's connected to Tarzi/Nafeesa. Later identified in photo: 'It's that guy from the apartment. Who said he never heard of her.' Chase scene: 'He made us.' 'Stick them in the air. Nice tackle.' Then he says: 'You won't find her! I'll never tell them where she is!' Detectives realize confusion: 'You'll never find her. We already did.'
notes: Hamoud is tackled by police who mistake him for being connected to Nafeesa's case. He had just moved into Tarzi's old apartment. His statement 'You won't find her! I'll never tell them where she is!' made police think he was involved, but this appears to refer to a different person/situation entirely. He is physically tackled and arrested but presumably released when the confusion is cleared up. The physical tackle constitutes assault/harm as a consequence of mistaken accusation.

consequence_detail: arrested, interrogated, charged with assault on Randall after acting on false belief, facing deportation
police_conduct_quote: Denny, now come on. It's time to come clean here, all right? For Emily's sake. It's just time to do the right thing. We wanna help you but you gotta tell us the truth.
quote_or_scene: Jamie tells case worker 'it was me' (Denny). Denny to detectives: 'I would never hurt my daughter.' Blood type excludes him. He later assaults Randall believing Randall molested Emily: 'I couldn't hand my daughter over to the man who was molesting her.'
tags: wrong_ID; fabricated_claim; arrested; coerced_confession; custody_dispute; immigrant; ruined_in_family; public_confrontation
notes: Denny is accused by Jamie (who told ACS it was him, not Randall). He's brought in for interrogation, pressured to confess. Blood analysis proves innocence. However, believing the false accusation that Randall molested Emily, Denny assaults Randall and faces criminal charges and deportation. His life is destroyed by the false accusation even after being cleared of the abuse itself.

consequence_detail: public_questioning_at_work, assaulted by Denny resulting in critical condition with cerebral hemorrhage
police_conduct_quote: Detectives to Randall: 'Denny Corea says you've been molesting her.' 'You had access. She slept in the next bedroom.' 'Of course, you could help expose our better halves by offering up a sample of your own.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Randall at his office: 'Denny Corea says you've been molesting her.' Randall responds: 'And you believed him? Look what he did to me.' He refuses sample, lawyering up. DNA later excludes him. Denny attacks him: 'I was on top of him hitting him again and again until I realized that he wasn't moving anymore.' Randall ends up in critical condition.
notes: Denny accuses Randall of molesting Emily. Detectives question Randall at his workplace, publicly accusing him. DNA analysis proves his innocence. However, Denny, believing the accusation, assaults Randall outside his office, putting him in critical condition with possible permanent disability ('may never walk'). Randall suffers near-fatal physical harm as a direct consequence of the false accusation.

consequence_detail: arrested, held in custody pending arraignment based on DNA match to his hairbrush
police_conduct_quote: Detective to Justin: 'Very clearly, we are trying to get you out of here. You understand that? Now, you keep talking in circles, you're gonna be spending your varsity years behind bars.'
quote_or_scene: Hair from Justin's brush matches rape kit sample. Detectives arrest him. Alex Cabot: 'We're holding Justin until he can be arraigned and then we'll release him into your custody.' Justin provides alibi (running in park). Jamie later confesses she used Justin's hairbrush to beat Emily, framing him.
tags: arrested; teen; db_error; fabricated_claim; held_overnight; ruined_in_family
notes: DNA from Justin's hairbrush matches evidence in the rape kit, leading to his arrest. He is held in custody and threatened with long-term imprisonment. His stepmother Jamie deliberately used his hairbrush to beat Emily, framing him. He is eventually cleared when Jamie confesses, but only after being arrested and detained.

consequence_detail: perp_walk, media_circus, death_threats, remanded_to_detention, expelled_from_school, family_threatened, physically_assaulted_by_vigilante
quote_or_scene: TRANSCRIPT: 'They're bringing the shooter up now.' [Perp walk scene with media present] / 'The protesters, death threats, the media trying to sneak into the building.' / 'Neighbors jumped him. Would have killed him if we hadn't been a block away.' [12-year-old TJ attacks Elias at end]
tags: perp_walk; media_outing; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically; school_alert; public_confrontation; fabricated_claim; teen; custody_dispute
notes: Elias is the central figure. He committed the shooting but is proven innocent of MURDER because: (1) he was in self-defense mode (saw gang members at fence who had murdered someone the night before), (2) he accidentally shot Carly while aiming at the gang members, (3) he lacked mens rea/capacity due to age (7) and trauma. The ADA withdrew all charges based on Dr. Olivet's testimony that he 'lacked the capacity to understand the consequences of his actions.' He suffered extreme public exposure (perp walk, media naming him, death threats to family, protesters outside home), was remanded to juvenile detention, expelled from school, and at episode's end is violently attacked by a 12-year-old vigilante who says 'Can't kill a sister and just walk.' This is a severity 4 case: life-altering harm including physical assault that nearly killed him. The 'accusation' is of intentional murder when it was actually a tragic accident by a traumatized child witness to murder.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler aggressively confronts Nash in interview: 'Mark, I tell you, you hit her so hard, she came out of her shoes. You felt bad, so you tried to put them back on her feet but you got them on the wrong feet, is that right?' Despite Nash's delusional state, Stabler presses for confession.
quote_or_scene: Nash is arrested at his apartment while reciting Crime and Punishment. Arraigned and remanded without bail. ADA Cabot coerces him into accepting anti-psychotic medication by threatening prison: 'I've got him cold for assault one... I'll rule it justifiable in exchange for a statement about the entire event.' Nash agrees to medication to avoid returning to Rikers. After being medicated and testifying, he commits suicide by strangulation in the hospital. Dr. Warner: 'The meds made him lucid. But with the voices gone, so were his friends. Loneliness led to depression and then to suicide.'
tags: arrested; perp_walk; coerced_confession; wrong_ID; suicide; legal_coercion; forced_medication
notes: Nash was the actual hero who defended Maggie by stabbing her attacker (Gilmore). He was schizophrenic and refused medication. Police treated him as primary suspect for rape/murder. Though technically arrested for assault (stabbing Gilmore), the context shows he was publicly accused of rape/murder, remanded without bail, and coerced into medication he didn't want. The medication compliance was forced as alternative to prison. His suicide is a direct consequence of being forced into lucidity he couldn't handle. Mother's final words to detectives: 'Go to hell.'

quote_or_scene: Moreland had stalked Maggie and had a restraining order. His fingerprints found at crime scene. When questioned in the Tombs after arrest for property destruction, he falsely confesses: 'Did you kill Maggie Sandomir?' 'I did.' He describes kicking and hitting her but can't explain how she actually died. He asks to do his time at Creedmoor psychiatric facility. DNA test clears him: 'the hairs found on Maggie Sandomir's body are not Mark Nash's' [and by extension not Moreland's either].
notes: Moreland was mentally ill (schizophrenic on anti-psychotics causing severe tremors/drooling). Had prior stalking history with victim. Gave false confession, possibly seeking psychiatric treatment facility over general prison. DNA evidence cleared him. His exposure was primarily through legal system (arrest, interrogation). No indication of public workplace/family exposure for the murder accusation specifically, though his earlier stalking was known to clinic and resulted in restraining order.

consequence_detail: arrested, perp_walk, charged, incarcerated_at_rikers, beaten_and_raped_by_inmates, murdered
police_conduct_quote: We've got your prints on the scene, your bizarrely circuitous escape route on tape, and your victim on her way down here to ID you as we speak... You're facing rape-one with a prior felony conviction. Given the degree of excessive force, you're looking at 25 years.
quote_or_scene: Ramsay repeatedly insists 'I never raped nobody' and 'It was a date. I met her at a bar. She gave me her room key.' At Rikers: 'You gotta help me... I can't sleep, all right? I gotta stay awake at night so I don't get ambushed... I can't look at a guy without getting jumped.' Later revealed: 'Russell Ramsay was attacked at Rikers. He was beaten and raped. He was killed.'
tags: fabricated_claim; arrested; perp_walk; charged_then_dropped; murdered; prior_conviction_weaponized; registry_used_to_target
notes: Ramsay was deliberately selected from the Sex Offenders Registry because of his prior statutory rape conviction, making him an easy target for the false accusation. His prior conviction was prejudicial and made him immediately credible as a suspect. The false accusation directly led to his incarceration at Rikers where, as a convicted sex offender accused of another violent rape of a minor, he became a target for inmate violence. He was beaten, raped, and murdered by other inmates. The episode explicitly states the legal theory: 'Your false allegation put him there. Under the law, you're responsible for his death.' No police apology is shown on screen. His ex-girlfriend Shelly Leevak consistently believed in his innocence throughout.

police_conduct_quote: That sense of humor is going to serve you well with your bunkmates up in Attica.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Hubert at his real estate office with board members present. They accuse him of rape and murder. Later proven innocent of murder (Lori confessed). The relationship was consensual and victim was 19, not 16.
notes: Hubert was having a consensual relationship with the victim (who lied about her age). He is accused of statutory rape and murder in front of board members at his workplace. Murder accusation proven false when Lori confesses. The statutory rape charge dissolves when victim's true age (19) is revealed. Detectives made degrading comments about prison. No apology shown.

police_conduct_quote: We got you on possession of stolen property. And we're a blood test away from nailing your little scruffy ass for rape. / You sons of bitches. You said I wouldn't have to take a needle. / Yeah, well, we lied.
quote_or_scene: Harry arrested for possession of victim's property found in bushes. Detectives threaten him: 'we're a blood test away from nailing your little scruffy ass for rape.' He pleads 'I can't stand needles. No needles, please.' They promise no needles to get confession, then force blood test anyway: 'Yeah, well, we lied.' Blood type doesn't match, clearing him.
notes: Harry is a homeless campus vagrant with petty theft/vagrancy record. Detectives use deceptive tactics (promising no needle, then forcing blood draw). Though interrogation was private, he was arrested and subjected to coercive threats. Blood test proves innocence. No public exposure beyond police interaction, but coercive treatment and arrest constitute harm (severity 2).

police_conduct_quote: If his DNA matches the semen from the rape kit... he'll be transferring to a campus upstate.
quote_or_scene: Detectives publicly arrest Joe at fraternity house in front of father and fraternity brothers: 'Joe Templeton... You're under arrest for possession of GHB and the rape of Kelly D'leah.' Father present, demands to see son. Later DNA test proves Joe's DNA does not match semen from rape kit, clearing him of rape charge.
notes: Joe arrested publicly at fraternity (his 'workplace'/community) for rape. Father and fraternity brothers present during arrest. Charged with rape based on circumstantial evidence (gonorrhea, victim's blood on sheets, GHB). DNA test later excludes him as rapist. He remains culpable for GHB conspiracy and giving victim gonorrhea, but was wrongly accused/arrested for the rape itself. Prior disciplinary history for similar pattern (Mandy Schumacher case). Public arrest at fraternity constitutes workplace/community exposure (severity 3).

police_conduct_quote: We'll start with possession, move to acting in concert... top it off with rape.
quote_or_scene: Hank arrested simultaneously with Joe at fraternity: 'Hank Ludlow... you're under arrest for possession of GHB, a controlled substance.' Threatened in interrogation with rape charges: 'possession, acting in concert... top it off with rape.' DNA later proves he did not commit rape.
notes: Hank arrested publicly at fraternity alongside Joe for GHB possession and implicitly threatened with rape charges during interrogation. DNA exclusion proves he did not rape victim. He remains culpable for GHB possession but was wrongly accused of rape. Public arrest at fraternity (his social/residential community) constitutes exposure (severity 3).

police_conduct_quote: We're a blood test away from nailing your little scruffy ass for rape... You sons of bitches. You said I wouldn't have to take a needle. Yeah, well, we lied.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Harry for possession of stolen property (Kelly's belongings found in his possession). They threaten him with rape charges: 'We're a blood test away from nailing your little scruffy ass for rape.' Harry pleads about needles, detectives promise no needles if he cooperates, then force blood test anyway. Blood type doesn't match semen, clearing him.
notes: Harry is a homeless man with petty theft/vagrancy record who found Kelly's belongings in bushes. Detectives arrest him, threaten rape charges, promise no needle if he talks, then lie and force blood test. Blood type clears him. Harm is contained to police interaction with coercive tactics and brief detention, but no public exposure occurred.

quote_or_scene: Detectives execute search warrant at Joe's fraternity room with other people present. Later arrest him publicly: 'Joe Templeton... put your hands right there. You're under arrest for possession of GHB and the rape of Kelly D'leah.' His father is present at precinct trying to see him. DNA test later clears him: 'Joe's and Hank's DNA don't match the semen from the rape kit.'
notes: Joe Templeton is arrested publicly at his fraternity house for rape and GHB possession in front of fraternity brothers and other students. His father witnesses the aftermath at the precinct. He is charged and processed, but DNA evidence proves he did not commit the rape (though still implicated in GHB conspiracy). The public arrest at a university fraternity would cause significant reputational harm in his academic/social community even though he's cleared of the rape charge specifically. Prior disciplinary record for different rape allegation (Mandy Schumacher case) complicates his situation but for THIS episode's rape, DNA clears him.

quote_or_scene: Arrested simultaneously with Joe: 'Hank Ludlow... you're under arrest for possession of GHB, a controlled substance.' DNA later clears him: 'Joe's and Hank's DNA don't match the semen from the rape kit.'
notes: Hank Ludlow is Joe's roommate, arrested publicly at the fraternity house for GHB possession and implicitly suspected of rape as Joe's accomplice. DNA evidence later proves he did not commit the rape. Public arrest at university fraternity causes reputational harm among peers and academic community even though cleared of the actual rape.

police_conduct_quote: Making me run on my bad knee. You're under arrest. You have the right to remain silent... Why'd you run? When did you and Miss Owens start knocking boots? She comes onto you, you get something going... then she wants to turn it off. You couldn't stand it... so what do you do?
quote_or_scene: Ethan arrested in public at teacher's memorial service: 'I got him. Move! Making me run on my bad knee. You're under arrest.' Detectives immediately accuse him of sexual relationship: 'When did you and Miss Owens start knocking boots? ...she comes onto you, you get something going... then she wants to turn it off. You couldn't stand it.' Ethan denies everything: 'Y'all got it all wrong, man! ...She never laid a hand on me. ...I was just trying to help her. ...She told me I could be somebody. I called her a whore.'
tags: public_confrontation; media_outing; coerced_confession; student; wrong_ID; ruined_publicly
notes: African American student with promising future (Temple scholarship) publicly arrested at his beloved teacher's memorial service in front of entire school community. Detectives immediately accused him of sexual relationship with teacher based on: (1) being last to see her alive, (2) nude photo found in his room, (3) fleeing when spotted. All evidence had innocent explanations: photo given by classmate Marcus who threatened to spread it, fled out of guilt for calling teacher 'whore' after she yelled at him for showing her the photo, was trying to warn her. Mother had to learn about nude photo investigation. Arrested in front of grieving students and teachers. Severity 3: public arrest, material reputational harm in school community, coercive interrogation.

police_conduct_quote: You said you met Marnie in a mentoring program. Sounds more like you were mentoring her. ...You jumped right in. Till she dumped me. Yeah. That's pretty rough. I've been there, pal. You're lonely, you go to her apartment to get back with her. She lets you in. You gotta have her. But she ain't giving it up. She turns her back on you. You force her into the bedroom.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Dr. Marks: 'You said you met Marnie in a mentoring program. Sounds more like you were mentoring her.' They paint detailed scenario: 'You're lonely, you go to her apartment to get back with her... You gotta have her. But she ain't giving it up... You force her into the bedroom.' Marks shown to have lied initially about nature of relationship (claimed mentoring program, was actually sex club). Lawyer cuts off interview. Alibi verified - doorman confirms he came home at 10pm, didn't leave until morning.
notes: Bellevue surgeon initially lied about how he met victim (claimed mentoring program vs sex club) and nature of relationship. Brother identified him as 'married doctor' having affair. Detectives used coercive interrogation painting detailed murder scenario. Had to retain lawyer. Was actually with victim night of murder (7-8:30pm) but alibi for time of death (10pm) verified by doorman. Lying about embarrassing sex life doesn't equal murder. Severity 2: subjected to accusatory interrogation with detailed murder scenario, but exposure remained with police and lawyer, no public outing or formal sanction.

quote_or_scene: Lindsay interrogated because she threatened Marchek at parole hearing, owned blue Honda matching stalker description, had access to ex-husband's 9mm. She admits stalking Marchek with gun but says 'I couldn't do it.' Ballistics clears her gun. Later murders of second victim with same MO prove she's innocent.
notes: Mother of rape victim Corrine Branson. Traumatized family living in isolation. Interrogated as murder suspect based on circumstantial evidence (threats, stalking, gun access). Exposure remained police-only with no public confrontation, so severity stays low despite interrogation stress.

quote_or_scene: Josh questioned about whereabouts night of murder. Stabler: 'Where were you last night?' Josh: 'I was in Chicago on business. You want the receipts? I can prove it.' Benson: 'No, that won't be necessary.' Stabler: 'Actually, it is.' Josh protests: 'You of all people.' Cleared by alibi.
notes: Father of rape victim. Divorced from Lindsay. Gun registered in his name. Questioned as suspect but quickly cleared with Chicago business trip alibi. Minimal harm—private questioning only.

police_conduct_quote: Cabot: 'You could threaten to kick up enough dust to re-open the Albany investigation.' Stabler uses personal empathy story to elicit confession attempt. Cabot threatens leveraging past 'bad shoot' case.
quote_or_scene: Winfield arrested at his auto shop in front of partner Paul Cormick. Stabler: 'Mr. Winfield, I won't forget about that first aid kit. You're under arrest for the murder of Thomas Marchek and Craig Moss and the attempted murder of James Campbell.' Charged based on circumstantial evidence (threats, gun ownership, alibis don't check). Ballistics later prove his 9mm didn't match murders—only the Campbell attempted murder. ADA Cabot suggests threatening to reopen his questionable police shooting in Albany as leverage.
notes: Ex-cop from Albany with early retirement after 'bad shoot.' Led Citizen Watch, distributed sex offender flyers, confronted/threatened parolees. Witnesses ID'd him as threatening Marchek with gun. Arrested publicly at workplace for two murders he didn't commit—only guilty of attempted murder of Campbell (firing shots to scare him away). Police/ADA considered leveraging his past to coerce confession. Cleared of murders when real killer (Louise) confesses. Severity 3: formal arrest, public workplace scene, coercive interrogation tactics, though ultimate charges partially stick (Campbell shooting).

quote_or_scene: Campbell to detectives: 'After they put me on that flyer, my boss fired me. Didn't want a pervert selling insurance.' His defense: 'I was 22. I met her in a club. I wasn't thinking a 15-year-old could even be out that late. She said she was 19... I didn't deny any of it, I went to prison. What more can I do?' Winfield's Citizen Watch distributed flyers with his photo/address. Winfield confronted him on street, grabbed him, threatened: 'if I didn't listen, I was gonna end up like the other two guys.' Someone fired shots through his apartment window (later revealed to be Winfield trying to scare him off).
tags: wrong_ID; fired; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; media_outing; physical
notes: Convicted of statutory rape (claimed consensual encounter with 15-year-old he believed was 19). Served time. On Citizen Watch flyer after release. Lost job as insurance salesman due to public exposure. Physically confronted and threatened by Winfield. Shots fired into his home (attempted murder by Winfield, who was trying to scare him into leaving neighborhood). Wife and daughter traumatized, sent to motel. Campbell is 'partially_involved'—guilty of the statutory rape conviction but the ongoing public persecution and violence are consequences of the flyer/vigilante campaign. Harm: job loss, physical attack on home, family displacement, public threats. Severity 3 due to firing, violent attack, family trauma.

person_label: Oliver Tunney (a.k.a. Jolly Ollie, a.k.a. Squiggles the Clown)
police_conduct_quote: We found balloons in your van. After a little dusting we'll find the girl's fingerprints, too. She's ready and willing to pick you out of a lineup.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Tunney on the street near his van: 'What's shaking there, Bozo?' 'Detective Tutuola and Munch.' 'You been keeping your nose clean?' Tunney is arrested on parole violation for having balloons in van. Later: 'Witnesses said they saw you at the county fair in Norwalk.' 'See? I told you I didn't do it. I'm innocent.'
notes: Prior sex offender targeted based on van ownership and prior record. Publicly confronted on street, arrested on parole violation. Alibi confirmed via Connecticut witnesses. Connecticut authorities pursue separate complaints. No explicit apology shown.

quote_or_scene: Detectives approach Hayes at his workplace: 'Joe Hayes?' 'Who's asking?' 'Detective Tutuola and Munch. Do you own a white van?' 'No. But I know what this is about.' 'Really? Illuminate us.' 'You think I killed those girls on account of that little Queens bitch.' Later Munch calls for '24-hour detail on a guy we're sitting on.' Show moves on to Clayton Mills as actual perpetrator.
notes: Ex-con with assault record and bad teeth identified by prior investigators. Publicly questioned at workplace in front of coworkers. Placed under 24-hour surveillance. Squad pivots away to actual perpetrator (Clayton Mills) without resolving Hayes's status on-screen, but investigative focus clearly shifts away, implying clearance.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Brad at the hospital: 'A woman's remains were found buried under the hydrangea behind your former brownstone.' Wife Pam is present and responds: 'Oh, my God.' Brad: 'I didn't kill Abbey.' They continue questioning him publicly before he has to scrub for surgery.
notes: Dr. Stanton was suspected of murdering his ex-wife Abbey. Detectives confronted him at the hospital in front of his current wife and likely colleagues. He was cleared when Abbey was found alive in hospice with AIDS-related dementia. The accusation was based on the pattern of abuse allegations and proximity to the burial site.

quote_or_scene: Detectives question Pam at her workplace: 'Why did you attack her?' Pam admits: 'I was angry. She was my friend once.' Then learns about the murder: 'A woman's remains were found buried under the hydrangea behind your former brownstone.' She's questioned as a suspect before being cleared.
notes: Pam was suspected alongside her husband of murdering Abbey. She was questioned at her workplace about the assault and the murder. Cleared when Abbey was found alive.

police_conduct_quote: Detective questions: 'Did you ever tame her? You know, S&M, bondage, discipline?' implying he was involved in the S&M-related murder.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Sloane about his relationship with Ava and the S&M items found with the body. Detective: 'Did you ever tame her? You know, S&M, bondage, discipline?' Sloane: 'I'm not into that.' He was cleared when his passport showed he was out of the country when Ava went missing.
notes: Sloane was questioned as a suspect based on his prior relationship with Ava and his arrest record for soliciting prostitution with S&M preferences. Cleared by alibi (passport records). Interview was private so limited public exposure, but detectives used confrontational tactics.

police_conduct_quote: Detective: 'You forced her to have sex with you. That's called rape. You pulled out fistfuls of her hair, knocked her teeth out. That's assault.' Detective: 'You think that we'd call you all the way down here if we couldn't [prove it]?'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Amis aggressively about abuse allegations. His wife May Ling is present. Detective: 'Restraining orders, filed by your first and second wives.' Detective: 'You forced her to have sex with you. That's called rape.' Amis: 'Prove it.' He's questioned about murdering Ava before being cleared.
notes: Paul Amis was accused of domestic violence against Ava and suspected of her murder. Detectives confronted him in front of his current wife with graphic accusations of rape and assault. He was cleared when investigation revealed Ava was alive and impersonating her sister. Wife witnessed the entire confrontation.

quote_or_scene: Paul Amis states: 'I didn't pay all that money for her to run around with some dentist.' The dentist is referenced as someone Ava had an affair with during her marriage to Amis, implying he was investigated as part of the case.
notes: Referenced but not seen on screen. The dentist Ava had an affair with was likely investigated as part of the case. Limited information about consequences. Flagged for potential exclusion due to lack of detail about exposure or harm.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Burton's home. His daughter Julia greets them. Detective: 'You reported your sister-in-law Ava Parulis missing... We may have [found her].' They reveal the murder in front of his wife (who they believe is Irina but is actually Ava). Later: 'Mr. Burton, we know how difficult this must be for you' as they question him about the murder. George learns his wife for three years was actually Ava impersonating her dead sister.
notes: George Burton was implicitly suspected when detectives investigated the murder of who they thought was Ava. He was questioned in front of his wife and child. The revelation that his wife Irina was actually dead and had been impersonated by Ava for three years caused massive family trauma. His entire marriage was a lie, and his daughter's mother was her aunt, not her biological mother. This is severe psychological harm stemming from the investigation's revelations.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Brad at hospital: 'I didn't kill Abbey. She was busy killing herself with her habit.' Wife Pam present, says 'I told you he was busy.' Brad presents proof Abbey is alive in hospice with AIDS.
notes: Brad is accused of killing his ex-wife Abbey based on bones found in yard of former home. He is confronted publicly at hospital in front of his current wife Pam and presumably colleagues. Proves Abbey is alive by showing her in hospice. Clears himself immediately with evidence.

quote_or_scene: Detectives ask Pam: 'Why did you attack her?' referring to Abbey. Pam admits beating Abbey but context shows victim is alive. When informed of bones: 'A woman's remains were found buried... They've been there about three years.' Pam: 'Oh, my God.' Then cleared when Abbey shown to be alive.
notes: Pam is suspected of possibly killing Abbey (first wife) after admitting she beat her up years earlier. When bones are found, she becomes potential suspect alongside husband Brad. Cleared when Abbey is proven alive. Exposure primarily to husband and detectives.

police_conduct_quote: Detective asks: 'Did you ever tame her? You know, S&M, bondage, discipline?' regarding his relationship with Ava
quote_or_scene: Detectives interview Sloane about Ava. 'Did you love Ava?' 'It was a business arrangement.' Passport proves he was out of country when Ava reported missing, clearing him.
notes: Matt Sloane is questioned as former boyfriend of Ava with known S&M interests matching evidence (collar/leash). Interview involves sexually explicit questions. Cleared by passport showing he was abroad during relevant timeframe. Exposure limited to police interview, no public consequence beyond questioning.

quote_or_scene: Detectives interview Paul Amis (dentist who brought Ava to US as mail-order bride). He provides Ava's dental records which later prove the body is NOT Ava, clearing him of any involvement in her death.
notes: Paul Amis brought Ava to US as fiance/mail-order bride, relationship ended. Questioned as potential suspect. His provision of dental records proves victim is NOT Ava, effectively clearing him. Exposure limited to police interview.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives confront him with: 'You forced her to have sex with you. That's called rape. You pulled out fistfuls of her hair, knocked her teeth out. That's assault.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives bring man to precinct, confront him publicly with record of civil harassment suit and restraining orders from two wives. 'You forced her to have sex with you. That's called rape.' Man responds: 'Prove it.' Investigation moves away from him after Ava's true identity revealed.
notes: Man with documented history of abuse (civil harassment suit, restraining orders from two ex-wives) is brought in and aggressively questioned about Ava/Irina's murder. Accused of rape and assault. Cleared when investigation reveals Toscu as actual killer. Has preexisting workplace sexual harassment allegation. Questioning appears to occur at precinct but his record is discussed openly.

quote_or_scene: Detectives inform George his wife Irina is dead: 'The dental records prove it... Irina is buried in that grave.' George responds: 'My wife can't be dead. What are you talking about? You're crazy.' Later learns wife he's been living with for 3 years is actually sister-in-law Ava who assumed Irina's identity. Detectives investigate if he knew.
notes: George Burton is implicitly investigated as possible accomplice when detectives discover his 'wife' is actually Ava impersonating murdered Irina. His genuine shock and grief at learning truth strongly implies innocence. Consequence is devastating revelation his marriage was a lie and real wife was murdered 3 years prior. Exposure to family (daughter present in home during investigation) and emotional trauma of discovery.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Spector at his janitorial job at LaGuardia Airport about the murder. Stabler asks: 'You get in her face? You have words? You threaten her?' Spector responds: 'I didn't threaten. I said I wasn't going without a fight and that she'd be sorry.' When told the victim is dead, he asks 'Is that true?' and denies involvement. Later states Ronnie came to see him about a week ago about getting him reinstated, and 'I got the impression that he wasn't her little pet anymore' (referring to Jason).
notes: Greg Spector was fired by the victim (Veronica Tandy) after Jason Mayberry accused him of using security cameras to zoom in on women's body parts. He threatened her after being fired but did not commit the murder. Detectives questioned him publicly at his workplace (LaGuardia Airport janitorial job) in front of coworkers. The investigation clearly pivots away from him when he provides alibi information and states that the victim had recently contacted him about reinstatement, suggesting Jason was no longer in her favor. Jason Mayberry is later revealed as the actual perpetrator who confesses to the crime.

police_conduct_quote: We're gonna send you back for slicing up a hooker when you were done with her.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at construction site: 'Can I help you?' 'Yeah. Police. We're looking for Norman Fredericks.' Worker calls: 'Norm, the cops are here.' Fredericks runs. 'I didn't do anything!' 'Innocent people always run. Norman Fredericks, you're under arrest for murder.' 'Murder?' 'Yeah. That prostitute you killed last night? We found your DNA inside her.' 'I picked up a whore, so what?' 'So it's a parole violation, pal.' 'You're gonna send me back upstate just for that?' 'We're gonna send you back for slicing up a hooker when you were done with her.' 'I didn't slice up anybody.' Later cleared when another victim murdered while he had alibi: 'M.E. says Folsom was killed sometime between midnight and 1:00 a.m.' and Fredericks 'didn't get home until 2:30 this morning.' Lab confirms: 'two different blood types at the last murder scene... Neither matches Fredericks.'
notes: DNA from semen matched Fredericks in sex offender database, connecting him to prostitute Cassie Horner. Arrested at workplace in front of coworkers for murder. Cleared when second murder occurred during time he had alibi (on Staten Island Ferry at midnight-1am). Blood evidence at second scene didn't match him. Booked on parole violation for soliciting prostitute but exonerated of murder. Public arrest at construction site = severity 2 (exposure without ultimate conviction). Threatening police language during interrogation.

police_conduct_quote: Do you have any idea what they do to child molesters in prison? I'm sure that they'll grow very attached to you once they find out why you're there.
quote_or_scene: Court: 'Case dismissed. Mr. Ramsey, you're free to go with the court's apology.' Wife confronts him outside court: 'Wasn't I enough? I trusted you! You disgust me!' Medical records show Megan is a virgin; sodium amytal therapy implanted false memories.
tags: public_confrontation; arrested; perp_walk; fabricated_claim; murdered; family_destroyed; ruined_in_family; media_outing; false_memory_syndrome
notes: Victim of therapist-induced false memory syndrome. Daughter Megan believed she was raped due to manipulative therapy with sodium amytal. Medical exam proved Megan was virgin (intact hymen), conclusively disproving rape allegations. Megan then fabricated physical evidence (planted pornography and underwear). Evan arrested publicly at home in front of family, charged, wife filed for divorce believing him guilty. Case dismissed when fabrication discovered. Court formally apologized. Days later murdered by daughter Jody during confrontation with Megan. Ultimate severity: death, though not by vigilante/stranger but by family member in shooting described as accidental during confrontation.

quote_or_scene: PLUMMER: 'I was beaten, raped and tortured. I finally learned to stop screaming, that only made it worse. Please don't dismiss what I went through by telling me I got a fair trial.' | LAWYER: 'He spent seven years upstate.' | BENSON: 'DNA wasn't used then. The guy wasn't working, didn't have an alibi, couldn't remember where he was... This guy was an innocent man and I helped put him away. I made the People's case against him with weak evidence.'
tags: wrongful_conviction; prison_rape; prison_torture; ruined_physically; exonerated_by_DNA; weak_evidence; eyewitness_misID
notes: Plummer was wrongfully convicted of rape and attempted murder based on eyewitness ID and weak circumstantial evidence presented by Det. Benson (pre-DNA era). He served 7 years in prison where he suffered extreme physical and sexual violence. Later exonerated, he changed his name to Norman Webber but became the perpetrator of revenge murders. Including him because he represents the 'lives harmed by false accusations' that the show examines, even though he later became a killer. His harm severity is 4 (life-altering: wrongful imprisonment, torture, rape). The episode explicitly acknowledges the systemic failure and Benson's role. FBI agent confronts detectives over lack of protective detail, which escalates to manhunt. Public exposure at his new workplace when police showed up.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Cook at Little League practice in front of his son: 'We're here about your son... Jennifer Talmadge... Her son disappeared. We think you're the father.' Cook and his ex-wife Linda and son Brandon are required to provide DNA samples. Cook says: 'I resent being dragged in here, having to prove my son is my son.' Linda Cook: 'If you kept it in your pants... And now we're murder suspects.'
notes: Cook is publicly confronted at his son's Little League practice and accused of being the father of Jennifer Talmadge's murdered baby, implying potential involvement in murder/kidnapping. He and his family are required to submit to DNA testing. DNA proves Brandon is Cook's biological son with Linda, not Jennifer's child, clearing him completely. The accusation occurs in front of his children (students/players). His ex-wife explicitly states they are now 'murder suspects.' Severity 2: public exposure in front of family/students without formal arrest but with serious reputational harm and invasive DNA testing requirement.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler to date Nashika: 'I bet he didn't even mention that he's HIV positive, did he?' (publicly revealing medical status). Interrogation: 'I don't like you.' Leon's mother: 'You murdered him... you killed him anyway.'
quote_or_scene: Leon confronted publicly in front of his date outside building: Stabler tells her Leon has HIV. Later arrested for attempted rape of Nashika Morris. Becomes prime suspect in serial murders (Aisha Thompson, others). Found dead of overdose. Mother says: 'My son was innocent... You murdered him.' Stabler to mother: 'I'm sorry about Leon.'
tags: public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; arrested; wrong_ID; perp_walk; death
notes: Leon Tate has criminal history (sodomy conviction, HIV-positive, targets minors) BUT is innocent of the serial murders he's suspected of committing. He is publicly exposed when Stabler reveals his HIV status to his date, arrested for attempted rape (interrupted before act), and becomes prime suspect in multiple murders. He dies of drug overdose while under suspicion. Mother explicitly states he was innocent of the murders and blames police for his death. DNA later proves Malik Harris committed all the murders Leon was suspected of. Severity 4 due to death occurring while wrongly suspected.

quote_or_scene: Detective questions him about Kleberg murder. Martin explains: 'Before the cream, I couldn't even talk to a woman.' He was arrested for attempted rape/assault after medication trial. Spent 6 months in prison. Says Kleberg lied in court, wouldn't admit side effects caused his violent behavior. DNA clears him of current murder/rape.
notes: Martin participated in Dr. Kleberg's impotency cream trial. Suffered violent side effects, attacked woman on subway, assaulted two men who intervened. Arrested, convicted despite claiming medication caused behavior. Doctor testified against him, denied connection. Served 6 months prison. Filed lawsuits but excluded Kleberg as 'judgment-proof.' Now works menial job cleaning pigeon droppings. Initially suspected in Kleberg murder due to known grudge and prior violence. DNA evidence proves innocence. Severe life consequences from original medication-induced incident where doctor refused to support his defense.

police_conduct_quote: Detective: 'You went back for the money. You got even with your dad.' Jesse: 'No. No, no, no! No.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Jesse at OTB racetrack, stop his bet, imply he's under investigation. Later interrogate him: 'Where were you Tuesday night, Jesse?' Accuse him directly: 'You went back for the money. You got even with your dad.' Jesse's mother (who funds Police Athletic League) complains of 'false arrest.' DNA clears him.
notes: 18-year-old college student, Dr. Kleberg's son from first marriage. Estranged from father after dad remarried Peyton. Compulsive gambler, $100K in debt to bookie. Father caught him trying to steal jewelry weeks before murder, cut off trust fund. Publicly confronted at racetrack, stopped from placing bet in front of other gamblers. Interrogated as patricide suspect due to motive (money, resentment). Mother hired attorney, complained to Captain about treatment. DNA sample voluntarily given, proves innocence. Suffered family exposure, public questioning, and accusatory interrogation.

quote_or_scene: Detectives execute search warrant at Peyton's home, find hidden jewelry. ADA Cabot: 'If you were almost anybody else, you would have been arrested for insurance fraud on the spot.' Peyton brought to precinct, confronted with husband's mistress Lara Todd sitting in waiting area. Detectives accuse her of staging robbery/rape, hiring hitman with $10K cash withdrawal. She explains money was for private investigator to track cheating husband.
notes: Rape victim and widow investigated as potential mastermind behind husband's murder. Detectives theorize she discovered affairs, hired Vincent Boyd as hitman, staged own rape. Evidence: threatened mistress 3 days before murder, withdrew $10K cash, jewelry 'stolen' then found hidden in apartment. Home searched via warrant. Brought to precinct, publicly confronted with mistress. ADA threatens arrest for insurance fraud. Cleared when investigation proves Vincent acted independently due to obsession with Lara Todd. Peyton was genuine victim but suffered investigative exposure, home invasion by police, public humiliation at precinct, and accusation of conspiracy to murder. ADA offers partial apology acknowledging she would've been arrested if not wealthy.

police_conduct_quote: Hawk to Roger: 'You're going back to jail, and this time I'm gonna see to it they strap you down and put a needle in your arm... I saved your sorry ass so you can die my way. My way!' Earlier (18 years ago): 'I put Roger in the box and I grilled him over and over and over, till I convinced myself he'd been in those apartments. I fed him every detail of the case. And then I told him that if he signed that confession, he'd go home to his mother.'
quote_or_scene: Hawkins admits: 'I put Roger in the box and I grilled him over and over... I fed him every detail of the case. And then I told him that if he signed that confession, he'd go home to his mother. Poor dumb son of a bitch believed me.' Roger later alibied by neighbor. Hawkins acknowledges: 'I took 18 years from an innocent man. God knows how many women died because of it.'
notes: Roger Berry is borderline intellectually disabled ('borderline retarded' per dialogue). Detective Hawkins obtained a false confession 18 years prior by repeatedly interrogating Roger, feeding him case details, and falsely promising he could go home to his mother if he signed. Roger spent 18 years in prison for crimes committed by Arthur Blessard. The real killer continued murdering during Roger's incarceration. Roger was re-accused when similar murders resumed after his parole, subjected to additional threatening interrogation by Hawkins, but eventually cleared via neighbor alibi and DNA evidence. This is a severity 4 case: wrongful conviction resulting in 18 years of imprisonment.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'You want to go down for this? You want to go down for raping and beating your own sister?' Detectives arrest him at what appears to be the gang's house/workplace in front of others.
quote_or_scene: STABLER: 'Well, robbery places you at the scene of her attack there, Johnny. Do you want to go down for this? You want to go down for raping and beating your own sister?' Johnny is arrested during a warehouse bust. Later cleared when true perpetrator identified through DNA.
notes: Johnny Chen was Helen's brother and member of Ghost Shadows gang. He robbed the warehouse where Helen was lookout, but did not rape her. Detectives publicly arrested him at the gang house and accused him of raping his own sister. He explains he found Helen after the attack but fled when sirens approached. He is cleared once DNA evidence points to Darrell Guan. The accusation and arrest occurred in front of gang associates (coworkers in criminal enterprise).

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'Why don't we stop with the performance, Dao?' BENSON: 'Or maybe it had nothing to do with them. Johnny Chen said that you're not good enough for Helen. He embarrassed you, made you feel stupid. But you're not stupid. You're a smart guy, right? You raped her while your friends robbed the warehouse.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Dao at Pho Hoa Restaurant in front of his Born to Kill gang associates. BENSON: 'Where's Dao Tran?' Detectives question him publicly about Helen's rape. Dao denies involvement and accuses Johnny Chen. Later cleared when DNA identifies Darrell Guan.
notes: Dao Tran was Helen Chen's boyfriend and member of Born to Kill gang. Johnny Chen initially accused Dao of ordering the rape. Detectives publicly confront Dao at his restaurant hangout in front of gang members, accusing him of rape. Dao maintains innocence and says Johnny ordered it. He is cleared once DNA evidence points to Darrell Guan. The confrontation occurs in his gang's gathering place (workplace equivalent) with multiple associates present.

police_conduct_quote: FIN: 'See, he wasn't being inappropriately friendly, he was schmoozing up a future boss.' / 'Inappropriate?' / 'Listen, the kid never had a father figure...' / FIN: 'You make toys for all of them?' / MUNCH: 'You really want to do this in front of them? Damage their little psyches?'
quote_or_scene: MUNCH: 'Danny Marston?' / 'Yeah.' / 'Steal a minute of your time?' / 'Sure. Hey, keep it going guys.' [Detectives confront Danny at Youth Rec Center in front of the kids he coaches] / MUNCH: 'You really want to do this in front of them? Damage their little psyches?' / DANNY: 'I am not a pedophile. And I refuse to stop helping kids in need just to avoid being labeled one.'
notes: Danny Marston, a construction worker who volunteers with youth programs and coaches Little League, befriended Cassie and made her small toys. Detectives publicly questioned him at the Youth Rec Center in front of children he was coaching, asking about inappropriate behavior. He explicitly states 'I am not a pedophile' and protests being labeled one for helping kids. He is later cleared when Glenn identifies himself as the person at the crime scene. Danny was publicly humiliated in front of the children he mentors—severity 2 for public exposure without formal sanction.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'Were you watching the girls?' / 'Cassie. Cassie. Cassie.' / BENSON: 'Glenn. Glenn, do you know how Cassie got hurt?' / STABLER: 'Were you playing games?' / GLENN: 'Gorgon. Gorgon killed her.' / [Glenn then has violent breakdown, screaming and hurting himself]
quote_or_scene: STABLER: 'Glenn, we found your sword. The one that you left with Cassie.' / STABLER: 'Were you watching the girls?' / BENSON: 'Glenn, do you know how Cassie got hurt?' / STABLER: 'Were you playing games?' / GLENN: 'Gorgon. Gorgon killed her.' / DOROTHY: 'Please, I know he didn't mean to. It had to be an accident.' / [Glenn begins screaming and hurting himself] / BENSON: 'Glenn.' / DOROTHY: 'You're hurting him! You're hurting him! You're hurting him!' / [Later] CRAGEN: 'Psych unit at Hillview.' / STABLER: 'Your boy had a psychotic break.'
tags: teen; family_member; psychotic_break; wrong_ID; coerced_confession; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically
notes: Glenn, a 14-year-old foster son with developmental delays and history of severe childhood sexual abuse, was the primary suspect after his sword and knife were found at the crime scene with Cassie's hair. Detectives interrogated him in front of his foster mother and grandmother. The interrogation caused him to have a complete psychotic breakdown requiring psychiatric hospitalization. He was actually trying to SAVE Cassie (moving her body to the construction site in a delusional video-game-inspired rescue attempt) after witnessing Dorothy and Jane torture and beat her to death. Glenn is later proven innocent when the true perpetrators (Dorothy and Jane) are identified. His consequence is severity 4: psychotic break requiring hospitalization, life-altering mental health crisis triggered by the accusation and interrogation. The interrogation tactics were coercive and caused severe psychological harm to a vulnerable abuse victim.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'You were drowning in bills. Did you kill her for the money?' and 'Now, if she choked, then you either knew about it or you killed her outright. In that case, you're gonna do some time yourself.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives interrogate Andrew about Sydney's death, accusing him of murder for insurance money. STABLER: 'You were drowning in bills. Did you kill her for the money?' BENSON: 'Which is it, murder or accident? Now, if she choked, then you either knew about it or you killed her outright. In that case, you're gonna do some time yourself.' Andrew reveals his wife was using drugs again and had been involved in raping a male stripper, providing an alternative suspect.
notes: Andrew is questioned as initial murder suspect due to financial motive (50k insurance payout). No public exposure - interrogation remained private. Cleared when evidence emerges that Sydney's death was staged by her co-rapists to prevent her cooperation with Peter's civil suit. Police use threatening language during interrogation but accusation never becomes public.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'You raped her, you cut her open. Then you beat up another woman to keep her mouth shut.' FIN: 'You killed the baby.' Also: 'We're gonna take you in for a little DNA test, prove you raped her. That's all the truth we need.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Novacek at his workplace, accusing him of rape and murder in front of coworkers. MUNCH: 'Kyle Novacek?' NOVACEK: 'What, I'm on every cop's list now? Third time this year with you guys.' FIN: 'How'd the program go?' NOVACEK: 'What program?' FIN: 'The methadone treatment.' Later: STABLER: 'Where is it? The baby.' NOVACEK: 'What the hell you talking about?' FIN: 'It's alive, you can still get out of this without a broken neck.' NOVACEK: 'You telling me somebody hurt that baby?'
notes: Novacek had legitimate connection to victim (was her secret lover and father of the baby), but was not the attacker. His fingerprints were on victim's car because he test-drove it the previous week. DNA test and alibi (Brooklyn College class, work until 6pm) cleared him. Detectives accused him publicly at his workplace, threatened him with death penalty ('broken neck'), and falsely claimed they had evidence. No apology shown.

quote_or_scene: BENSON: 'This is what I'm thinking. You and your boyfriend follow Nicole Manning into the parking garage. You have a fight, it gets a little out of hand, your boyfriend goes crazy, not your fault.' ERIN: 'I don't have a boyfriend.' BENSON: 'Must have been jealous of Nicole. The woman who took everything from you, and now she's having her own baby.' ERIN: 'Get out.' Later when arrested for probation violation: BENSON: 'What happened to your face?' ERIN: 'I got hit.' STABLER: 'Someone's fist, looks like.' ERIN: 'I really, really need to get out of here, okay?' BENSON: 'Someone's afraid that he's going to hurt you, just like he did Nicole. Who're you hiding from?' ERIN: 'Kyle. Nicole's [boyfriend].'
notes: Erin had motive (Nicole reported her for drug diversion, causing her to lose job and nursing license, plus her son was taken by CPS). Detectives suspected her and 'boyfriend' as accomplices. She was physically assaulted (visible facial injury) - appears to have been beaten by someone to keep quiet about what she knew. When pressed about who she's hiding from, she points to Kyle (Novacek), Nicole's actual boyfriend, suggesting she knows he's being wrongly accused and is afraid of retaliation. The beating appears to be consequence of being suspected/questioned, not the original accusation itself. Cleared when husband Richard Manning is identified as perpetrator.

quote_or_scene: Officers chase and arrest Scotty near marina after he flees when spotting police light. Interrogated with interpreter about double murder/mutilation. Detectives suggest: 'Well, body parts can get heavy.' Scotty responds: 'I had nothing to do with this.' Released when duffel bag contains stolen laptops/jewelry, not body parts. No bloodstains on him despite bloody crime scene.
notes: Arrested at crime scene, interrogated as murder suspect, but quickly cleared when recovered bag contained burglary evidence rather than body parts. Handed to burglary division. Exposure limited to police interaction - no sign of workplace/family/media notification.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'We've got your knife, kid. It's only a matter of time before they find the victims' blood on it.' Also: 'You're a sadistic sociopath. You like to take your time, draw out the pain. You get off on the control and the domination.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives search Harry's bedroom while mother present, finding books on serial killers and calling him a 'sadistic sociopath' in front of her. Mother protests: 'That's not true. Harry?' Harry arrested, booked, interrogated at length about double murder. Stabler to Cragen: 'We need to get Harry off the street.' Released when evidence shifts to Poletti. Later encounter: STABLER: 'Come here, you sick little freak.' No apology shown.
notes: Arrested and booked ('Just finished processing Harry'). Mother present during bedroom search and hears detectives call her son a sociopath. Interrogated with psychological manipulation tactics. While highly disturbing (animal torture history), ultimately released when investigation pivots to Poletti. No murder charges filed. Detective Stabler later confronts him publicly calling him 'sick little freak' with no consequences, demonstrating ongoing harassment despite release.

quote_or_scene: MARCOSI: 'Had you been in our position, you would have done the exact same thing. Now do yours and help us out.' Response: 'You got some nerve asking me for help.' Later: 'You wasted your time fingering me.' / Earlier scene shows SVU taking him from precinct in front of fellow officers: 'OFFICER 1: I smell a rat. OFFICER 2: Make that three.' / 'I came off the West Side Highway...they got me riding a desk.' / Tucker explains to SVU: 'You made yourself look wrong' but investigation revealed he was not the rapist-killer.
tags: cop; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; wrong_ID; suspended; IAB_investigation
notes: Marcosi is tagged 'partially_involved' for innocence_status in that he admits to on-duty sexual misconduct (sex with prostitutes, breaking rules) but is strongly implied innocent of the rape-murder accusations. However, per rubric instruction to include only 'proven_innocent' or 'strongly_implied_innocent' in person_rows, and since he IS strongly implied innocent of the ACCUSED offense (rape-murder), he qualifies. The harm flows from the rape-murder accusation, not his separate misconduct. Public exposure occurred when SVU confronted him at his command, searched his locker in front of other officers ('I smell a rat'), and IAB investigation resulted in desk duty. Consequence is material sanction (desk duty, IAB investigation) = severity 3. No police apology shown. Detective Huang interviews him as suspect. Eventually evidence points to cop impersonator, clearing Marcosi of the sex crimes but not his other violations.

quote_or_scene: BENSON: 'Ross McKenzie?' / MCKENZIE: 'Yeah?' / BENSON: 'Detectives Benson and Stabler, we'd like to ask you a few questions.' / STABLER: 'We need answers about drug distribution and sex parties involving minors. You ready?' ... [Later at school] STABLER: 'Sorry to disappoint you, but you have an appointment with a needle.' / MCKENZIE: 'What, you want my blood? What for?' / STABLER: 'To match your DNA to a rape kit.' / CHAREST (principal): 'Mr. Charest, this is a mistake. They've got the wrong guy. I never raped anyone.' / CHAREST: 'I've already started the paperwork to fire you.'
tags: teacher; public_confrontation; arrested; fired; fabricated_claim; ruined_at_work
notes: McKenzie is publicly confronted in his classroom at Harrison High School, removed by detectives in front of colleagues and students, taken to precinct for DNA collection, and subjected to termination proceedings. His DNA conclusively exonerates him. While he admits to questionable ethics (attending student parties, offering ecstasy), he is proven innocent of rape. The victim Cynthia fabricated the accusation to protect her actual rapist (peer Nick Radsen) and maintain status in the 'popular crowd.' Principal explicitly states termination paperwork has been started. This is material job loss (severity 3) resulting directly from the false accusation.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'And you did it every which way you could.' Detectives imply he's a predator who 'extract[s] sexual favors and terrorize[s] women.' BENSON: 'Because she told you to get lost. And we all know how well you handle rejection.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives interrogate Prescott about hidden cameras in apartment he owns, confront him about videotaping women without consent including ex-girlfriend Valerie Baxter. BENSON: 'You having a good time with Cassie Germaine?' They accuse him of stalking behavior (flowers, calls) and assault. STABLER: 'Where were you night before last?' BENSON: 'Are you insinuating that I had something to do with her attack?' Prescott provides alibi: 'I was with a young lady... Her name is on the last tape. It's time-coded and it's dated.' Alibi later confirmed, clearing him.
notes: Prescott is morally questionable (secretly videotaped consenting partners, owns cameras in rental properties) but is innocent of the specific crimes: planting cameras in Cassie's apartment, stalking her with flowers/calls, and assaulting her. The actual perpetrator is Terry Willard. Prescott's reputation suffers from public police questioning and revelation of his videotaping history with multiple women. Detectives' confrontational tone treats him as predator before confirming his innocence.

police_conduct_quote: Arresting your punk ass... If that bitch is saying rape, she's lying... You raped her, you beat her to a bloody pulp
