quote_or_scene: Detectives enter bar with music playing, confront Gordon publicly: 'Arresting your punk ass.' Gordon arrested in front of bar patrons. Later interrogated: 'You raped her, you beat her to a bloody pulp and you left her to die while you tracked down her old man.'
notes: Gordon is guilty of raping Patricia but innocent of murdering her and attempting to murder Judge Thornburg. He was publicly arrested at a bar and charged with murder and attempted murder. While he confesses to the judge shooting ('Maybe I took a shot at the judge'), the DNA evidence only proves rape, not murder. Patricia's mother Brook ultimately confesses to the murder. Including for contrast as someone publicly exposed for crimes partially committed (rape yes, murder no).

quote_or_scene: Captain Cragen to Judge Thornburg in hospital: 'I'm afraid I have extended all the professional courtesy I can. I'm sure Brook told you we ran a paternity test on Brian. He's yours, Walter. You raped that little girl.'
notes: Judge Thornburg is guilty of child sexual abuse (impregnating his 11-year-old stepdaughter). He admits it when confronted privately by Captain Cragen. He is falsely suspected of murdering Patricia initially but is cleared. Not including as a qualifying false accusation row because: (1) he is guilty of the primary accusation (CSA), and (2) the murder accusation appears to remain with law enforcement only with no public exposure. Episode focuses on his actual guilt of CSA.

quote_or_scene: CLERK: 'Number 423154: People v. Daniel Ryan, Two counts Rape in the First Degree. One count Attempted Murder in the Second Degree. Two counts Grand Larceny' JUDGE: 'Bail is set at $500,000, cash only.' Later: FIN: 'Report's back. It's not his. He didn't rape Jessica Todd, Denise Johansen or anybody else.'
notes: Ryan is a locksmith student studying criminal justice with aspirations for law school. Con artists Crandall and Cormier planted jewelry and pantyhose in his work van to frame him. Ryan's fingerprints were legitimately at crime scenes because he installed locks there. He was arrested, faced multiple felony charges including attempted murder, and held on $500k bail (which he couldn't afford: 'Half a million? I can barely make my tuition'). DNA evidence proved his innocence. No indication of public exposure beyond the legal system itself - the accusation and arrest appear contained to police/court proceedings with no workplace, media, or family exposure shown.

quote_or_scene: CABOT: 'I'll drop the charges against your granddaughter as soon as we're done here.' Final scene shows charges dropped after Grace confesses to killing both children.
notes: Claire was falsely accused by her mother Grace of killing her baby sister Lisa 14 years prior. Grace claimed Claire had 'uncontrollable rages' and was prone to violence, supported by juvenile records. However, Claire was actually a witness who couldn't stop Grace from killing Lisa. Claire was arrested, booked, sent to Tombs, had arraignment set with $300k bail (posted by grandmother). Issued bench warrant when she missed court hearing. Eventually Grace confessed to killing both Lisa and an earlier infant Anthony. Charges against Claire dropped. While exposure was primarily within law enforcement and legal system, Claire suffered arrest, detention, bail requirements, and the trauma of being accused of her sister's murder. Harm includes legal jeopardy and psychological trauma from false accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Hey, my word against a moron's. / Detective: It just slipped out [after physical altercation]. / You think rape is funny?
quote_or_scene: Katie tells detectives bus driver Ray 'took things from her' and 'touched her.' Katie points to breasts and other areas. Detectives arrest Ray at his bus. Search warrant executed on apartment finds Katie's stolen necklace. Ray admits to petty theft but says 'I got a vasectomy. I'm shooting blanks.' Medical records confirm vasectomy two years prior, proving he cannot be the father.
notes: Ray was accused by Katie of touching her inappropriately and was arrested publicly at his workplace (the bus). While guilty of petty larceny (stealing necklace), he was innocent of rape as proven by medical records showing vasectomy. Bus company mentioned they would fire him. Detectives physically confronted him and engaged in verbal intimidation. Severity 3 due to public arrest at workplace and job loss.

quote_or_scene: Former instructor Joe Parker tells detectives: 'Last year, one of our 17-year-old clients turned up pregnant. She was so scared, she blamed it on me [Scott Lucas].' Lucas explains: 'I asked for a DNA study to confirm it. The baby was his [male client's].' DNA proved Lucas innocent and identified the actual father as another client.
notes: Lucas was falsely accused by a 17-year-old client in a prior incident (not Katie's case). The scared pregnant girl blamed Lucas, but DNA testing proved a male client was the father. Exposure remained limited to internal workplace investigation. No public exposure or material sanctions documented in transcript, so severity remains low despite the gravity of the accusation.

quote_or_scene: Katie tells Dr. Huang: 'I got my baby from Danny... Kissing, stupid.' Katie's mother Rebecca immediately demands: 'Aren't you going to have him arrested?' ADA Cabot responds: 'Katie's uncorroborated statement isn't enough... And we can't do a paternity test until the baby's born.' Later, Danny tells detectives: 'I didn't have sex with Katie. I love her and she loves me... Today, I told Katie what the teacher said about sex, and she didn't believe me.' Katie confirms she thought 'exercise' (actual rape by Cheney) was sex, not what Danny described.
notes: Danny was accused by Katie of being the father because she misunderstood what sex was. Katie's mother and detectives confronted him in front of Katie and family. Though not arrested, he was publicly accused and had to defend himself. The accusation was based on Katie's fundamental misunderstanding—she thought kissing and hand-holding made babies. Danny was actually trying to help Katie by teaching her the truth about sex and helping her escape the forced abortion. Severity 2 for public family exposure and accusation, though no formal sanctions imposed.

police_conduct_quote: Detective pressures Kyle about blood on his uniform: 'Blood stains kind of clash with the school colors, huh?' Implies guilt before evidence.
quote_or_scene: Kyle arrested in interrogation: 'Stand up. Why? Because we're planning on arresting you. For what? The murder of Lawrence Fuller.' Later: 'Bail is revoked. Defendant is remanded.' Released only after Barbarossa confesses: 'I'm bringing Barbarossa's confession before a judge tomorrow morning to formally drop the charges. Kyle's a free man by noon.'
tags: arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; charged_then_dropped; teen; family_member; custody_dispute; fabricated_claim
notes: Kyle is arrested for murdering his father based on (1) murder weapon (his baseball bat) found under his bed with his prints, (2) blood on his clothes, (3) being present at scene. He is publicly arrested, remanded to Rikers when bail is revoked. Media reports on the case. He is later exonerated when Frank Barbarossa confesses that Gloria orchestrated the murder and planted evidence to frame Kyle. Kyle was manipulated and potentially coerced by his stepmother/wife Gloria throughout.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives threaten: 'We got your DNA to match to the rape kit. That alone will get you 12-and-a-half to 25 years of personal training at Attica. Of course there's a murder conviction. That's another 25-to-life. Your parole officer hasn't even been born yet.' Also: 'The jury sees you, the schmuck trainer to the rich and famous. You're jealous, you want what they have.'
quote_or_scene: Barbarossa arrested: 'Frank Barbarossa? Police, Frankie. You're under arrest. What are you arresting me for? Raping Gloria Stanfield.' During interrogation detectives show him photos and threaten him with decades in prison. Later proven innocent when forensics show: 'This sperm was frozen... There's no way this semen could have come from a rape.' Gloria 'freezes it, she plants it on herself to set him up for rape. And murder.'
notes: Barbarossa is falsely accused of RAPE by Gloria Stanfield, who planted frozen semen (from previous consensual encounter) on herself to frame him. He is arrested, interrogated with threats and insults ('schmuck trainer'), and held. Forensics prove the rape accusation is fabricated. However, he IS guilty of murdering Lawrence Fuller (at Gloria's direction), so he ultimately goes to jail for murder, not rape. Including him because the RAPE charge was definitively false/fabricated, even though murder charge was valid.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Joe at his workplace in front of investors: 'I asked you to stay away from my investors. Three just pulled out.' Joe complains police are 'ruining me.' Later cleared when Hal Shipley confesses to the burns.
notes: Joe was suspected of abusing/burning his mother because he had financial motive (draining her accounts) and kept her restrained to a bed. Detectives publicly questioned his investors, causing three to pull out of his business deals. He suffered material business harm before being cleared when Hal confessed. His neglect/financial exploitation was real, but he was innocent of the torture burns.

police_conduct_quote: Detective implies Andy exploited grandmother: 'Gran won't write out any more checks. That must've pissed you off.' 'Sometimes she gives me presents.' 'She doesn't even know her own name. Must take some prodding on your part.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives barge into Andy's home (his mother answers), confront him about the party, suggest he's angry at grandmother for not writing checks, imply he hurt her. Andy's mother is present. Later, father Joe publicly blames Andy: 'No lip from you. You're the one that started this whole thing by letting that drug supplier into my house.' Andy is cleared when Hal confesses.
notes: Andy was suspected because he had financial motive (getting checks from grandmother) and was at the party. Detectives confronted him at home with his mother present, then his father publicly blamed him. While Andy did help Hal get fraudulent checks (making him 'partially_involved' in check fraud), he was innocent of the torture burns. The accusation created family conflict and public humiliation.

quote_or_scene: Arthur Esterman attacks Pomerantz at the precinct after he's brought in. 'Murderer!' Esterman shouts. 'I'll kill you!' Physical altercation breaks out requiring officers to intervene.
notes: Pomerantz has prior rape conviction and made threatening calls to Dr. Esterman about her notifying his wife of his gonorrhea. He is brought to the precinct and questioned in an interrogation room. While there, Arthur Esterman (the actual killer) arrives and physically attacks him, shouting 'Murderer!' The attack occurs in the precinct in front of detectives and staff. Pomerantz is proven innocent via alibi - verified at diner with waitress and coworkers, clocked in at work at 8am in Queens. The public attack by the grieving widower (who is the actual murderer) constitutes physical harm resulting from the false accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives imply he killed Dr. Esterman: 'Did you?' when he says he wishes he'd seen her death. Also treat him with contempt regarding his HIV status and sexual behavior.
quote_or_scene: Mario is questioned in hospital bed where he's being treated for AIDS-related pneumonia. Detectives ask: 'Is that why you killed her?' regarding Dr. Esterman. He responds: 'Doc got capped. Hmm. I'm crushed. Wish I'd seen it.' Detective: 'Did you?' Mario: 'Not from this bed.' Hospital records show he's been in for six days, clearing him.
notes: Mario Molinari is HIV-positive and had threatened Dr. Esterman ('Nosy bitch'). Detectives suspect him of killing her and confront him in his hospital bed. He is proven innocent via medical records showing he was hospitalized for 6 days with AIDS-related pneumonia, unable to commit the murder. The ADA later charges him with attempted murder and reckless endangerment for knowingly spreading HIV, but this is unrelated to the Esterman murder accusation. Since the murder accusation remained private (hospital room, no public exposure beyond police) and he faces no material consequence from the false murder accusation specifically, this case is borderline for inclusion. However, included because detectives treat him degradingly and accuse him of murder while he's hospitalized and dying.

quote_or_scene: Michael Kerring at precinct: 'Gregory. It's Mike from LA. I thought you were dead.' Detective responds: 'You're drunk. I don't know you.' Kerring: 'I swear, you got a twin out there.' Later Peter explains: 'He told us he was recognized by someone in your precinct.' AUSA Williams: 'Perlman has eyes everywhere.' Peter is later shot and killed during his son's arrest. Detective Stabler: 'Dad!' Peter's son Gavin screams: 'Dad! Oh, my God. Dad! No!'
tags: wrong_ID; WITSEC; murdered; cover_blown; mob_target; public_confrontation; witness_protection_compromised
notes: Peter Sipes was a federally protected witness (WITSEC) who testified against Russian organized crime. DNA initially pointed to him as the serial rapist, but Y-chromosome analysis proved his son Gavin was the actual perpetrator. Peter's cover was blown when Michael Kerring (a former criminal associate) recognized him at SVU precinct. This recognition led to Peter being moved by US Marshals and ultimately to his murder by Russian mob hitmen during a supervised visit with his son. His entire witness protection was destroyed as a consequence of being falsely suspected. The investigation's exposure of his identity and location directly led to his assassination. AUSA Claudia Williams explicitly states detectives 'endangered his life' by their investigation tactics.

police_conduct_quote: The second the Rawleys find out I broke the restraining order, they'll have me arrested. / Detectives: Really? How's your sex life been lately? / Call me a hopeless romantic, but I don't see a little court order standing in the way of your undying love.
quote_or_scene: STABLER: Really? How's your sex life been lately? / DAVID: None of your business. / BENSON: It is now. / STABLER: If you two think... / DAVID: You two are sick. Besides, I haven't seen her in months.
notes: Fiancé initially suspected and threatened. Later excluded via paternity test (blood type). Exposure remained within police interrogation room with no public exposure or material consequences beyond the interrogation itself.

quote_or_scene: BENSON: You do these exercises with Stephanie Rawley? / JENSEN: Three times a week... / STABLER: She's hooked to life support. You roll those machines up here? / JENSEN: I have a special routine for the coma patients. I can do them in their beds. / STABLER: You don't say.
notes: Physical therapist questioned due to access to victim. Suggestive questioning ('You don't say') but no public exposure or material consequences. Later excluded via DNA/blood type.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: Come on! Don't split hairs with me, Wesley! Come on! / And we had a big laugh at your expense. / You can't trust a woman with a pulse.
quote_or_scene: STABLER: Kind of late to be paying your respects, isn't it? Guess you two were close. Really close. You like the quiet type, huh? / Scene shows detectives playing videotape of Wesley with corpse during interrogation. / ADA CABOT: The only thing rendering Mr. Dilbert limp is the 12-to-25 he's facing on rape one... / Court: Bail's set at $5,000. / MR. RAWLEY: So he'll be out by morning. Free to ruin someone else's daughter.
notes: Necrophiliac arrested and charged with sexual misconduct after videotape evidence. Publicly identified as rape suspect in court ('number-one suspect in the rape of a comatose patient'). Later excluded via fetal blood type analysis (AB fetus, Wesley type A). Arrested, publicly accused in court, subjected to degrading interrogation. Work exposure when detectives interview him at workplace ('You're gonna get me fired').

quote_or_scene: STABLER: I know the drill. Somebody committed a crime, so let's check out the black guy. / HILL: That stinks of racial profiling. / BENSON: We're looking at everyone. / STABLER: Where's your probable cause? What about a search warrant? This flies in the face of the Fourth Amendment. / HILL: If you decide not to volunteer, you're presumed guilty. / Scene shows another employee (Baltzer) present during confrontation.
notes: Black custodian publicly confronted at work with colleague (Baltzer) present. Accused of racial profiling and defended civil liberties. Public workplace exposure with coworker witness qualifies as severity 2 (public exposure without formal sanction). Later excluded via DNA/blood type.

quote_or_scene: STABLER: I'm sorry to have to say this, it's standard procedure, but I should get a DNA sample. / ROBERT RAWLEY: [assaults officer] / STABLER: You just assaulted a police officer. It's your call. / BENSON: No, it's okay. It's okay. / Later: HUANG: Questioning the father as a suspect is never a crowd-pleaser. / STABLER: Verbal vitriol you'd expect, anyone else think the father protests a bit too much?
notes: Father questioned as suspect in front of wife. Stabler asks for DNA sample, father physically assaults officer. Wife present during accusation qualifies as public exposure within family. Later excluded via blood type. Partial apology ('It's okay') after assault. Father's strong reaction ('protests a bit too much') suggests significant emotional harm from being suspected.

police_conduct_quote: Detective poured soda down his throat for five hours and then escorted him to bathroom to view his genitals without proper arrest/probable cause. Judge ruled this was police misconduct and coercion.
quote_or_scene: Jackie: 'I wanted somebody to blame.' When asked why she picked Karl: 'Because you showed me his photo.' She admits 'Because he saw me outside the station. He hangs out at the deli out there.' Karl's lawyer Bernardo argues the police held him 5+ hours, coerced him by pouring soda and inspecting genitals. Judge rules inadmissible. Karl later confirmed as ex-boyfriend who had consensual relationship that ended a month prior.
notes: Karl was Jackie's consensual ex-boyfriend (statutory rape technically, as he was 18 and she was 14, but relationship was consensual per both parties and teacher). Jackie falsely identified him after being shown his photo by police. He was arrested based on this false ID. A judge later ruled the police conducted an illegal search/coercion. No evidence of public exposure beyond police interaction - his arrest and interrogation appear contained to law enforcement. Severity 3 due to arrest and legal process, but no clear public exposure to workplace/family/media.

quote_or_scene: STABLER: 'There's no easy way to say this. Rebecca's been sexually abused.' ... STABLER: 'In these kinds of cases, it's typically somebody who knew the victim.' ... 'I understand that you're her primary caregiver?' PETER: 'You're accusing me of hurting Rebecca?' STABLER: 'Sir, we're not accusing anyone.' PETER: 'Yes, you are. You think I raped my daughter.' ... STABLER: 'It's my job to rule everyone out. Now, you'd really help us out if you'd consent to a gonorrhea test.' PETER: 'You go to hell.'
tags: family_questioned; public_confrontation; wrong_ID; prior_false_allegation; father_accused; hospital_scene
notes: Peter was accused in front of his wife at the hospital while their daughter was dying. He had a prior false allegation from Missy 5 years earlier that was investigated and she recanted. CPS had cleared him then. This time, he refused STD testing (which came back negative for whole family anyway). Doctor independently tested him and he was clean, proving innocence. The real abuser was Missy herself.

person_label: Joey Field (Missy's boyfriend, video store clerk)
quote_or_scene: MISSY: 'He raped me and he raped Rebecca, and I couldn't stop him!' ... 'It was Joe, my boyfriend.' ... Later revealed: JOEY: 'Missy and Rebecca both had gonorrhea... [but] you tested negative.' ... 'She got it from somebody else, and then she gave it to her sister.' ... Video shows Missy forcing Joey to abuse unconscious Rebecca: MISSY: 'Can't we just leave her and go?' JOEY: 'No. She is knocked out. She won't feel it.' MISSY: 'No, it is not okay.' Joey is arrested: 'Joey Field, you're under arrest for the murders of John Marcum, Eric Campbell and Rebecca Kurtz.'
tags: fabricated_claim; arrested; remanded_no_bail; death_penalty_sought; coerced_by_girlfriend; public_arrest; media_potential; wrongly_accused_rape
notes: Joey was innocent of rape (he tested negative for gonorrhea while both Missy and Rebecca had it, proving Missy was the abuser). Missy falsely accused him to cover her own crimes. Joey was manipulated/coerced by Missy into helping orchestrate Rebecca's murder, but he did not rape either girl. He was arrested publicly outside his home in front of his father, remanded without bail, faced death penalty. His lawyer father had to defend him. Eventually the truth emerged through video evidence and medical tests. Joey did participate in murder conspiracy but was innocent of the sexual abuse he was accused of.

police_conduct_quote: Edmunds testifies: 'Cooper shot him, but the bastard wouldn't die, so we had to plant a drop gun. We testified Angel opened fire on us. Jury didn't even blink.'
quote_or_scene: Willie Angel to detectives: 'Cops like you with that same look in their eye... They wanted me to step from my business. And when I refused, next thing I know I got a bullet lodged in my spine, and I'm on trial for attempted murder.' Edmunds' confession corroborates: officers shot Willie, planted a drop gun, then testified falsely that Willie fired on them first.
tags: fabricated_claim; cop; charged_then_dropped; registered_then_cleared; ruined_physically; wrongful_conviction; physical_injury_permanent; perjured_testimony; evidence_planted
notes: Willie Angel is a drug dealer who was shot by Officers Cooper and Edmunds, then framed with a planted drop gun. Both officers testified falsely that Angel opened fire on them. Angel was convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to 25 years. The shooting left him paralyzed (wheelchair-bound). When Edmunds later confesses to multiple murders and the frame-up, Angel's conviction is overturned and he's released. This is a life-altering wrongful conviction case: innocent of the ACCUSED crime (attempted murder of police) even though he was a drug dealer. The accusation was fabricated by police, resulted in trial/conviction, 25-year sentence, and permanent paralysis. Severity 4: permanent physical injury plus wrongful imprisonment.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Bishop physically restrains Crowley, shoves him against desk. Bishop: 'The woman you raped and murdered.' Crowley: 'Wait a minute. You got the wrong guy!' Bishop: 'She found out about you, Ronnie, what a sick little worm you are. So you killed her!' Bishop had to be removed by Captain Cragen. Later Crowley says: 'I'll be better when I smack a lawsuit on that guy's ass. Did you see that?'
quote_or_scene: BISHOP: 'The woman you raped and murdered.' CROWLEY: 'Wait a minute. You got the wrong guy!' BISHOP: 'She found out about you, Ronnie, what a sick little worm you are. So you killed her!' CROWLEY: 'I did not!' [Bishop becomes physically aggressive] CRAGEN: 'Let's go, Bishop.' CROWLEY to ADA Williams: 'I'll be better when I smack a lawsuit on that guy's ass. Did you see that?' Later cleared: 'His prints don't match either scene.'
notes: Crowley was guilty of passport fraud (helping Mia Van Wagner travel illegally) but innocent of the rape/murder of Meredith McGrath and kidnapping Mia (she went willingly). He was violently confronted in front of his employee at his copy shop workplace. Detective Bishop physically assaulted him and accused him of rape and murder. Captain had to intervene. ADA Williams later confirms his innocence of the murders via fingerprint exclusion. Crowley threatens lawsuit for the treatment. This is clear public workplace exposure with physical coercion and false murder accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Czech officer to Tassig (in foreign language): 'I merely reminded Mr. Tassig that we were not in America. So perhaps he'll be more inclined to cooperate and stop this ridiculous performance.' Tassig becomes frightened. After translated threat, Stabler grabs Tassig: 'Come here... What did you say to me? Huh? What do I need? All right. This little girl. Who is she?'
quote_or_scene: Tassig arrested in Prague for child exploitation crimes. During interrogation about the murder: STABLER: 'You recorded yourself numerous times having sex with Mia Van Wagner' and shows photos of other girl. STABLER: 'Who is she?' [regarding Amy] TASSIG: 'I don't know her.' Czech officer speaks in foreign language, then explains: 'I merely reminded Mr. Tassig that we were not in America. So perhaps he'll be more inclined to cooperate.' TASSIG to Stabler: 'You need permission from this bitch?' [Stabler grabs him]. Later cleared when Nick2Shy's identity revealed as Nicholas Taylor.
notes: Tassig is guilty of child sex trafficking, child exploitation, and having sex with Mia Van Wagner (14). However, he is INNOCENT of murdering Meredith and Roger McGrath, which is what Stabler is investigating. Stabler and Czech officer interrogate him about Amy's photos, believing he may be Nick2Shy. Czech officer makes veiled threat about not being in America. Stabler physically intimidates Tassig. Later proven innocent of murders when Nicholas Taylor identified as Nick2Shy/actual killer. Exposure was police-only (no public component beyond arrest for his actual crimes), but arrest and coercive interrogation about murders he didn't commit qualifies as harm. Included because he was falsely accused of specific murders with physical coercion during interrogation.

police_conduct_quote: Husband's definitely got motive now. Not only was she cheating on him, she was using his money to wine and dine her lover.
quote_or_scene: Detectives aggressively question Preston about his wife's murder, suggesting he had motive due to alleged affair. Later cleared when partner Ryan Chambers explains the marriage was for immigration purposes only.
notes: Preston was the initial suspect based on husband-victim relationship and perceived lies about their marriage. He was innocent of murder but had entered a fraudulent marriage for immigration purposes. Kept private - no public exposure beyond police questioning.

police_conduct_quote: Preston know you were banging his wife? / You got a sense of humor. That's good. That'll serve you well in prison. / You were the last person who saw her alive. You're going to need to come with us.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Ryan's home where Preston is also present. They accuse Ryan of having an affair with Kunsong and being the last to see her alive. 'Preston know you were banging his wife?' 'You got a sense of humor. That's good. That'll serve you well in prison.' Threatened with arrest in front of his partner.
notes: Ryan was accused of having an affair with Kunsong and murdering her because he was the last to see her alive at dinner. He was publicly confronted and threatened with arrest in front of his business partner Preston. The accusation exposed his immigration fraud (fake marriage) to his partner. He was proven innocent when Jerry Dupree was identified as the actual killer.

police_conduct_quote: We've got a murdered girl. Our medical examiner places her time of death smack dab in the period she was scheduled to be in your apartment. / We also have a slew of very peculiar burglaries in your neighborhood. / My thieving whore of an ex robs me blind, and you accuse me of stealing?
quote_or_scene: Paulie is brought in for aggressive interrogation. Detectives tell him the victim died during the time she was scheduled to be at his apartment looking at a couch. They link him to shoe burglaries in his neighborhood. He consents to search of his apartment, which clears him.
notes: Paulie was suspected because Kunsong had his address (642 East Houston) in her notes, he lived near multiple shoe burglaries, and had a knife collection. However, she had actually written down 642 when the correct address was 462 - an inversion error. Full search of his apartment found no evidence. He was cleared when the real address led to Jerry Dupree. Questioning remained private.

quote_or_scene: Detectives question Marshall at the bowling alley about stolen boots. They ask his coworker about him: 'He annoy the customers as much as he annoys you?' Coworker confirms Marshall 'hits on every girl that walks through that door' and they ask if he takes things that don't belong to him. Marshall is questioned in front of coworker Jerry about the theft.
notes: Marshall was suspected because expensive boots were stolen from the bowling alley where he worked and where he had been hitting on the victim's date. Detectives questioned him at work in front of his coworker, asking about his history of harassment and theft. He was cleared when investigation moved to shoe burglaries near the bakery. Qualifies as severity 2 because he was accused of theft/harassment in front of coworkers.

police_conduct_quote: You cut 10 seconds off that security tape. How many more cover-ups you think this clown's got?
quote_or_scene: Drew's grandmother Mrs. Lamerly tells detectives in front of Tom: 'Tom Paysen, our security man. He was obsessed with Carmen. He wasn't here on Saturday night.' Detectives had been accusing Tom of cover-up and tampering when the Lamerlys deflect blame onto him for Carmen's murder.
notes: The Lamerlys falsely accuse their own employee Tom Paysen of murdering Carmen to deflect from Drew. Tom is confronted by detectives in presence of the Lamerlys. While Tom did cover up evidence (tape editing), he did not murder Carmen - Drew did. The false murder accusation is made publicly in front of his employers.

quote_or_scene: Detectives initially believe the dead woman is Anna Rivera based on maid uniform. Douglas Lamerly identifies body as Anna: 'I think it's Anna... Anna Rivera. She worked a month for us... we had to let her go.' Later proven the victim was Carmen Trancoso, not Anna.
notes: Anna was misidentified as the victim and briefly suspected of being involved in sex crimes/suicide. However, exposure was contained to police only with no public harm documented. Douglas Lamerly's false ID was part of the cover-up to protect Drew. Anna is later found alive in Miami. Included for contrast - this is borderline case with minimal harm (severity 1, police_only exposure).

police_conduct_quote: Detectives ask for DNA sample stating 'It's standard procedure' and Mr. Lathan says 'I know what you're thinking, but I'd never hurt Cherie. I worshipped her.'
quote_or_scene: STABLER: We're going to need a DNA sample, Mr. Lathan. It's standard procedure. / MR. LATHAN: I know what you're thinking, but I'd never hurt Cherie. I worshipped her. [Later:] That was Olivia. Nassau cops put out a missing kid alert about an hour ago... Olivia and Elliot are on their way to talk to the parents. / Cause of death? ... rape kit was positive for fluids... / The DNA on Cherie's father came back clean.
notes: Cherie's father was questioned as standard procedure and gave DNA sample. His DNA came back clean. No public exposure beyond the private interview. Severity 1 because it was private questioning only.

police_conduct_quote: MUNCH: 'Sure he can. Parental consent is all we need till you're 16.' KEVIN: 'This isn't fair. You fascists lay one finger on me, I will sue.' STABLER: 'Sit down, you little prick.'
quote_or_scene: Kevin and his father are brought to the precinct. MUNCH: Kevin's an enterprising young man. He posts his stories for the world to read on his own website... 'What I would do to take a bite out of Cherie.' ... Guidance counselor said he recently persuaded a sixth grader to pose in a bikini... CRAGEN: That must be Kevin and his dad. Talk to them. [In interrogation with father present] MUNCH: Where were you this morning, Kevin? School marked you absent. MR. ROUMEL: You were ditching? ... STABLER: You hurt her pretty bad in your little stories... 'She tried to escape, but I was too strong. I held her down and licked her tears away.' ... Cherie was raped and murdered. I don't want to hear about your damn stories. KEVIN: Look, I make stuff up, I don't do it. Then give us a DNA sample. KEVIN: No. You can't violate my civil liberties... MR. ROUMEL: He'll give you a sample. KEVIN: You can't force me. MUNCH: Sure he can. Parental consent is all we need till you're 16. KEVIN: This isn't fair. You fascists lay one finger on me, I will sue. STABLER: Sit down, you little prick. [DNA results] Sorry, no match. It's not Kevin.
notes: Kevin is accused in front of his father at the precinct. Detectives call him names ('little prick'), threaten him ('fascists'), reference his written stories about Cherie as evidence of guilt. Father learns of the accusation and suspicion during interrogation. DNA proves innocence. Severity 2 because accused publicly in front of father with degrading language but no formal sanction beyond the confrontation.

police_conduct_quote: BENSON: 'We hear they [kiddie beauty pageants] turn you on.' / STABLER: 'Put your johnson back in your pants, Canotti.'
quote_or_scene: BENSON: Rob Canotti? New York Police in Jersey City. CANOTTI: Has a child been attacked? BENSON: Why would you ask us that question? CANOTTI: Why else are you here? STABLER: To talk about kiddie beauty pageants. We hear they turn you on. CANOTTI: If I denied it, you'd call me a liar. BENSON: You ever see a little girl named Cherie Lathan compete? CANOTTI: Not that I recall, but it's hard to keep track of so many little lovelies. STABLER: Where were you last night? CANOTTI: At home watching Nickelodeon. Can anyone vouch for that? I live alone. BENSON: Well, then, I think you better come with us. [Cell phone rings] There's no point. BENSON [into phone]: Benson. WARNER: The guy you're looking for probably ejaculated in his victim. CANOTTI: What are you saying? The urges started to come back. So I had them cut off. STABLER: What? CANOTTI: My gonads, Detective. Take a look. STABLER: All right, all right. Put your johnson back in your pants, Canotti.
notes: Canotti is confronted at his home in Jersey City and brought in for questioning. Detectives make degrading comments about his sexual interests and past. He is physically examined (forced to expose himself to prove surgical castration). No formal arrest or public exposure beyond police interaction. Severity 2 because of the degrading treatment and forced exposure of body to prove innocence, even though contained to police.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'You hit Joe... You went back to the party to bring Cheryl home... You find her in the bathroom with your brother's hands all over her. Come on, Eddie, be a man. Don't let your girlfriend go down for something you did.' Eddie responds: 'Okay! I was in the room. I was there.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives theorize Eddie killed Joe based on: (1) Joe's dying words 'Get Eddie, he did it'; (2) Eddie fought with Joe at party; (3) Eddie has sprained ankle from jumping out bathroom window. Under coercive interrogation, Eddie admits being in bathroom but maintains he found Joe already on floor. Later, after learning Cheryl is trans, Eddie suffers emotional breakdown and dies from digoxin overdose (ruled suicide) while in police custody.
notes: Eddie was never formally arrested but was intensely interrogated as primary suspect in brother's death. Detectives used aggressive tactics to extract confession. Though exposure was 'police_only,' the consequence (suicide in custody) is severity 4. His death is directly linked to: (1) being falsely suspected of murder, (2) coercive interrogation extracting partial admission, and (3) learning girlfriend's secret during police questioning. IAB investigates the death as 'death in custody.'

quote_or_scene: Cheryl initially claims: 'He tried to rape me... He put his hands on my breasts. I tried to yell for help but the music was too loud. Then he ripped my shirt and he punched me in the face.' Later, in court testimony, Cheryl confesses true motive: 'He was gonna ruin it [her relationship with Eddie], and I couldn't let him do it. I had to stop him.' She admits killing Joe not because of ongoing attack but to prevent him from exposing her trans identity. Medical examiner confirms Joe died from 'blows to the head caused a subarachnoid hemorrhage.'
notes: Joe is accused of attempted rape by Cheryl Avery. Evidence shows Joe did physically assault Cheryl (her bruises are real, his knuckles cut), BUT Cheryl's rape claim is fabricated. She confesses in court she killed him to prevent exposure of her trans identity ('Joe was gonna ruin that... I had to stop him'). Joe's dying words were 'Get Eddie, he did it'—suggesting he was trying to identify Eddie as involved. The case centers on whether Joe's initial assault constituted attempted rape or was defensive reaction to discovering Cheryl's anatomy. Cheryl's confession reveals the rape claim was fabricated to justify the killing. Joe is dead as consequence of the false accusation. Party attendees, paramedics, and later media all heard/reported the rape accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives took him to bathroom after 'pouring soda down his throat for five hours' to observe genital piercing without warrant; held over 5 hours before arrest.
quote_or_scene: Jackie: 'I was coming home from school when this guy grabbed me.' Later identifies Karl from subway photo. Teacher Miss Bowen states she told Karl 'if he went near Jackie again, I'd cut his balls off.' Jackie later recants: 'Because you showed me his photo. I wanted somebody to blame... He saw me outside the station. He hangs out at the deli out there.' DNA excludes Karl: 'M.E. just called with a match on the second sperm sample. Karl Sirett's in the clear.'
tags: wrong_ID; witness_recant; teacher; arrested; ruined_at_work; public_confrontation; coerced_confession
notes: Karl was Jackie's ex-boyfriend (relationship when she was 14, he was 18). Teacher confronted him publicly about the relationship. Police conducted coercive interrogation including bathroom escort to view genital piercing without proper warrant. He was arrested for rape based on Jackie's identification and genital piercing match, then cleared by DNA. Jackie later admits she falsely identified him because detectives showed his photo and she 'wanted somebody to blame.' He was following her at subway because he happened to see her, not because he raped her.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler: 'Big guy like you have to tie up a defenseless girl.' Benson: 'A rapist and a murderer.' Detectives accuse him of being involved in murder of Chelsea Doe.
quote_or_scene: Randall rents room next to Jackie. Detective: 'Why would you let a 40-year-old man rent a room right next to your 15-year-old daughter?' DNA found inside Jackie matches Randall. Randall: 'I swear I never laid a hand on her... I didn't touch the girl!... He paid me to do it. He paid you to have sex with his wife? Yeah. He likes to watch.' Detectives: 'Your little tadpoles just swam in all by themselves... Jackie Landricks, she some kind of joint project you and big Charlie work on together?' Later revealed Tom Landricks used semen from Randall (who had consensual sex with Angie) to artificially inseminate Jackie.
notes: Randall lived in room next to Jackie and took medication (Mevastatin) that was found in rape kit. His DNA was found inside Jackie, leading to arrest and accusation of rape/murder. He voluntarily gave DNA sample, insisting innocence. Eventually revealed he had consensual paid sexual relationship with Jackie's mother Angie at Tom's direction, and Tom used the semen to inseminate Jackie via syringe. Randall never touched Jackie but was accused of being co-rapist with Charles Eno and potential involvement in Chelsea Doe murder.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler: 'Big guy like you have to tie up a defenseless girl.' Fin: 'Just like two years ago, in the meat-packing district, when you were chopping up those carcasses. You chop her up, too?' Eno: 'You're sick! What do you think I am?' Detectives: 'A rapist and a murderer.'
quote_or_scene: Eno lives a block from Landricks, worked as butcher 2 years ago near where Chelsea Doe was found. DNA match: 'M.E. got a DNA match on one of the samples. Charles Eno.' Detectives: 'We know you like attacking women. Did you go all the way with Jackie?' Eno: 'Where were you last night?' 'Home till 11:30. Then I went to the club. I work security... I didn't rape no girl... I didn't tie up no girl, man... I had sex with Angie Landricks, but I never touched the girl... Why would I mess with jailbait when I could get it from her moms?'
notes: Eno's DNA found inside Jackie led to arrest and accusation of rape and potential involvement in Chelsea Doe murder (he worked as butcher in meat-packing district). He had consensual paid sexual relationship with Angie Landricks at Tom's direction. Tom used semen from Eno's encounters with Angie to artificially inseminate Jackie. Eno never touched Jackie but was accused of being co-rapist with James Randall and potential murderer. Prior arrests for assault and robbery increased suspicion.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER showing photo to Stark: 'Is this how you like it, you little freak?' Stark responds: 'Get that out of my face! I've never seen that girl.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Stark at hotel in front of his wife Dora. Wife yells 'You cheating son of a bitch!' When detectives show victim photo and accuse him, Stark protests innocence. Wife references his history of cheating. He provides alibi (strip club all night, convention speech day before). DNA clears him (AB Negative doesn't match any of four rapists' DNA).
notes: Stark's rental Jaguar was used by the actual perpetrators (valet Mitch Wilkens stole keys). Stark was innocent of rape/murder but did admit to cheating on wife with sex workers. His alibi is confirmed by multiple witnesses. The public accusation in front of his wife caused marital humiliation even though he was cleared of the sex crime.

police_conduct_quote: I'm 30 seconds from shoving your face right through that wall... If she dies because you're holding out on us, I will personally stick that needle in your arm myself, you little prick.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Daniel at his workplace construction site in front of his boss Rose Granville and his fiancée Melinda: 'Daniel Lester, you're under arrest for the kidnapping of Annika Bergeron.' During interrogation, Stabler threatens: 'I'm 30 seconds from shoving your face right through that wall' and later 'If she dies because you're holding out on us, I will personally stick that needle in your arm myself, you little prick.' Daniel falsely confesses under pressure: 'Yeah. You're right. I did it. I'm so sorry.'
notes: Daniel is arrested publicly at his construction job in front of his employer (future mother-in-law) Rose Granville and his fiancée Melinda. He gives a false confession after sustained interrogation pressure and explicit threats of violence and death penalty from Detective Stabler. He confesses to protect Melinda, who actually orchestrated the kidnapping. He is later released when the truth emerges. The public workplace arrest and false confession under coercion caused significant harm to his reputation and relationship, though he ultimately maintains his relationship with Melinda (the actual perpetrator).

quote_or_scene: Police execute search warrant at Derek's home in front of his father Randy. Derek is arrested and taken to precinct. Father Randy says 'You don't have to say anything.' Detectives respond: 'That's right. Listen to your pops. You can spill your guts at the precinct.' Derek had his gun confiscated at school Friday; it was used in Saturday murders. School expelled him. Investigation shifts away after Joe's drawing and other evidence emerges.
notes: Derek is arrested in front of his father for the school shooting because his confiscated gun was used in the murders. He is later cleared when evidence points to Joe Blaine as the actual shooter. Severity 3: arrested and taken to precinct, publicly confronted at home.

police_conduct_quote: FIN: 'We know you went to the school today.' STABLER: 'You killed these kids, George.' FIN: 'Sure you did. With the gun you lifted from the security office.' STABLER: 'You stole the gun, killed Luke and Tyrell, dragged Joey into the boiler room, locked yourself in, then you tried to kill Joey.'
quote_or_scene: School security guard Hector tells detectives George is the janitor with a temper who 'went after [kids] with a mop' after Luke and Tyrell kicked his bucket over. Joe Blaine's drawing identifies George. Detectives interrogate George aggressively, accusing him of murder. George proves he couldn't have escaped through the window due to emphysema. Later confesses he gave Joe the gun 'just to scare the other kids' but 'had no idea it was loaded.'
notes: George is accused based on victim Joe's drawing and prior altercation with the murdered boys. He is interrogated with accusatory statements but proves physical impossibility of escape. While he admits giving Joe the gun, he is innocent of the murders themselves. His workplace role is exposed during investigation. Severity 2: workplace exposure and aggressive interrogation but no arrest shown.

person_label: Benny Edgar Ralsay (the Duct Tape Rapist)
police_conduct_quote: Fin: 'Planning your next rape, Benny?' Detective broadcasts: 'You don't have to broadcast it.' Detectives interrogate him at workplace in front of GPS monitor specialist.
quote_or_scene: Benny to detectives: 'I would never hurt the Doc. She's the reason why I'm out.' Later: 'Turns out he was fired yesterday after we left. The co-workers revolted when they found out who he was.' Lab confirms: 'Nothing matches Benny's tools or prints.'
notes: Benny was a civilly committed sex offender on electronic monitoring. Detectives publicly questioned him about the attack on Dr. Heints, exposing his identity. His employer fired him after the squad's visit when coworkers learned who he was. Forensics later cleared him completely. He was re-committed to state hospital for violating monitoring conditions (unrelated to the attack). Severity 3: Lost job due to public exposure from investigation.

quote_or_scene: Robert admitted to hospital Sunday 2:15 PM, left at 7:15 PM (5 hours). Attack occurred Sunday night. Nurse Lynch: 'Robert checked in voluntarily, so he was free to leave.' Sister Christina later reveals she attacked Dr. Heints. Courtroom scene shows Robert's complete mental breakdown while being accused: 'Just tell them you love me, please.' Judge deems him unfit to proceed. Christina confesses: 'I phoned her and told her I was a friend of Robert's and he was in trouble... I kicked her as hard as I could between her whoring legs.'
notes: Robert was aliased by hospital records proving he couldn't have committed the attack (admitted 2:15 PM, left 7:15 PM, attack was later that night). His sister Christina was the actual perpetrator. Robert was publicly accused, arrested, brought to court where he had a complete psychotic breakdown in front of judge/attorneys/public while being confronted with accusations. He attempted suicide. The public courtroom humiliation and suicide attempt while innocent of the specific attack constitute severity 4 harm. Note: Robert WAS a victim of Dr. Heints' inappropriate therapy, making this a complex case where he's innocent of the assault but involved in the broader controversy.

quote_or_scene: M.E.: 'Larry Tauber wasn't murdered. Suicide. He sustained one blow to the head from a sharp metal object... He must've jumped off of [scaffolding] and hit the dumpster.' Garrett sent him harassing email: 'You killed her, Larry. You kicked that poor woman to death. Cops are coming for you, Larry. You can run, Larry Tauber, but you can't hide.' Garrett paid programmer $1,000 to send this. Tauber commits suicide two hours after receiving it. Later proven Garrett and Louise were the actual killers; forensics show size 9 shoes kicked victim (Tauber wore size 11). Garrett manipulated Tauber throughout, then pushed him to suicide to silence potential witness.
notes: Tauber's car/apartment/computer were used by Garrett Perle and Louise Karnaki to commit the murder. All physical evidence initially pointed to Tauber. He was never formally arrested on-screen, but detectives clearly treated him as primary suspect ('your guy,' 'genius'). The exposure appears limited to police investigation, but the consequence—suicide directly caused by Garrett's psychological manipulation and fear of being wrongly convicted—is severity 4. His death was a direct result of being falsely implicated. Garrett testified he manipulated Tauber and sent the suicide-inducing email. Tauber is later proven innocent when shoe size and other evidence exonerate him.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Wolcott home with search warrant, confront him in front of wife Kelly. "You expect us to believe that you didn't tell your wife that she wasn't getting the baby? ... By killing her. ... This was my daughter. I didn't do this." Wife present throughout interrogation about murder accusation.
notes: Accused of murdering Brianna Morris and stealing baby. Squad obtains search warrant, questions him at home in front of wife about pharmaceuticals found. Later cleared by security camera alibi showing he was at work during murder timeframe. Wife witnessed entire accusation and search of their home.

police_conduct_quote: "You know what her biggest fear was before you? Starting the first grade. She told her mom that she was ready for big-girl clothes... You lured her into the dressing room." "It's not in a pedophile's nature. ... Yeah, you are." "We're gonna find your other victims and all of your cellmates are going to know exactly how many you raped."
quote_or_scene: Newlands arrested for 1998 child rape based on DNA match. Interrogated aggressively by Stabler and Benson who call him pedophile, describe rape of 6-year-old Molly in graphic detail, threaten prison violence. Later discovered he faked paternity test by implanting tube with another patient's blood - the actual rapist's blood. Newlands was innocent but murdered before this proven. Wife and children left him. "DNA doesn't lie. ... There must be some mistake."
tags: wrong_ID; db_error; arrested; charged_then_dropped; murdered; ruined_in_family; ruined_at_work; doctor; coerced_confession
notes: CRITICAL CASE: Newlands actually murdered Brianna Morris but was INNOCENT of child rapes. His DNA matched 1998 rape only because he surgically implanted tube containing real rapist's blood to beat paternity test in Morris murder. Suffered extreme consequences for crimes he didn't commit (the rapes): arrested, bail set then forfeited, wife/children left, medical practice destroyed, subjected to intense interrogation with threats and moral condemnation, murdered execution-style before trial. Police used graphic descriptions of child rape and threats of prison violence during interrogation. No apology given (he was murdered). ADA Novak went to his home and confronted his wife, contributing to family breakdown. Severity 4: murdered as direct consequence of false rape accusation.

police_conduct_quote: You did the lady, left your tag, even faced down a cop. Only thing we don't get is why a big, tough hombre like you had to knock her out before you tried to rape her. Sounds like performance anxiety to me.
quote_or_scene: FIN: You touched something. That look like orange paint? Let go of me. MUNCH: Uh-huh. I might've guessed. NYPD's very own civil rights busters. [...] The paint's a match. You're cooked, Leon. [...] Jennifer later testifies: 'It wasn't him. It was your husband, wasn't it?'
notes: Leon was confronted at the crime scene by Officer Breggin at gunpoint ('Drop the gun or I shoot'), arrested, interrogated with insults and accusations of rape/performance anxiety, and had his civil rights attorney mock the police conduct. Paint evidence matched but only proved trespass. Jennifer Fulton later recanted her identification, admitting her husband Craig was the actual attacker. Leon was prosecuted only for criminal trespass. No explicit apology shown. While exposure appears limited to police/legal system, the severity of being held at gunpoint, accused of rape with degrading comments, and arrested qualifies as severity 3.

police_conduct_quote: The badges mean we ask the questions.
quote_or_scene: Cragen and Stabler confront Dennis at his workplace drug store in front of customers/coworkers. His fingerprints were found on film carton from crime scene. He explains he works in photo finishing and handles hundreds of rolls daily. Detectives question him aggressively about processing photos from playground.
notes: Drug store employee whose fingerprints were on film carton because he processed customer photos as part of his job. Questioned publicly at workplace. Cleared when customer (PI Ronny Ickles) confirmed story.

police_conduct_quote: You cooperate or we collar you.
quote_or_scene: Ickles was taking photos at playground. Veronica Nash described him as suspicious. Detectives threaten to arrest him for operating without PI license. He explains he was hired by client David Jeffries to surveil his nanny. Client confirms story.
notes: Unlicensed PI taking photos at playground for legitimate surveillance job. Threatened with arrest but cleared when client confirmed. No public exposure beyond police interaction.

police_conduct_quote: When we get mad we lose control. We all have our breaking point. Are you saying I hurt Lucy?
quote_or_scene: Benson uses coercive interview tactics to suggest Sarah hurt Lucy. Sarah breaks down crying, admits to stealing small amounts of money from employer. Evelyn (employer/Lucy's mother) is told Sarah is suspected. Sarah passes polygraph and is cleared. Museum staff later identifies Veronica Nash, not Sarah, as the one who hit Lucy.
notes: Young nanny accused of shaking baby Lucy. Subjected to coercive interrogation. Employer informed of suspicion. Cleared by polygraph. Profile fit (young, overwhelmed, long hours with difficult child) led to focus on her despite her innocence.

police_conduct_quote: You shook that baby. And then you got your rocks off with her mother while her baby lay dying a few feet away!
quote_or_scene: Stabler aggressively interrogates Drew, describing scenario where Drew shook Lucy to stop her crying during affair with Evelyn. Drew admits Lucy vomited on him but denies shaking her. Stabler uses insults and moral condemnation. Drew worries his wife will find out about affair and divorce him. Medical evidence (hand size doesn't match rib fractures) clears him.
notes: Evelyn's married boss/lover. Was alone with Lucy for 20 minutes when she vomited on him. Medical evidence (hand size analysis of rib fractures) ruled him out. Feared exposure of affair to wife. Subjected to aggressive, degrading interrogation tactics.

consequence_detail: arrested, convicted, imprisoned_10_years, shot_by_police, separated_from_son, public_stigma
quote_or_scene: Baxter: 'I never touched him. I swear I never touched him.' Later proven innocent by DNA retesting showing Jeremy (cousin) was the actual rapist. Lee: 'I panicked. I didn't think she would call the police. I was scared.' Warner: 'They're different, but they have the same Y-chromosome. Lee and his rapist are related.'
tags: wrong_ID; fabricated_claim; imprisoned_wrongfully; physical_harm; legal_conviction; separated_from_child; dna_exoneration
notes: Baxter spent 10 years in prison after Lee falsely identified him as his rapist. Lee was actually raped by his cousin Jeremy but blamed Baxter because he feared losing his mother's attention when she became pregnant with Baxter's child. Baxter escaped prison to prove his innocence. He was shot by police during hostage situation. DNA retesting proved his innocence. He was separated from his son Danny for 10 years, who was told his father was dead. Mother had to believe he was guilty and helped him escape only because she was dying. Severity 4: life-altering—10 years wrongful imprisonment, shot by police, completely separated from his child, relationship destroyed.

police_conduct_quote: Come on, she knew the camera was there. She knew what she was doing. [Vernon gets upset] Hey, hey, hey. Take it easy, Vern. Let's take a little ride down to the precinct. Medical Examiner got some evidence she wants to talk to you about. What evidence, huh?
quote_or_scene: Vernon arrested after busting into Tyler's fraternity and taking a swing at him. Detectives bring him to precinct saying 'Medical Examiner got some evidence.' He has alibi: 'I was making deliveries till midnight.'
notes: Vernon has criminal history (assault/battery, 3 years at Sing Sing). Suspected because he assaulted Tyler previously and worked near treatment plant. Cleared by alibi (making deliveries). Exposure appears limited to police interrogation - no evidence of public workplace/family exposure, so severity remains low despite coercive interrogation tactics.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives confront him at his workplace (newspaper office) in front of employees, accuse him of beating/murdering his wife: 'We figure you left your grandson at the office and went out with your son to start a fire.' 'The guy was careless. Maybe he left somethin' else behind.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives visit 'The Arab American' newspaper office where Elbisi works with his mother. They confront him publicly about his wife's murder. Benson: 'Mr. Elbisi, we're very sorry. Your wife was murdered last night.' Stabler: 'She was burned to death.' Later interrogation implies he killed her: 'We figure you left your grandson at the office and went out with your son to start a fire.' Elbisi responds: 'We're not barbarians. We're faithful Muslims.' The detectives accuse him based on marital problems, domestic violence reports, and wife's affair with Jewish man Joshua Feldman.
notes: Elbisi was suspected because: (1) prior 911 calls about domestic violence, (2) wife having affair with Jewish man, (3) oil traces in car trunk, (4) inconsistent alibi with mother. He was publicly confronted at his workplace. Later cleared when real killer (Sean Webster) was identified. Detectives showed no apology. The exposure occurred at his newspaper office in front of employees. Severity=2 because publicly accused at workplace but no arrest/formal charge shown on screen.

police_conduct_quote: Munch: 'Every word out of her mouth was a lie, except maybe good morning.' Detectives accuse her of lying about alibi: 'Your stories don't match. Which probably means you're not telling the truth.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives interrogate Jazlyn about her whereabouts the night of the murder. Her alibi conflicts with her son's. Munch: 'Your son told two detectives that you left at 10:00 p.m.' Jazlyn: '10:00, midnight. It was a long day. What's the difference?' Munch: 'The difference is your stories don't match. Which probably means you're not telling the truth.' She's accused of complicity in daughter-in-law's murder.
notes: Jazlyn was suspected as potential accomplice to her son in the murder. Interrogated about inconsistent alibi. Cleared when real killer identified. No public exposure shown—contained to police interview. Included because detectives explicitly accused her of lying and potential involvement, but severity=1 since exposure was police-only with no material consequence beyond the interrogation itself.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives break into his apartment during consensual sex with Lisa, accuse him: 'You're screwing one student. You were screwing Shannon, too. You workin' your way through the 11th grade, Steve?' and 'Maybe Shannon finds out you're doin' her best friend. She tells anybody, your career's history. So I murder her? ... your career's over anyway, choir boy.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives burst into Abruzzo's apartment during sex with student Lisa Faber, confront him in front of Lisa: 'You're screwing one student. You were screwing Shannon, too.' Later at interrogation: 'Maybe Shannon finds out you're doin' her best friend. She tells anybody, your career's history. So I murder her?' Abruzzo: 'Are you insane?' Lisa provides alibi proving he was with her during Shannon's murder.
notes: Abruzzo had a prior complaint at his last school (Garfield High) where a student accused him of inappropriate conduct, costing him tenure. He denies it was legitimate ('She's a liar... I gave her a D. This is what I get for tryin' to do my job'). In this episode, detectives find his fingerprint on a condom wrapper from Shannon's purse and burst into his apartment during consensual sex with 16-year-old student Lisa Faber. They publicly accuse him of statutory rape and murdering Shannon. Lisa provides alibi proving he was with Steve all night. The breaking-in scene and accusations occur in front of Lisa. Career is described as 'over anyway' by detectives. He is later cleared when Lisa's alibi is confirmed. Severity 3: career damage, arrest threat, public humiliation in front of student, degrading interrogation tactics.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler to Brian during interrogation: 'You accidentally see Shannon comin' out of the shower. Undressing in her room... She looks good, like all the girls at school. You couldn't help...' Brian: 'Stop! I never touched Shannon! ... That's disgusting.'
quote_or_scene: Warner tells mother Susan that DNA proves 'the baby's father was related to Shannon.' Detectives ask about uncles/cousins, then say 'Do you remember Shannon spending any time with, uh, uncles or cousins about two months ago?' When she says no relatives exist, they turn to Brian. Mother attacks Brian physically, screaming 'Brian, did you get Shannon pregnant? Tell me what you did!' and 'Did you get her pregnant? You tell me!' while trying to hit him. Detectives pull her off: 'Mrs. Coyle, calm down.' They take Brian for DNA testing. During interrogation, Stabler uses graphic sexual imagery about Shannon to pressure Brian, who repeatedly denies and calls it 'disgusting.' DNA later proves Jason Connor (not Brian) is the father.
tags: family_member; public_confrontation; ruined_in_family; coerced_confession; assaulted; teen
notes: Brian is Shannon's 16-year-old brother. When DNA reveals incest, detectives inform the mother in Brian's presence. She immediately physically attacks him, screaming accusations in front of detectives. He is taken to ME for DNA testing and subjected to degrading interrogation where Stabler uses sexually explicit hypotheticals about his sister. DNA proves Brian is NOT the father—Jason Connor is. Mother later admits 'I knew Brian didn't hurt Shannon. I was just trying to protect Jason.' Brian suffers violent assault by mother, public family humiliation, and coercive interrogation. No apology shown. Severity 3: physical assault by mother, family destruction, graphic sexual interrogation as minor, arrested/detained for DNA testing.

quote_or_scene: Detectives tell Aidan's parents: 'We know that you two had sex the night she was murdered.' Mother asks 'What in God's name did you do?' Father says they should call a lawyer. Aidan provides alibi (doorman confirms he was home all night). Later, after father's murder, Stabler tells Aidan privately: 'Your father was also Shannon's father... Shannon was pregnant, and we tested the fetus's genes.' Aidan: 'Shannon's not my sister.' Stabler: 'Our DNA tests prove she is... This is not your fault. None of this is your fault.' Aidan: 'I had sex with my sister?' [Vomits, screams, sobs]. Later falsely confesses to murdering his father to punish himself. Stabler tells him: 'You didn't cause any of this. You, Shannon, Brian, every one of you were just born into this mess.'
tags: teen; family_member; ruined_in_family; psychological_trauma; suicide_attempt; wrong_ID
notes: Aidan, 16, is accused of murdering Shannon when detectives learn they had sex the night she died. Parents are told in his presence. He provides alibi (home all night, confirmed by doorman). DNA test clears him. Later accused of murdering his father Jason Connor. Again provides false confession to protect himself/punish himself after learning of incest. Mother Debra ultimately confesses to the murder. Aidan suffers catastrophic psychological harm: learns his girlfriend was his half-sister, that he committed unknowing incest, that she was pregnant with his child, her death, his father's murder, his mother's arrest. He wishes he had 'used my father's gun on myself' (suicide ideation). Stabler offers partial apology/assurance ('not your fault') but initiated the traumatic revelation. Severity 4: life-altering trauma, suicide ideation, complete family destruction, learns of incest in graphic detail from police.

police_conduct_quote: Benson during interrogation after Susan is arrested fleeing to Canada: 'Are you gonna put on another performance like you did when you slapped your son around?' (implying she's lying/manipulative).
quote_or_scene: Susan and Brian are stopped by state police fleeing to Canada. Brought back to NYC. Benson arrests her: 'You're under arrest for murder.' Susan: 'You think I killed my own daughter?' Benson: 'Not Shannon. Her father, Jason Connor.' Susan: 'Jason's dead? I didn't kill Jason.' Benson: 'He was shot with your gun, Susan.' Susan explains Jason told her it was an accident, that he asked her to flee to Cuba. Detectives accuse her of murder. Evidence (stolen diamonds, gun registration, motive) points to her. She is held/interrogated. Later Debra Connor confesses to the murder, clearing Susan.
notes: Susan is arrested for murdering Jason Connor based on: (1) gun registered in her name, (2) she stole $2M in diamonds from Debra Connor's vault using forged ID, (3) she was fleeing to Canada with plane tickets Jason gave her to Cuba. She is interrogated, accused of performance/lying about protecting her son. Debra Connor later confesses to the murder, proving Susan innocent of murder (though guilty of diamond theft and complicity in covering up Shannon's death). Severity 3: arrested, publicly accused of murder, interrogated with degrading tactics, held in custody until real killer confesses. Exposure limited to legal system (no media/workplace shown), but arrest and flight constitute significant harm.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive on set while Lukas is filming commercial, interrupt shoot: 'We need to talk to the grapes.' 'Police. Come on down. We need you to answer a few questions.' Director says 'Copy that. Lukas, visitors.' Confronted in front of crew about 'underage girlfriend.' He provides alibi: 'I was on a movie set last night... there till 4:00 in the morning.'
notes: 23-year-old actor dating 16-year-old Emily (statutory rape). Detectives confront him on set in front of director and crew. Alibi confirmed immediately. Clear workplace exposure but no arrest or formal sanction.

quote_or_scene: Principal Kilgore tells detectives: 'Agnes Linsky may be delayed academically and socially, but she couldn't kill anyone.' Detectives pull Agnes from class at school. She tells them: 'I know you don't believe me. Nobody does.' and 'I know it sounds awful, but I'm happy. I'm happy she's dead.' She says she was 'home alone' the night of murder. Brother Troy later attacks Brittany, saying 'Nobody's protecting my sister, okay? Not the school and not the cops.'
notes: 18-year-old victim of years of bullying by Emily. Father tried to get restraining order against Emily (denied). Detectives pull her from class for questioning in front of school officials. Home alone with no alibi. Squad strongly suspects her initially but she is never arrested. Show pivots away when evidence points to Emily's friends as killers. School exposure = severity 2.

quote_or_scene: Detectives go to Linsky home night after murder. Mr. Linsky opens door and immediately says: 'You guys know damn well that bitch is not my daughter's friend. Go bother her parents. They deserve it.' When told Emily was murdered: 'She made my daughter's life miserable. And God help me, I'm not sorry she's dead.' Detectives later verify: 'Pat Linsky was bartending from 8:00 until 4:00 the night of Emily's murder' (alibi confirmed).
notes: Father of Agnes, initially suspected due to his anger about Emily's treatment of his daughter. Confronted at home in front of son Troy. Alibi confirmed at bar. Family exposure (son present) = severity 2.

consequence_detail: arrested, wife present during confession, charged_then_dropped, public_accusation_in_front_of_wife
police_conduct_quote: FIN: 'Come on, Sam. The kid was running wild. You were at the end of your rope. You put that pillow over his face, you held it there till he stopped movin'.' FIN: 'No, you killed him. Then you took him to the church to cover it up.' FIN: 'Let it out, Sam. You'll feel better.'
quote_or_scene: SAM: 'I just wanted him to sleep. Just be still for a while. But then he stopped moving.' ... Later: SAM: 'No! I could never have hurt Jamie. I wanted him to be our son! You killed him.' ... SAM: 'I loved you, Lori-Ann. I believed your lies. I let you hurt those kids.'
notes: Sam confessed under police pressure to protect his wife Lori-Ann, who was the actual killer. He was interrogated in front of his wife who witnessed his false confession. The detectives used classic coercive tactics including accusations, pressure to confess for relief, and manipulation. Sam later recanted and told the truth when confronted with his wife.

police_conduct_quote: FIN: 'You held him so tight the ring left an impression on his flesh.' MUNCH: 'You crushed the life out of him.' FIN: 'You killed him.'
quote_or_scene: HENDRY: 'God forgive me. I was only trying to help the boy. I... I must have held him too tight. I... I saw the mark my ring had made. I took it off. I'm so sorry.' ... CRAGEN: 'About to take him to booking.' CRAGEN: 'Put him in the cage. I think you better talk to Warner first.' [Then Warner reveals Jamie was already dead before the church prayer session]
notes: Father Hendry was accused of crushing Jamie to death during a prayer session based on a ring mark on the body. He was arrested and about to be booked when ME Warner revealed Jamie was already dead before arriving at church. The ring impression was made post-mortem. Hendry had no idea Jamie was dead when he prayed over him; Sam Dufoy lied to him.

consequence_detail: arrested, fired, pension_loss, media_crucifixion, threatening_calls, suicide
quote_or_scene: MARIEL: 'I lost my job, my pension. I've been crucified by the press, I get threatening phone calls.' ... MARIEL: 'I've saved thousands of children, and I'll only be remembered for one.' [Shoots herself]
notes: Mariel was charged with reckless endangerment in Jamie's death and record tampering. Found NOT GUILTY of endangerment, guilty only of record tampering. However, she suffered devastating public consequences: job loss, pension loss, media attacks, threatening calls. She committed suicide after detectives confronted her about another missing girl. She was negligent but not criminally responsible for endangerment per jury verdict. Included because she faced public exposure and severe harm despite partial exoneration on main charge.

quote_or_scene: Scene shows reporters mobbing Tripley: 'Did you do it, Billy? How many kids have you molested?' Attorney: 'There is no truth in these outrageous allegations. Scurrilous lies, plain and simple.' Later: Warner discovers April never had leukemia (mercury poisoning instead), and April's grandmother Nora was poisoning her. Final line suggests April's molestation claim was also fabricated: 'Has she lied about other things that you know about?' regarding the molestation story.
notes: Complex case: JJ's original accusation appears credible (specific birthmark detail, $4M settlement suggesting prior incident), but JJ recants under apparent parental coercion to protect settlement. April's accusation is strongly implied to be fabricated by grandmother Nora, who was revealed to be poisoning April and lying about leukemia. Billy Tripley suffered arrest, perp walk, massive media exposure based primarily on April's fabricated claim (the 'new' victim that strengthened the case after JJ disappeared). The episode's final revelation that Nora fabricated the leukemia and likely the molestation claim suggests Tripley was falsely accused regarding April. Included here as the April accusation (which drove the arrest and media exposure) appears fabricated, even though JJ's earlier claim remains ambiguous. Warner's discovery and April's final line ('Has she lied about other things?') strongly imply the molestation claim was also a lie.

quote_or_scene: Detectives chase Keisha on the street, confront her publicly. 'Your prints were on the door. And on the john.' Keisha: 'I touched the car, but I didn't kill him. As a matter of fact, he was already dead.' Later DNA proves she wasn't involved: 'Keisha Brown's DNA didn't match the sample in the condom.'
notes: Fingerprints placed Keisha at the scene, leading to public street confrontation and questioning. DNA evidence later exonerated her completely. However, there's no indication of consequences beyond the initial confrontation - no arrest, no workplace/family exposure, no sustained harm. Borderline case for inclusion, but exposure was limited to police interaction on the street with no evidence of broader impact. Severity 1 reflects brief detention/questioning only.

consequence_detail: arrested, perp_walk, publicly_tried, convicted, imprisoned, career_destroyed, relapsed_to_heroin, $12M_lawsuit_filed
police_conduct_quote: Captain Cragen to Vega during interrogation: 'I remember you, Vega. When I collared you after we found that poor woman's stinking corpse, you cried like a baby. You denied it then, but we had your prints all over that oil drum. You lied then like you're lying now.'
quote_or_scene: Judge: 'You're free to go with the court's apologies.' Captain later says 'I'm sorry. I'll talk to the ADA. Get you out of here right away.' Vega responds: 'A mistake? That's the best you can say? ... Can you bring Rebecca back to life? Can you give me back my career? Get out of my face.'
tags: ruined_at_work; ruined_physically; perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation; wrong_ID; teacher; suicide_attempt; fabricated_claim
notes: Vega was framed using physical evidence (condoms, fibers, rental car GPS) by student Kyle Luhrmann. His past murder conviction (served 30 years prior) made him an easy target. Despite being a reformed ex-con who had been clean for 16 years, built a career as professor, and was trying to help society, he was publicly arrested at Rebecca's grave, tried, convicted, and imprisoned. While incarcerated awaiting release after being cleared, he relapsed into heroin use. His daughter Gabrielle notes the entire ordeal destroyed his life and career. This is a severe case of life-altering harm (severity 4) due to false accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Rudy during interrogation: 'Just got out of prison, your wife's got a new man. So you figured you'll take what you need from Rebecca... She resists, you choke her. Maybe you didn't mean to kill her, the next thing you know, she's not moving... You're scared. You panic.' Then: 'Write, Rudy. Just write. Maybe you'll see the world again before you die.'
quote_or_scene: Sister Peg: 'When you interrogated him, you pushed him over the edge. He didn't deserve that... You've been telling every drug dealer in town you're looking for him. They think he's a rat... He came to me for help. He's afraid he's gonna get killed.' Rudy was publicly arrested at homeless shelter, coerced into false confession, then went into hiding fearing street retaliation.
tags: ruined_physically; ruined_in_family; coerced_confession; public_confrontation; witness_recant; online_rumor
notes: Rudy, a recently paroled recovering addict, was Rebecca's research subject. Sushi delivery driver placed him at her apartment the night of the murder. Detectives publicly arrested him at St. Anne's homeless shelter, then used coercive interrogation tactics to extract a false confession. After his release, police spread word on the street they were looking for him, causing dealers/addicts to think he was an informant. Sister Peg reports he was 'terrified' and 'afraid he's gonna get killed,' forcing him into hiding. Material harm through arrest, coercion, and creating dangerous street conditions (severity 3).

police_conduct_quote: Stabler: 'You tried to kill Christina so your wife wouldn't find out you were banging her.' Benson: 'We found your handcuffs, Brooks.' Stabler: 'Toilet seat was up, you do that? ... You sprinkle when you tinkle. Our medical examiner tested the urine you left behind. You're dying of kidney failure.'
quote_or_scene: Cragen: 'Mr. Harmon, I'm Capt. Cragen. There's been a misunderstanding. You're free to go.' Harmon: 'With our apologies.' Brooks: 'You people are nuts.'
notes: Brooks Harmon was Christina's boss and affair partner. After Christina reported being raped, detectives focused on Brooks as the last person seen with her and found him on surveillance entering/leaving her building during the attack timeframe. Detectives accused him of rape and attempted murder, using coercive interrogation tactics including falsely claiming medical evidence tied him to the scene ('the urine you left behind... You're dying of kidney failure'). He was cleared when ME determined the urine belonged to a woman, not Brooks. Captain offered only partial apology ('misunderstanding'). Harm was primarily the intense interrogation with threats and false accusations, though contained to police setting. Severity 2 because while no public exposure occurred, he was subjected to aggressive, accusatory interrogation with false evidence claims.

police_conduct_quote: STABLER: 'The bitch is dead, Gary.' BENSON: 'Why didn't you like her? Everyone else did.' STABLER: 'Everyone else didn't work for her.' STABLER: 'Fair trade?' (re: stealing Rolex). STABLER: 'So DeVaal is lying.' Later cleared when forensics prove signature forgery.
quote_or_scene: DeVaal: 'I hated her, but I didn't kill her.' Benson: 'The bitch is dead, Gary.' DeVaal: 'I never got a chance to return them [keys].' Stabler: 'I guess you didn't have a chance to return her dead husband's watch either, huh?' DeVaal about Claudia Wooding: 'I've never seen her before in my life.' Stabler: 'RDH says you were her nurse.' DeVaal: 'RDH is lying. Someone's setting me up. Check the files.' Forensic examiner later confirms: 'They're identical... transposition forgery. Someone Xeroxed DeVaal's signature and cut and pasted it onto files.' Stabler: 'So DeVaal was right. He is being set up.'
notes: Gary DeVaal was fired from RDH for stealing from Donna Brooks. When she and other patients are murdered, squad finds his signature on nursing logs for all victims including Claudia Wooding (whom he claims never to have treated). He's brought in for interrogation, treated hostilely ('the bitch is dead'), accused of murder.
