Forensic document examiner proves his signatures were forged via Xerox cut-and-paste method, clearing him. Emma Spevak forged the logs to frame him. While he did steal (admitted theft of Rolex), he's innocent of the murders. Primary harm: arrest and hostile interrogation. No evidence of public exposure beyond police custody, but the accusation and arrest constitute material legal consequence (severity 3).

quote_or_scene: Benson arrests Spevak in front of client: 'Matt Spevak, you're under arrest for murder in the First Degree.' Spevak: 'This is insane. What the hell did you tell them, Emma?' Later, Benson to Emma: 'We've made a terrible mistake. We searched Matt's apartment and found his rock-climbing equipment. His rope matches the strangulation mark on those poor women's necks... We are so sorry.' Spevak was actually murdered by his sister Emma, who framed him.
tags: arrested; public_confrontation; perp_walk; murdered; ruined_at_work; fabricated_claim
notes: Dr. Matt Spevak arrested for three murders in front of workplace client and staff. Held on $500K bail. Actually murdered by his twin sister Emma, who staged scene to frame him posthumously. Emma strangled elderly women with Matt's climbing rope, forged nursing logs, embezzled from his charity foundation, then killed him and staged it as if he died attacking final victim. Detectives later apologize to Emma for blaming Matt ('terrible mistake... so sorry'). Matt's innocence proven when investigators realize Emma committed all murders including their mother. Severity 4: murdered by actual killer while being framed. Public exposure at workplace during arrest. Partial apology given to sister posthumously.

quote_or_scene: Hospital lab found what they thought was ethylene glycol using gas chromatography. But MMA produces a substance that older tests mistook for ethylene glycol. Baby had MMA genetic disease. Hospital treatment with ethanol drip (right for antifreeze, wrong for MMA) caused crystals and killed the baby. Silvo arrested at hospital while her baby died during mug shots. Served 10 years in prison. Daughter Diana in foster care.
tags: tech_db_error; arrested; imprisoned_10_years; custody_loss; media_outing; ruined_in_family; CSA
notes: Medical misdiagnosis led to wrongful murder conviction. Baby Christine died of methylmalonic acidemia (MMA), a genetic disease. Hospital lab test误identified MMA byproduct as ethylene glycol (antifreeze). Hospital's ethanol treatment for antifreeze poisoning actually killed the baby. Silvo spent 10 years in prison, lost custody of second daughter Diana. Judge Taft denied defense expert testimony about genetic disease theory. Conviction later vacated when DNA testing proved MMA diagnosis. Severity 4: life-altering imprisonment, permanent family separation.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at McMaster, Kennedy & Barringer (58 Wall Street) and ask receptionist for Howard Kendall. When he appears, Stabler says 'Police. Why don't we talk in your office, Howie?' They question him about Jiao Wu in front of workplace colleagues. Kendall has DV assault record but is cleared when he explains the relationship ended, Jiao called him after their confrontation, and he still has her purse she never retrieved. Detectives take the purse as evidence and leave.
notes: Kendall is questioned publicly at his Wall Street workplace about a missing woman and potential assault. He has a criminal record (DV assault, DWI, resisting arrest) which makes him an initial suspect. Detectives confront him in his workplace where colleagues can see/hear. He is cleared when he provides alibi evidence (subsequent phone call from Jiao, possession of her purse). Though he works as a mail clerk (not executive), being publicly questioned by police at a Wall Street firm carries professional stigma. No evidence of formal job consequences, but public exposure to colleagues qualifies as severity 2.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Franco: 'You're pimping out a 16-year-old to jack up your ratings.' Also: 'You got her stripping for money.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Franco in his office with Jessie present on the couch. He is arrested: 'No way! I didn't do it!' Detective: 'Well, DNA puts you at the scene.' Franco is questioned aggressively about making Jessie 'run around half-naked every week' and 'pimping out a 16-year-old.'
notes: Franco faked his DNA test because he was illegally married to 16-year-old Jessie (he's 40). While his marriage is problematic, he is innocent of the rape. DNA evidence that initially implicated him was fraudulent (he paid someone else to submit DNA). He is publicly accused and arrested in front of his star actress and crew. The investigation reveals his inappropriate marriage but clears him of rape. Detectives use degrading language about his relationship with Jessie and his show's content during interrogation.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at 'Kilmore Time Sales & Repair' and publicly question him: 'You're the only one in this time zone. So tell us, Rupert, why would a rapist use your full name?' His employee is present and a phone call comes in asking 'are the cops there?' The real killer is using Kilmore's name as part of his game. Kilmore says 'I swear, I don't know anything.' The detectives quickly realize he's being framed when they get the fax clue.
notes: Humphrey Becker (the real killer) deliberately used Rupert Kilmore's full name in his poem to mislead police as part of his scavenger hunt game. Detectives confronted Kilmore at his business in front of his employee and customers. While we don't see explicit job consequences, the public nature of the accusation of being a rapist at his workplace qualifies as severity 2 exposure. The killer even called the shop to confirm police were there, showing this was orchestrated public exposure. No apology is shown to Kilmore after he's cleared.

quote_or_scene: Girlfriend: 'We were walking along the street, when these bastards started calling Joe a rapist. And they chased him into the street, and straight into a car.' Hospital says Joseph Eglee is still unconscious. Detective: 'He's gonna make it?' Response: 'He's stable.'
tags: media_outing; perp_walk; ruined_physically; vigilante_attack; wrong_ID; cadet
notes: Named in newspaper as suspect ('Student rape: cadets questioned. Byline's Jamie Barrigan'). Public mob chased him into traffic, resulting in head injury and coma. Tandi later recants entire rape claim, clearing all cadets. Life-altering physical harm from mob violence triggered by media exposure of his name as suspect.

quote_or_scene: Tandi shown photos: 'Him. He's one of the cadets.' Second page: 'Him.' Detective: 'Are you sure?' Tandi: 'They raped me.' Later videotape authenticator: 'That's Luke Delvecchio. I interviewed him. Real bottom feeder.' Tandi later recants on TV.
notes: Named in newspaper along with other cadets. Publicly identified by Tandi as one of her rapists from photo array. Tandi later recants entire story on national TV, clearing him. Media exposure as accused rapist, though no indication of physical violence like Eglee.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Tony Storr on city sidewalk, asking about Tandi. Reporter Jamie: 'What is this? Student rape: cadets questioned.' Chief to Stabler: 'A high-profile case with the media on it like the measles, and you go and name our main suspects.'
notes: Named in newspaper as one of questioned cadets. Confirmed Tandi was at party but denied involvement. Tandi later recants entire rape claim. Media exposure as suspect despite no evidence of personal wrongdoing beyond hosting party where minor drank.

quote_or_scene: Detective questions Joe Delvecchio about Tandi at party. Lawyer Trevor Langan intervenes: 'You have no right to question my client on university property.' Later newspaper names cadets questioned. Tandi recants on TV.
notes: Named in newspaper as questioned cadet. Questioned by police about Tandi at party. Tandi later recants entire rape story. Media exposure as suspect though he had girlfriend and denied involvement.

police_conduct_quote: Elliot: 'The night she didn't come home, you went looking for her. But you didn't tell us that you found her. Now, you saw her coming out of that party. You wanted to be mad, but she was drunk. Maybe she was flirting with you a little bit.' Ron: 'Shut up.' Munch: 'So you brought her to the dorm and did what you always wanted to do.' Ron: 'You bastard.' Fin: 'Oh, come on, man. She is a peach. You're only her stepfather. What's the big deal, huh?'
quote_or_scene: Benson: 'Because your handprints say that you were [in the room where Tandi was raped]. On the sheet rock right next to where Tandi was found.' Ron: 'We supply sheet rock. It must have ended up in that building.' Stabler: 'That's quite a coincidence, Ron.' Later Tandi reveals: 'He never touched me.' Real perpetrator was her boss Mike Tucker who threatened Ron's job/insurance.
notes: Detectives find his handprints at crime scene, interrogate him aggressively with sexual taunts about his stepdaughter. He punches detective and is arrested for assault. Had prior false abuse allegation in 1995 (withdrawn by 7-year-old Tandi, orchestrated by biological father). Cleared when Tandi reveals real perpetrator was her employer Mike Tucker. Interrogation tactics included repeated sexual provocations designed to trigger violent reaction.

police_conduct_quote: You son of a bitch, we better find him alive. / I'm gonna hurt you, son of a bitch. (said by Wolinsky but in police presence)
quote_or_scene: Wolinsky organizes public protest outside Billy's apartment with bullhorn: 'Do we want a pervert in this neighborhood? We want him out.' Crowd chants 'We want the perv gone.' Fin: 'Crime Lab says cat hairs from Billy's apartment don't match the ones on Henry Morton. We gotta let Billy go.'
tags: wrong_ID; public_confrontation; online_rumor; ruined_in_family; arrested; interrogation_coercion; reputation_damage
notes: Billy is a registered sex offender on parole who was actually innocent of THIS crime. Police conducted coercive interrogation ('You son of a bitch'). Vigilante Wolinsky broke into apartment, trashed it looking for the child, then organized PUBLIC PROTEST with bullhorn outside Billy's residence while he was in custody, calling him 'pervert' and 'baby raper' in front of neighbors. Billy proven innocent via airtight alibi (babysitting neighbor's child during kidnapping window, confirmed by mother and child). Cat hair evidence excluded him. Severity 3: arrested, held, publicly exposed to entire neighborhood via protest, apartment searched/trashed.

quote_or_scene: Dean called him in this morning and fired him... The college told me to vacate faculty housing... I have lost my job. I lost my home. I've lost everything... My daughter has had to change schools. My wife is suing for sole custody.
tags: teacher; fired; evicted; media_outing; custody_dispute; public_trial
notes: Marked 'strongly_implied_innocent' because the transcript ends before the verdict is revealed, but defense narrative presents consensual encounter gone wrong. Severity 4 due to job loss, housing loss, custody battle, daughter changing schools, and complete life disruption. The ambiguous ending prevents definitive 'proven_innocent' classification, but the episode structure suggests reasonable doubt about guilt. The accusation itself - whether ultimately valid or not - caused massive public consequences including termination from employment before any conviction.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Thomas during interrogation: 'You're just looking for the right girl. And one day you'll rape her and live happily ever after.' Also: 'That is disgusting' response to his homosexuality; public confrontation at mother's home with arrest.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Thomas's mother's home in Queens. Mother says 'Tom didn't tell me about a car accident.' Detectives question her about Thomas's whereabouts. Detective: 'Thomas Mathers, you're under arrest for the murder of Lori Switzer. You have the right to remain silent.' This occurs in front of his mother. Later: 'Warner called. Thomas Mathers' DNA didn't match the blood found at either crime scene... She ran it three times. Cut him loose.'
tags: wrong_ID; public_confrontation; arrested; interrogation_coercion; family_exposure; db_error
notes: Thomas Mathers is arrested for rape and murder at his mother's home (public family exposure). Detectives build case on circumstantial evidence: Ford Taurus ownership, cigarette smell from mother's smoking, dirty fingernails from furnace repair, proximity to crimes. During interrogation, detectives focus heavily on his homosexuality, theorizing he's a closeted gay man who rapes women due to self-hatred. One detective says: 'You're just looking for the right girl. And one day you'll rape her and live happily ever after.' DNA testing (run three times) proves he is NOT the rapist. He is released. No apology is shown. Harm includes: (1) arrest in front of mother, (2) hostile interrogation focusing on sexuality, (3) public accusation of serial rape/murder. Severity 3: material sanction (arrest) plus family exposure.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Dobbins: 'You're disgusting!' and 'You give private lessons to your daughters too?' Also threatened: 'I'm gonna make sure the judge maxes out your sentence when you're convicted.' Detective Benson to wife: 'Your husband's a child molester... You were right here, you didn't do a damn thing about it? ... Lady, you're as sick as he is!'
quote_or_scene: Arrested publicly: 'Come on, now! Von B! Hit Von B, he's open! Come on, hit him! Yes! Nice catch! - Dobbins! - Game's over. What...What are you talking about? We're talking about a little girl who trusted you, and you molested her. Mark Dobbins, you're under arrest for sexual abuse. You're kidding me. You're wrong. You're making a mistake!' Later: 'Chestnut Academy fired me. They said forging that letter damaged my integrity. Set a bad example for the students. I'll never get another teaching job. We're selling the house, moving in with my parents upstate.'
tags: ruined_at_work; public_confrontation; perp_walk; fired; teacher; coach; wrong_ID; witness_recant; coerced_confession
notes: Dobbins was arrested publicly at a football game in front of hundreds of people. Was accused by three girls (Holly, Nicole, Danielle), but Holly later recanted saying she lied because she was afraid of the real abuser (Kevin Wilcox). Nicole and Danielle were coached by their mothers after hearing about Holly's case. Charges dismissed but Dobbins lost job, reputation, had to sell house and relocate. Police were verbally aggressive and threatening throughout interrogation. No apology shown on-screen. Life-altering consequences justify severity 4.

police_conduct_quote: Detective: 'Sometimes there are extenuating circumstances. You just need to be straight with us. Tell us exactly what happened up there, and this will be okay.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives question Logan at his elite private school (Hanover Day School) in front of headmaster and search his locker. Later: 'Logan, you need to tell us what happened on that roof.' Logan panics: 'Get me out of here! Help!' He's eventually taken to psychiatric emergency services.
tags: ruined_at_work; school_alert; public_confrontation; coerced_confession; teen; wrong_ID
notes: Logan was home with sister Lindsay (witnessed by Lindsay). DNA matched because his identical twin Lindsay was actually assigned male at birth. Detectives confronted him publicly at school, searched his locker, questioned him without parents initially, used soft coercive language about 'extenuating circumstances.' He had psychiatric crisis and was taken to emergency psych hold. Parents present for arrest at home.

person_label: Lindsay Stanton (teen, student, assigned female but born male)
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Stanton home to arrest Logan. Lindsay attacks detective to protect brother, fractures detective's rib. She's taken to psych ER. Later confesses to being on roof but claims self-defense (which appears true). During interrogation, Dr. Hendrix reveals to her she was born male: 'You were born a boy.' Lindsay: 'I knew it! I never once felt right! I always thought I was a freak! Why didn't anybody tell me?'
notes: Lindsay WAS on the roof and DID bite Luis Vega in self-defense during attempted rape—so she's guilty of the act that caused his death, but it was legitimate self-defense. However, she was falsely accused of MURDER rather than recognized as a victim defending herself. She's included here because: (1) she suffered severe public exposure and family confrontation during the investigation, (2) the investigation caused life-altering trauma when her birth sex was revealed during interrogation, (3) she was treated as a suspect rather than a victim. The accusation's consequence was the revelation of her assigned sex at birth, which was catastrophic. Severity 4 for life-altering identity trauma.

quote_or_scene: Detectives track evidence (car, apartment, computer, purse) to Tauber. Forensics show 'DNA proves his car ran her down, but I don't think he killed her. His feet are size 11. Shoes that kicked Melody to death were size 9.' Later: 'Either Tauber made the kids take part... Or, he's the patsy. Kids used him. His apartment, his computer, his car.'
notes: Tauber was present at the murder but didn't commit it - teenagers Garrett and Louise used his car and apartment. He was complicit (stayed in car, didn't intervene) but didn't rape or kill Melody. Investigation remained police-only; no evidence of public exposure or workplace/family harm from the accusation. He later commits suicide after being manipulated by Garrett, but this is due to guilt/manipulation, not public exposure from false accusation. Excluded from person_rows because exposure was police_only with no public harm.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler threatens Tim: 'You're gonna tell me what I wanna know!' and 'You're the one who's gonna be charged... with having sex with his 15-year-old daughter.' Stabler also threatens to 'lock you up' during emotional confrontation.
quote_or_scene: Detectives follow Tim to Dr. Tanner's office and publicly confront him about attacking Tanner. Tim found Tanner's body. Later interrogated about both murders. Stabler accuses him: 'You were in his apartment. Your fingerprints were on the doorknob.' Tim: 'I didn't kill Tanner... I didn't shoot him. But I sure as hell wish I did!' Detectives search his truck, car, house for gun. He's treated as primary suspect until cleared.
notes: Tim Downey is the victim's father who becomes a murder suspect after his fingerprints are found at Dr. Tanner's murder scene. He discovered Tanner's body after following him. Detectives publicly confront him at Tanner's workplace, threaten him with charges for sex with his daughter (which he didn't do - they mean Tanner did), and interrogate him aggressively. He's subjected to searches and treated as prime suspect for both murders despite being innocent. The public confrontation at the hospital and threats constitute severity 3.

police_conduct_quote: Benson: 'You bash her head in when you ran out of words?' Stabler: 'You got so worked up when you found out about all the guys she was doing that you smacked her around.' Andy: 'I never hit her, and I swear I didn't kill her.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Andy Wall at college, accusing him of murder and domestic violence. Andy: 'I would never hurt her.' Detectives: 'We hear that you got so worked up when you found out about all the guys she was doing that you smacked her around.' Andy denies hitting or killing Lisa. His alibi with study group is verified. Confrontation occurs in presence of his study group members.
notes: Andy Wall is Lisa's ex-boyfriend accused of domestic violence and murder based on Angela's claim he hit Lisa (black eye). He's confronted publicly in front of his college study group. Detectives use aggressive accusations and threats. His alibi is verified - he was studying for exam on Camus' The Stranger with five witnesses. The public nature of the confrontation in front of peers at his study location qualifies as severity 2 exposure.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler: 'How'd it feel? How'd it feel screwing a 15-year-old. You like that? You're a liar!' Later: 'You're pathetic.' Stabler physically manhandles him.
quote_or_scene: Detectives burst into Dr. Tanner's workplace during patient care. Tim Downey is physically attacking Tanner. Stabler: 'You knew Lisa had HIV!' Tanner arrested and publicly questioned about statutory rape and murder. He admits sexual relationship with Lisa but claims he didn't know her age and denies murder. His hospital alibi clears him of Lisa's murder. He's later shot and killed by Angela Agnelli, with the detectives' public exposure of him being a contributing factor.
tags: red_herring; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; arrested; murdered; doctor
notes: Dr. Tanner is guilty of statutory rape (sex with 15-year-old Lisa) but innocent of her murder. Detectives publicly confront him at hospital in front of staff and patients. He's arrested and interrogated. The public exposure leads to Angela Agnelli shooting him to retrieve the sex tape. While he's guilty of the sex crime, the murder accusation was false, and the public exposure contributed to his death. Including because the exposure/investigation created the circumstances leading to his murder. Severity 4 due to death as consequence.

police_conduct_quote: Looks to me like you never stopped trying. [Shows photo] When I saw her at the library, I snuck up on her... She was asking for it.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Jake at Michael Winnick's loft apartment where he's staying with unnamed woman. Stabler says: 'Looks to me like you never stopped trying' and 'She was abducted and raped. Do you know anything about that?' Jake responds defensively about Kaley's virginity. Detectives discover Jake knew Kaley was auctioning her virginity online, eliminating him as suspect.
notes: Jake was Kaley's ex-boyfriend who broke up because she wouldn't have sex. Photo from Kaley's phone showed he met her a week before abduction. Detectives publicly confronted him at friend's apartment in front of unnamed woman. Questioning included aggressive implications about rape. He was cleared when he provided information showing Kaley was auctioning her virginity online, establishing he had no motive since he could have bid. No apology shown.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler: 'You don't do that well with the ladies, do you, Harlan?' 'Yeah, when you pay for it.' 'A girl's virginity would be the ultimate collectible, wouldn't it?' 'You've got an expensive habit here, pal.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives enter Harlan's apartment filled with collectibles. Stabler mocks him: 'Yeah, I can't believe they stopped making these babies.' Benson: 'You don't do that well with the ladies, do you, Harlan?' Stabler: 'Yeah, when you pay for it. A girl's virginity would be the ultimate collectible, wouldn't it? In mint condition, yes. Bet you're the type who has to win every auction you're in. You've got an expensive habit here, pal. How were you gonna pay for the virgin?' Harlan responds he was going to sell Hummels. Scene cuts when Kaley's body is found, implying Harlan's clearance.
notes: Harlan was high bidder on Kaley's virginity auction using screen name 'ConEsewer' (connoisseur). Detectives tracked him through BiddingRoom feedback. Confronted in his apartment where they openly mocked him as a socially inept virgin collector who 'pays for it.' Implied he would kidnap/kill to win auction. Scene immediately cuts to discovery of Kaley's body, strongly implying his innocence since timing proves he couldn't have killed her. No formal apology or acknowledgment of wrongful accusation shown.

quote_or_scene: Denise catches Justin with Carrie: 'I caught that man raping my daughter.' Police: 'He's 21. She's 15. That's statutory rape.' Justin arrested: 'Am I under arrest?' 'You 21?' 'Yeah.' 'Let's go.'
notes: Justin was accused of statutory rape by Denise Eldridge. While he admits to a consensual relationship with 15-year-old Carrie (making him technically guilty of statutory rape under the law), he was arrested and publicly processed for this. The rape accusation drove the initial investigation. Tagged as 'partially_involved' because he was in a relationship with a minor but the 'rape' framing was contested by both him and Carrie as consensual.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler to Justin: 'You can't stand to look at your own work? You hit her 14 times. Lacerated liver, fractured ribs. Punctured lungs. You bashed her head in so hard, her brain broke clean off its stem.' Benson: 'How could you let the man that you love take a murder rap for you?' (lie to Carrie)
quote_or_scene: Justin arrested at cabin: 'Justin Sharp, you're under arrest for murder and kidnapping.' Interrogation: graphic description of injuries. Justin held in contempt of court when refusing to testify against Carrie. Carrie ultimately confesses: 'I killed her.' Justin released after Carrie's confession.
tags: wrong_ID; arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation; interrogation_coercion; held_in_contempt; relationship_destroyed
notes: Justin was arrested for murdering Denise Eldridge based on circumstantial evidence (coat at scene, witness seeing blood on shirt, motive to remove obstacle to relationship). He was publicly arrested, processed through the system, interrogated with graphic accusations, and held in contempt of court for refusing to testify against Carrie. Carrie ultimately confessed to the murder. Justin's life was severely impacted - arrested for murder, publicly humiliated, relationship with Carrie destroyed when she believed detectives' lie that he betrayed her. Severity 4 due to murder arrest, potential life sentence exposure, contempt holding, and complete destruction of his relationship and reputation.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at her apartment thinking she is the victim. She reveals she stayed home after being assaulted at the sex club the night before. 'I've taken six showers since last night. I was so upset I couldn't even call in sick.'
notes: Briefly suspected as the murder victim when identified as 'Lola' from the sex club, but quickly cleared when found alive at home. Limited exposure, primarily police interaction.

person_label: The unnamed sadist/master from the sex club
quote_or_scene: Detectives track him down at restaurant 'Soriellos' where he works as a chef. He admits to BDSM play at the club but denies the murder when shown victim photo: 'Wow, I like it rough, but not that rough. And that's not Lola.'
notes: Ejected from sex club for being too rough. Detectives suspect him initially but he's cleared when he doesn't recognize the actual victim and has different woman as his partner.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler to Duvall after Casey's attack: 'They can't protect you from me.' / 'You better pray someone saw you in there.'
quote_or_scene: Stabler visits Gabriel's home late at night after Casey is attacked, threatens him. Eleanor Duvall later demands apology: 'Do you like your job, detective?... I think an apology is in order.' Captain has Stabler apologize indirectly through Eleanor.
notes: INCLUDED FOR CONTRAST: Gabriel is actually guilty of the serial rapes/murder, but there's a specific incident where Stabler wrongfully accuses him of attacking Casey Novak (which was actually done by Milan Jurgen). This false accusation results in family exposure and threats, followed by a forced apology. The overall case against Gabriel for rape/murder is valid.

police_conduct_quote: You realize you're committing perjury. You could go to prison.
quote_or_scene: Jenny initially picks Jake Lumet's photo: 'Maybe him.' Later recants: 'No, I made a mistake.' Detectives accuse her of selling drugs: 'Did you really lose your pills, Jenny, or did you sell them because you needed the money?' Jenny denies assault occurred.
notes: Jenny initially identifies Jake Lumet as her attacker, then recants. Detectives suspect her of drug dealing. She's threatened with perjury charges in court. Though not publicly exposed beyond police interrogation, she faces legal jeopardy. Ultimately revealed to be abuse victim herself, forced to protect abusive son Kevin. Included as she was falsely accused of drug dealing and assault when she was actually a victim.

quote_or_scene: Detective to Kevin: 'Where's your mother?' Kevin: 'She should be here.' Detective shows bloody footprints: 'Is there any way that these are hers?' Kevin: 'Oh, no. Oh, mom, no.' Kevin arrested: 'Kevin Rogers, you're under arrest for the murder of Carol Rogers.' Kevin to mother: 'Mom, what have you done?' Case dismissed after Jenny recants: 'I never saw him. I was angry at Kevin for marrying that awful woman. I wanted to punish him.'
tags: ruined_in_family; perp_walk; arrested; charged_then_dropped; witness_recant; family_member
notes: Kevin is accused of murdering his wife Carol based on DNA evidence (blood under Carol's fingernail) and his mother Jenny's grand jury testimony identifying him running from the scene. Arrested in front of his mother. Held at Rikers pending trial. Case dismissed when Jenny recants on witness stand, admitting she lied and never actually saw him. Though Kevin is ultimately revealed to be abusive toward Jenny and likely did commit the murder, Jenny's recantation legally clears him of the murder charge. The false accusation element comes from Jenny's perjured testimony which she admits was false.

police_conduct_quote: You think he killed Manette because she put a dairy fork in the meat drawer? / So you chop her up. / Then why'd you kill her? / You, you think I butchered Manette?
quote_or_scene: Detectives enter synagogue: 'Put this on.' 'I look Jewish to you?' 'Respect.' 'Leon Shragewitz?' 'Yes, yes.' 'Police. We need you to come with us.' Later in interrogation: 'You couldn't control her. You like to be in control, don't you, Leon? Is that why you killed her, or is it because you caught her going down on some skel? She made herself unclean by touching him. So you chop her up.' Leon: 'What? What are you talking about? You, you think I butchered Manette? I loved her.'
tags: wrong_ID; public_confrontation; church; coerced_confession; ruined_in_family; social
notes: Leon is arrested at his synagogue in front of his congregation after being tracked there. He confesses under pressure to accidentally pushing Manette down subway stairs, causing her death, but is proven innocent of the murder/dismemberment he was accused of. The M.E. confirms she died from the fall, and body dismemberment was done post-mortem by Russ Bianco at the morgue. Leon's religious community witnessed his arrest. Detectives used accusatory language and moral condemnation ('she made herself unclean,' 'is that why you killed her') during interrogation. No apology shown.

consequence_detail: public_confrontation_at_work, arrested, charged_then_dropped, perp_walk, media_exposure, marriage_dissolution, reputation_damage
police_conduct_quote: Happy enough for the wife to alibi you? // The hell I am. I didn't have sex with anybody. // Yeah, by the way, congratulations. You're the daddy.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Pallister at his workplace (Pallister Labs, 43 West 37th Street) in front of cadavers he works with. He states: 'I was probably here. I spend more time in the lab than I do at home.' His lawyer later says: 'Mr. Pallister admits that he met the defendant at a bar. They had drinks, but he does not remember having sexual relations with her.' At trial, his lawyer mentions: 'She left me after you charged me with rape.' DNA test forced on him proves paternity but he maintains innocence. Later proven he was drugged with Rohypnol and sexually assaulted via electro-ejaculation while unconscious.
tags: ruined_at_work; ruined_in_family; public_confrontation; charged_then_dropped; fabricated_claim; coerced_confession; divorce
notes: Barclay Pallister is the primary victim of false accusation. April Troost fabricated the rape claim after drugging and sexually assaulting him to harvest sperm. He faced: (1) public workplace confrontation by detectives, (2) forced paternity test, (3) criminal charges, (4) public trial with testimony, (5) wife leaving him, (6) reputational destruction. His marriage ended as direct consequence: lawyer states 'She left me after you charged me with rape.' He was eventually proven innocent when investigation revealed April was a serial sexual predator who drugged 34+ men. Police showed no apology on screen. Severity 4 due to marriage dissolution and life-altering reputational/legal consequences.

police_conduct_quote: Benson: 'Killer, your tag, your crime.' Fin: 'You killed them. You wrote your name right there.' Later: 'Then we canvass everybody on that list...Gabriel's last name is Thomason...Gives Gabriel mondo motive to murder Lydon and Robin.'
quote_or_scene: Detective confronts Henry in interrogation: 'Who's calling who a faggot? You're gay doll must be jam. Yeah, you may be just too scared to come out.' Henry: 'I'm not queer.' Detective: 'You're on the circuit. That is until we put you in jail for murder.' Henry: 'Murder? Yo, I never saw them.' Detective: 'Yes, you did. You killed them. You wrote your name right there.' Henry: 'You think I wrack those fags? I ripped them off, that's it!' Later squad realizes 'killer' refers to HIV strain not gang tag, clearing Henry.
notes: Henry Finello (MKS gang member 'King Henry') was arrested for assault/robbery at Euphoria club. Detectives saw 'KILLER' graffiti at both murder scenes and connected it to his gang affiliation. During interrogation they explicitly accused him of the murders ('your tag, your crime', 'you killed them'). He denied it ('I never saw them', 'I didn't kill no one'). He was cleared when Dr. Huang realized 'killer' referred to the HIV killer strain, not the gang. While arrested on other charges (assault), the false murder accusation occurred in private interrogation with no public exposure beyond the arrest itself. Severity 2 for being publicly arrested and formally accused of double homicide in custody.

quote_or_scene: Maddy's uncle Patrick McCorkle goes to Buggesi's apartment after being tipped off by Mrs. McCorkle. SVU finds Patrick beating Buggesi unconscious. Patrick says Buggesi 'said he was sorry. That he was born with unnatural urges, he couldn't control himself.' Buggesi is hospitalized. Later: 'Buggesi was sitting in a dentist's chair at the time of the shooting' and 'There's an open warrant on him from Florida' (for actual molestation, not this shooting).
notes: Buggesi is proven innocent of the SHOOTING (he has a dentist alibi), which is what SVU was investigating. He appears guilty of molesting Maddy (there's a Florida warrant and his own admission of 'unnatural urges'), but he did NOT commit the crime SVU was investigating (the school shooting). The uncle's assault is a direct consequence of SVU informing the family, leading to severe physical harm (beaten 'almost to death'). Severity 4 due to life-threatening injuries.

quote_or_scene: Witness tells detectives 'Johnny Mayhew. He's a boy in my class that gets a lot of timeouts. He has a gun. The first day after summer vacation. He brought it to school in his backpack.' Detectives go to the Mayhew home and confront Mrs. Mayhew about the gun. They find a .380 semiautomatic (mother's gun), test Johnny for gunshot residue, and arrest Mrs. Mayhew. Mrs. Mayhew protests: 'There is no way my Johnny shot those kids.' Later confirmed: 'This is a precision sniper rifle... We can rule out little Johnny Mayhew.'
notes: Johnny is publicly accused in front of his mother at home. The detectives conduct gunshot residue testing on him and arrest his mother for illegal gun possession, creating family exposure and stigma. Though not arrested himself, the accusation is made publicly in his home with his mother present, and the wrong weapon caliber proves his innocence. Severity 2: public accusation witnessed by family, mother arrested, but no formal sanction against Johnny himself.

police_conduct_quote: You're going to jail, Charlie. And if we charge you as an adult, you're looking at 20 years.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Charlie at his home with his father and half-sister Emma present. They accuse him of stabbing Sean based on video evidence showing him near the school, threaten him with 20 years as an adult. Emma's alibi is revealed as a lie. Later proven Charlie was covering for Emma—he only drove Sean to hospital and disposed of evidence.
notes: Charlie initially suspected because he beat up Sean the previous week. Security footage places him at school when his alibi (walking Emma home) falls apart. Detectives threaten him with adult prosecution in front of his father and sister. He's actually innocent of the stabbing—he was protecting his 8-year-old sister Emma, who actually stabbed Sean. No apology shown.

quote_or_scene: Emma's grandparents, coached by attorney James Decker, manipulate Emma into falsely accusing Zoe of sexual abuse using photos of therapeutic massages. Detectives confront Zoe at the hospital immediately after her partner Kate dies. Court testimony reveals grandmother used anti-gay 'studies' and leading questions to manufacture the accusation. Expert witness Dr. Huang testifies to 'parental alienation syndrome.' Prosecution proves it was fabricated hate crime.
tags: fabricated_claim; custody_dispute; public_confrontation; ruined_in_family; arrested; family_present
notes: Zoe is Emma's non-biological mother (partner of deceased biological mother Kate). After winning custody of Emma, grandparents accuse Zoe of molesting Emma to gain custody themselves. Attorney Decker coached them using anti-gay pseudoscience. Zoe arrested and faces losing Emma permanently. Accusation occurs literally as Kate dies. Proven false via expert testimony on parental alienation. Grandmother admits in court she was 'led to ask leading questions.' Life-altering harm: loss of child, arrest, public accusation of CSA during partner's death.

quote_or_scene: Parole officer Craig Lennon accompanies detectives to Mayder's apartment. They break down door, Mayder flees to rooftop pursued by police shouting 'Police! Stop!' and 'Mayder, we just wanna talk to you.' Mayder jumps from rooftop to his death during pursuit. Later investigation proves he had nothing to do with Carly's abduction - his journal shows he was still 'searching' for victims on day of kidnapping, laptop contains no photos of Carly, and no DNA evidence links him to the crime scene.
tags: physical_death; suicide; rooftop_pursuit; sex_offender_registry; parole_involved; wrong_suspect; proven_innocent_posthumously
notes: Joel Mayder is a registered sex offender on parole who was caught sitting outside Carly's school a month earlier. When detectives and his parole officer arrive at his apartment to question him about the kidnapping, he flees and jumps to his death from a rooftop during the pursuit. Subsequent investigation (laptop journal dated day of kidnapping shows he was still searching for victims, no DNA match to van, no connection to actual crime) proves he was not involved in Carly's abduction. His death was a direct consequence of being accused/pursued for this crime. The parole officer's presence during the apartment confrontation constitutes workplace/professional exposure. Severity 4: death directly caused by the false accusation and pursuit.

quote_or_scene: Detectives publicly confront Varla on the street outside coffee shop: 'You threw him away.' Varla protests: 'No, he's inside me.' Medical exam proves she has pseudocyesis (phantom pregnancy), not real pregnancy. Detective acknowledges: 'Detective... you don't have to do that. Varla hasn't recently been pregnant.'
notes: Varla is publicly accused on the street in front of coffee shop customers. She suffers from pseudocyesis after having three children taken by ACS. Detectives threaten arrest before doctor intervenes and clears her. Clear case of mistaken accusation with public exposure and threat of arrest.

police_conduct_quote: Any chance you fathered those babies? / I'm a happily married man. / So take a paternity test.
quote_or_scene: Detectives interview Spencer at what appears to be his workplace or campaign office. Munch: 'Any chance you fathered those babies?' Spencer: 'I'm a happily married man.' Munch: 'So take a paternity test.' Spencer: 'No. Doing that would be admitting there's a possibility I slept with her, and I didn't.' Detectives leave when called away; Spencer is never mentioned again.
notes: Spencer is accused of fathering Ella's babies based on proximity (worked closely with her during campaign). He's questioned at work/office setting. Refuses paternity test on principle. Never mentioned again after detectives are called away, strongly implying he was cleared. Public exposure at workplace (detectives came to his office) plus threat of invasive testing qualifies as severity 2.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Franklin in the locker room in front of his teammates: 'Hey, Roddy.' 'What can I do for you?' 'Come with us. We'll explain in the car.' 'It's all good, fellas. Just the cops have found my double D.' Teammates present witness him being taken away by police. Later questioned about murder: 'That's not the only thing we found. Your ass is gonna be astroturf you don't start talking.'
notes: Franklin is publicly approached by detectives in the team locker room in front of teammates and taken for questioning. Though his wife provides alibi, detectives continue to pursue him as suspect based on ring found in victim's room and casino footage showing conflict. Eventually proven innocent when actual killer (Adam) is identified. Public exposure at workplace (locker room with teammates present) qualifies as severity 2 harm even without formal job consequences.

police_conduct_quote: Captain to Fin: 'You practically treated my kid like anybody off the street. Why don't you believe him?' Elliot: 'His body language is all over the place.' Olivia: 'If he put a body out there, Elliot, why dig it up?'
quote_or_scene: Ken is arrested for felony assault, drunk and disorderly, and resisting arrest. SVU interrogates him as a murder suspect. Captain Cragen: 'Ken Randall is now a viable suspect in the Stansfield homicide. I've already started a file.' Ken provides DNA that clears him, proving his half-brother Darius is the killer.
tags: arrested; public_confrontation; family; wrong_ID; coerced_interview; ruined_in_family
notes: Ken was arrested and investigated as the primary suspect in a double homicide. Though he was trying to protect his half-brother Darius, Ken was publicly interrogated, arrested for felony assault on police (later shown to be defensive), and treated as a viable murder suspect by SVU including his own father. His innocence was proven through DNA testing that revealed Darius as the actual killer. Ken suffered arrest, interrogation, family exposure (mother present during questioning), and suspicion from his father and SVU colleagues.

consequence_detail: ostracized, defamation_risk, reputation_damage, ongoing_investigation_for_years, social_isolation, employment_impact
quote_or_scene: Steven Stansfield: 'I didn't kill my wife. I know you don't believe that. Nobody does. But I didn't do it. ... they tell me that Nina's dead... But where is my son? The police will not tell me a thing. But they sure as hell talked to my in-laws, my boss, my friends, and labeled me a killer.' Munch: 'Husband's still the prime suspect.' Captain: 'Three DV calls six months before she disappeared.'
tags: ruined_at_work; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically; media_outing; ostracized; wrong_ID; reputation_damage
notes: Steven Stansfield was the prime suspect in his wife's murder for THREE YEARS despite being innocent. Police spoke to his in-laws, boss, friends, and neighbors, publicly labeling him a killer. He states 'Nobody believes I didn't do it' and describes being unable to get information about his missing son while being treated as a murderer. He was socially ostracized, professionally damaged, and psychologically devastated. By the end of the episode, Darius Parker is proven to be the actual killer. Steven's life was completely destroyed by false accusation - he turned to drinking at home, lost social connections, was alienated from his wife's family, and lived under a cloud of suspicion for years. This is severity 4 (life-altering) harm.

police_conduct_quote: BLAINE: 'I'm saying the little whore came in here and stole your tobacco license, so you wanted to pay her back.' BLAINE: 'That's why you took her outside and hit her over the head?' BLAINE: 'You get turned on by little children? Pervert.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Hamzid at his store in front of customers/employees. BLAINE: 'Yeah, the health inspector said you wanted to kill her.' HAMZID: 'I was angry. She comes in here... She is real pretty.' BLAINE: 'Yeah. She is a hottie, all right.' BLAINE: 'You get turned on by little children? Pervert.' He is eliminated when CSU determines shoe prints don't match: 'Based on the depth of impressions, the smaller perp weighed about 240 pounds, the heavier 300. At most, this guy weighs 150.'
notes: Store owner previously caught in tobacco sting by Jessica. Detectives publicly accuse him of rape and call him a pervert at his workplace based on his anger toward Jessica and proximity to crime scene. Quickly eliminated via physical evidence (weight/shoe print mismatch). Subjected to degrading accusations and insults during questioning in his store.

police_conduct_quote: BLAINE to Mia (minor, age 14): 'Tell us the truth, and it counts in your favor. It counts a lot... once your mother shows up, the lawyers show up. And then truth time is over... whatever you say has to be put in the book. And once it's there, it's on your record forever... This is your chance. Tell the truth now. And the fact it's your first offense, you'll get off... You'll get immunity.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives publicly arrest Mia at school orchestra practice: 'Hey, and what happened to your face?... You're coming too. Let's go.' Questioned as minor without parent present in coercive interrogation. Later proven she acted in retaliation for Jessica's brutal assault on her brother Rudi. Jessica confesses: 'JESSICA: Yes. I couldn't stand the sight of him. I'm sorry.'
notes: 14-year-old girl arrested at school in front of orchestra peers for rape/assault she didn't commit. Was actually retaliating against Jessica who had brutally assaulted her brother Rudi. Subjected to coercive questioning as a minor without parent present. Detective Blaine promised immunity falsely and attempted to extract confession before mother/lawyer arrived. Jessica's fabricated rape claim proven false when Jessica confesses to attacking Rudi first.

quote_or_scene: Detectives publicly arrest Kenny (age 16) at school orchestra practice: 'Kenny, no phones in practice.' 'Hey, Kenny. What's going on? You tell me. Where were you two afternoons ago? You don't remember. Stand up. Come with us.' Later proven he retaliated against Jessica who had assaulted his brother. Jessica confesses to the original assault on Rudi.
notes: 16-year-old boy arrested at school in front of orchestra for rape/assault he didn't commit. Like his sister, was retaliating against Jessica for her brutal assault on their brother Rudi that resulted in hospitalization and amputation of three fingers. Jessica's rape claim proven fabricated when she confesses to initiating violence against Rudi.

police_conduct_quote: You think he'd let me see my son if I wasn't cured? / If you think you can get away with it, yeah. / Threaten to kill him or you told him he'd never see his mommy again? Usually works for while.
quote_or_scene: STABLER: Were you alone with your son Jake yesterday? HENSAL: No. Why? STABLER: He says he was abused. HENSAL: Well, it wasn't, it wasn't me. I would never touch my son. STABLER: Well your rap sheet says differently. ... WARNER: This is Jake's mitochondrial DNA. This is his abuser's. It's an exact match. Jake and his molester have identical mitochondrial DNA. The mother passes that on to the children. That means Teddy abused his little brother.
notes: Gregory Hensal has a prior conviction for molesting his older son Teddy 7-8 years ago. When Jake reports abuse, detectives immediately suspect Gregory due to his history and the fact he had supervised visits with Jake. Detectives confront him at his home with his sister present, use aggressive interrogation tactics including threats and accusations. Polygraph initially shows deception about being alone with Jake (his sister admits she left them alone briefly), reinforcing suspicion. DNA evidence later proves Teddy (not Gregory) abused Jake. Gregory experiences public accusation in front of family, aggressive police interrogation with threats, but no arrest or formal charges shown. Severity 2: publicly accused in front of sister at home, subjected to threatening interrogation, but no material sanction shown.

quote_or_scene: Danny Morrison, Cameron Shaw. Come with us, please. / Can it wait till after rehearsal? We open next week. / Show's over. // The school throws Cameron out: 'They're throwing Cameron out of school. He graduates in five weeks. He could lose his scholarship.'
tags: school_alert; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; fabricated_claim; witness_recant; teen
notes: Danny is arrested publicly during school play rehearsal in front of classmates. Jamie later recants on video evidence showing she initiated the sexual encounter. Danny is expelled from school. His father's lawyer is mentioned calling the ADA. The rape accusation was proven false through security camera footage and physical evidence (wax patterns on clothing contradicted Jamie's account). Severity 3: expelled from school weeks before graduation, arrested publicly, reputation damage.

quote_or_scene: Danny Morrison, Cameron Shaw. Come with us, please. Can it wait till after rehearsal? We open next week. Show's over. // Cameron's father: 'I work two jobs to send him to that school. He's got a scholarship to Cornell. He's the first in our family to go to college. This could ruin Cameron's life.' // 'They're throwing Cameron out of school. He graduates in five weeks. He could lose his scholarship.'
tags: school_alert; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; fabricated_claim; witness_recant; teen
notes: Cameron is arrested publicly during school play rehearsal. First-generation college student with full scholarship to Cornell. Father works two jobs to afford prep school. Expelled five weeks before graduation, scholarship at risk. Jamie later recants; security footage and forensic evidence (wax residue patterns) prove the sex was consensual and Jamie-initiated. Father threatens to go to media about racial angle ('White girl lies about being raped by a black boy and just walks away'). Severity 4: career-ending consequences (scholarship loss, expulsion preventing graduation, first-generation college opportunity destroyed).

police_conduct_quote: Domestic terror charge is gonna put you under 40 years to life, Mitchell. It'd be in your best interest to tell us where Haley is.
quote_or_scene: FBI agent Star and detectives question Mitchell about Haley's rape based on audio recording of him grabbing Haley's arm. Mitchell denies involvement: 'I haven't seen her since... The Cause meeting on Monday night.' He describes seeing Haley get into an SUV with another man. DNA later proves Zander Owens was the rapist, not Mitchell.
notes: Mitchell was questioned privately in police interview rooms and at his cabin. No evidence of public accusation or exposure beyond law enforcement. His arrest was for domestic terrorism charges (dynamite possession), not rape. The rape investigation remained confidential. No workplace, family, media, or other public exposure occurred regarding the rape accusation. Therefore, while Mitchell was wrongly suspected, he does not meet the threshold for inclusion as he experienced no public harm from the false rape accusation - only private interrogation.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Beck to Barry during arrest: 'Shut up!' when he protests innocence
quote_or_scene: Detective Beck tips off media: 'You want a story? I got a story for you. Martin Trenway, the big PI lawyer, right over there, just got charged with rape.' Barry arrested at girlfriend Ophelia's home, taken in front of her. Media present during perp walk asking questions.
tags: wrong_ID; perp_walk; media_outing; arrested; public_confrontation; db_error
notes: Barry Cole works at rental car agency. His fingerprints found on Jaguar passenger window from processing rental cars, misinterpreted as suspect prints. Detective Beck called O'Halloran for prints match but didn't wait for full analysis showing prints were on wrong side of car and belonged to employee. Barry arrested at girlfriend's home in middle of night, taken in custody. Detective Beck deliberately tipped off media about wrong suspect (initially said 'Martin Trenway' but Barry was the one arrested and perp-walked). Shows coercive language during arrest. No apology shown on-screen after release. Released only after O'Halloran clarified prints belonged to car processor, not rapist.

quote_or_scene: Detectives find Andrew Munch, a homeless man with Alzheimer's-like symptoms, near the crime scene with blood on his hands and a collection of sex crime newspaper clippings. He's brought in for questioning. Later determined to have pseudodementia of depression, not involvement in the crimes. Real perpetrator (Brent Allen Banks) identified through fingerprints and bite marks.
notes: Andrew Munch was suspected based on circumstantial evidence (proximity to victims, blood on hands, collection of crime clippings). No public exposure occurred—questioning was private and he was held only briefly. He was later proven innocent when the real perpetrator was identified. His consequence severity is rated 1 because there was no public exposure and only brief private questioning. However, he later commits vigilante murder of the actual perpetrator during a manic episode, which is a separate criminal act for which he is responsible.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler and Beck question him aggressively at work site: 'Women don't like you, do they?' 'You take? That sounds like rape to me.' 'You're just trying to twist my words'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Ted at work property he's inspecting, in presence of office manager Luke Dixon. Stabler: 'Four rapes and a homicide in your buildings makes me think we don't [have the wrong guy].' Beck/Stabler probe his sexual behavior publicly. Ted: 'I take what I want and move on.' Stabler: 'You take? That sounds like rape to me.'
notes: Property manager accused of being serial rapist due to access to master keys and buildings. Questioned aggressively at work site in front of office manager. Cleared via DNA/hair sample. Detectives apply psychological pressure suggesting he 'takes' women and 'doesn't need to' rape because he 'gets action,' implying sexual misconduct. No apology shown. Severity 2: public workplace accusation without arrest, but reputational harm and professional humiliation clear.

police_conduct_quote: Deputy physically assaulted T-bone during arrest; sheriff questioned both activists about Dunford murder trying to connect them to homicide despite environmental group's non-violent history
quote_or_scene: T-bone arrested at environmental protest. Later questioned by sheriff about Carl Dunford murder: 'Your pacifist friend here, T-bone, he just sucker-punched one of my deputies.' Persephone responds: 'T-bone is not a killer. But your deputy, Ibold, is gunning to become one.' Eventually revealed Britney Dunlap killed Dunford, not activists.
notes: T-bone and the environmental group were primary suspects in Carl Dunford's murder, subjected to police scrutiny and pressure. Sheriff tried to leverage assault charges against Persephone to get information. Group placed under moratorium. Actual killer was Dunford's long-term captive victim Britney Dunlap.

police_conduct_quote: Sheriff to Persephone: 'You people certainly aren't doing anything to find the real killer.' FBI agent: 'If it was someone in EDG, we've got them on the federal RICO statute. Could take down the entire organization.'
quote_or_scene: Sheriff investigates environmental group for Dunford murder, presenting threatening email as evidence. Group put under moratorium. FBI threatened RICO prosecution. Press conference held publicly linking case to activists before Britney identified as actual killer.
notes: Collective group treated as suspects in murder investigation. Public exposure through press conference and investigation. Actual killer was Dunford's captive victim. Group members innocent but publicly investigated and threatened with federal charges.

police_conduct_quote: You raped all three of these girls and battered them to death? ... Don't lie to me. Take a look at them. Now you hit them over and over and over until they were dead.
quote_or_scene: Detectives burst into motel room while Peters is with companion. 'Blake Peters, you're under arrest for statutory rape.' Motel clerk and companion (Candy) present during arrest. In interrogation, Stabler accuses: 'You screw little girls off the street... You're so sorry that you raped all three of these girls and battered them to death?' Peters denies murder: 'I didn't kill those girls. I wanted to help them get off the street.'
notes: Peters is guilty of soliciting minors for prostitution (statutory rape) but innocent of the three murders he was accused of. His arrest was conducted publicly at a motel with witnesses present (motel clerk, his companion Candy). During interrogation, detectives aggressively accused him of murder with verbal threats and showed graphic autopsy photos. His wife was also indirectly exposed when detectives visited his home asking for his location. No apology given when investigation shifted to Victor Bodine. Classified as 'partially_involved' because he committed sex crimes but not the murders.

police_conduct_quote: Yeah, just leave two kids to drown. / After you handcuffed them to the chair. / It wasn't me, no way. It was that crazy bitch.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Frank at his mother's home after he hides in a refrigerator box. Mrs. Hovis objects: 'Who says you can come in?' Fin and Munch accuse Frank publicly: 'Yeah, just leave two kids to drown.' Frank defends himself: 'I saved them. I risked my own life to get them out... It was that crazy bitch [Alma]. She said she didn't cuff them, they'd try to jump out.' Frank is arrested/detained but it's established he was merely hired transport and actually saved the children. The accusation happens in front of his mother and potentially neighbors she mentioned worrying about.
notes: Frank Hovis is initially treated as complicit in child endangerment. Detectives pursue him to his mother's home and accuse him publicly in front of her despite his protestation that he merely drove the van for hire and actually risked his life to save the children after Alma Cordoza handcuffed them. He receives harsh treatment and moral condemnation ('moron') despite being innocent of the abuse. His mother expresses concern about neighbors talking, establishing community exposure. While he may face legal consequences for involvement, he is innocent of the child abuse/endangerment the detectives accuse him of, and he actually saved the children. The public confrontation at his family home with accusations in front of his mother qualifies as severity 2 exposure.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at dance rehearsal: 'Mr. Masoner, I'm sure you can make room on your dance card for me.' Later arrested: 'Congratulations, Mr. Masoner. Three weeks ago, you became the proud owner of a 2-gram vial of dieldrin.' Wesley protests: 'I didn't do it! What the hell is going on?' Eventually Glenn Cheales confesses: 'Wes took the love of my life, so I took his. I killed Danielle.'
notes: Wesley Masoner was publicly questioned at his workplace (dance rehearsal with company members present), arrested, and charged with murdering his wife Danielle. Police found planted evidence (dieldrin vial, forged shipping receipt) at his home. The real killer, Glenn Cheales, framed Wesley to punish him for having an affair with Glenn's wife Naomi. Wesley was proven innocent when Glenn confessed on-screen. Though initially suspected of rape (victim mistakenly thought to have been raped), the actual charge was murder via poisoning. Includes workplace exposure (detectives interrupted rehearsal in front of dance company), arrest, formal charges, and attorney involvement before exoneration.

quote_or_scene: MOLLINAX: 'September 17, 1971, I was sitting on a bar stool at McFadden's. Cops came in and arrested me for killing Suzanne and the baby. I told them I didn't do it. But nobody believed me.' 'I was a mean drunk back then. I didn't take it well when Suzanne threw me out.' 'One time I said I'd burn the place down if I ever caught her with another man.' 'It took the jury 20 minutes to convict.' FIN: 'The Mollinax case was closed in 1972. The ex-husband was convicted. Mike Mollinax, two counts of Murder Two, Arson in the First.'
notes: Mollinax was convicted in 1972 for murdering his ex-wife Suzanne and their baby in an arson fire. He was actually innocent - Jack Colino committed the murders and Jud Tierney killed Colino. Mollinax served 34 years before exoneration. His conviction was based on motive (prior threats while drunk) and fleeing. He admits to being 'a mean drunk' who threatened to burn the house down, and beating up a girlfriend who then turned him in, but he did not commit the murders he was convicted of. The consequence is life-altering: 34 years wrongfully imprisoned, plus the complication of a prison killing in self-defense that nearly prevented his release.

police_conduct_quote: Carisi to Gabriel: 'We're gonna search that van. If we find any evidence that Theo was inside, you're on the hook for first-degree kidnapping. You better come clean. That's 15 years, son.' Also threatens him with Mexican Mafia prison violence.
quote_or_scene: Gabriel is publicly arrested at his apartment with roommates present ('You sit down too'), chased down when he flees out a window, detained, and subjected to coercive interrogation including explicit threats about prison rape by gangs. His lawyer repeatedly tries to get him to stop cooperating. He's held on weapons charges as leverage despite having nothing to do with Theo's disappearance.
tags: ruined_physically; public_confrontation; coerced_confession; arrested; held_overnight; interrogation_coercion; wrong_ID
notes: Gabriel is Nadine's ex-boyfriend who broke up with her 2 months prior. His DNA (hair) was found in Theo's room from when he dated Nadine. He was angry about the breakup and sent threatening texts but had nothing to do with the kidnapping. Police arrest him publicly at his apartment with roommates present, chase him when he flees, detain him, and use extreme coercive tactics including threats of 15 years prison and Mexican Mafia sexual violence to try to extract a confession. He's held on weapons/drug charges as leverage. Eventually proven innocent when Gloria and Oscar confess to the actual kidnapping plan. No apology shown.

police_conduct_quote: "I'm not gonna let you go now, friend." "We're talking about Ming Hao, Kara Bawson, Edie Rimpo. Anna Fischner. Did she fight back? Is that why you killed her?"
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Dr. Chanoor at the clinic in front of staff: 'Rankesh Chanoor, you're under arrest for rape and murder.' Henry (employee) witnesses: 'I was there when you busted him the other day.' Lineup follows where victims cannot identify him. His daughter (attorney) says: 'Obviously you don't [have other ways to ID], or we wouldn't be leaving.'
notes: Dr. Chanoor had prior workplace allegations of sexual harassment and assault (supply closet incident with Joanne Bing), which may have influenced detectives' suspicions. He is arrested publicly at his clinic in front of staff including Henry (his son, the actual perpetrator). All rape victims fail to identify him in lineup. Cleared when his son Henry is revealed as the actual perpetrator.

police_conduct_quote: "You're about to be hating life." Detectives accuse him of targeting women for revenge: "You thought they were all Brooklyn trash. Nothing but warm-ups for your ultimate target. Kara Bawson, your ex-fiance. You lost your meal ticket...You wanted revenge."
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Oliver at work: 'Southeast Asian sex tourism board. Congratulations, you won a free cruise to Thailand.' Oliver: 'Am I getting punked?' Detective: 'You're about to be hating life.' They question him about Ming Hao (shows photo): 'You know her.' Oliver: 'Never seen her before in my life.' Ming later identifies his photo: 'That's Oliver Mitsakos. He was a TA for intro to econ my freshman year...He always flirted, but he was aggressive about it.' Cleared when another attack occurs while he's in custody: 'Finn, a moment? You just got an emergency call, urgent. Your perp just hit again.'
notes: Oliver is Kara Bawson's ex-fiancé. Kara's father Tom Bawson identifies him as suspect: 'Start with Oliver Mitsakos...this little jerk has a thing for young Asian hookers.' Ming Hao identifies his photo and describes him as her aggressive TA who flirted with her. Cleared definitively when another rape occurs while he's being questioned. Exposure appears limited to police interrogation with no indication of public knowledge or workplace consequences shown on screen.

quote_or_scene: Police execute search warrant at Millstead's apartment while building residents present. 'Seth Millstead, you're under arrest for possession of child pornography.' Defense attorney: 'There is not one image of genitals or a sex act... Based on your definition, this is child pornography.' Photos were actually medical documentation of illegal pesticide testing causing skin reactions, not sexual abuse.
notes: Millstead was guilty of conducting illegal human pesticide experiments on children (including Diego) for Danforth Chemical, causing serious harm including cancer. He was NOT guilty of child pornography - the photos of Diego in underwear were medical documentation of skin reactions to pesticide exposure, not sexual exploitation. He was publicly arrested for CP in front of building residents, held at Rikers, and murdered in prison before the true nature of the photos was discovered. Qualifies as 'partially_involved' - innocent of the ACCUSED offense (CP) but guilty of a different serious crime (illegal human experimentation/poisoning).

police_conduct_quote: About 20 years? [when asked when she can go home] // You made her suicidal with your accusations and innuendo! [father's accusation]
quote_or_scene: Detective shows Charlotte her bloody sneaker: 'That's your mother's blood.' Charlotte: 'I was there? I did it. I killed my mom.' [Immediately after] 'Calm her down. Pull her arm up. I wanna die. Get a bus! SVU to central. We need a bus at the one-six. Attempted suicide. She's bleeding out.'
notes: Charlotte is interrogated without attorney present despite being a minor. Father Sidney (a lawyer) explicitly objects: 'you interrogated her without a lawyer present!' Detectives confront her with physical evidence (bloody shoe), tell her 'About 20 years' when she asks to go home, causing her to confess under duress. She immediately attempts suicide by slitting her wrist. Later cleared via sodium amytal interview showing Ryan Bedford was the actual killer. No public exposure occurred - accusation remained within police/family circle. However, severity is 4 due to suicide attempt directly caused by interrogation tactics.

quote_or_scene: IAB: 'I can't risk having a cop with your anger issues out on the street. As of right now, you're on suspension.' // News coverage shown on TV. // Casey: 'IAB's gonna have to go after Elliot now.' // Elliot: 'The press has already convicted me. IAB has suspended me. Grand jury will indict.'
notes: Elliot is accused of murdering Ryan Bedford during arrest. Ten eyewitnesses report seeing him 'beat' Ryan. IAB suspends him immediately. Media covers the story extensively (shown on screen). He faces grand jury investigation. Eventually cleared when ME discovers Ryan had undiagnosed long QT syndrome that caused cardiac arrest during the chase, not Elliot's actions. The CPR Elliot performed (not the restraint) may have ruptured the spleen, but Ryan was already dead from cardiac arrest at that point. Public exposure via media coverage and workplace suspension constitute severity 3.

police_conduct_quote: Stabler to Dan: 'You know, pal--you know, you love your kid so much, you better stop worrying about your ass and start helping me find your boy. Now, what were you doing last night and why? What were you doin'?!' [aggressive interrogation]
quote_or_scene: Laura tells detectives: 'I know who took him. Who? Dan Kozlowski. My ex-husband.' Later proven via DNA that Dan is not even the biological father. Highway patrol chases Dan through Manhattan, he jumps in river, arrested. Interrogation scene shows Stabler yelling at him aggressively.
notes: Dan was falsely accused by Laura of kidnapping. He had alibi (was in Bronx until 10pm making drug delivery). Police pursued him in high-speed chase shown on-screen with sirens and press/media clearly present. He was arrested, interrogated aggressively by Stabler. Later DNA proves he's not even the biological father, completely exonerating him. He suffered public humiliation via police chase, arrest, and interrogation as suspected kidnapper.

quote_or_scene: Cragen: 'If we did that to Laura, we would have every victim rights group in the country picketing the stationhouse.' Stabler: 'I thought Laura had lied to me, so I sicced a reporter on her.' Marino on TV: 'Sources close to the investigation tell me you're the prime suspect, Laura... You threw his sonogram in the trash. You hated that child, didn't you?... You killed him.' Laura: 'No! You get out of my house right now!' Laura then commits suicide. Baby later found alive, proving her innocence.
notes: Laura was publicly accused of murdering her baby by reporter Cindy Marino in a televised interview. Stabler admits he 'sicced' the reporter on her after suspecting Laura killed Kendall. Marino aggressively confronts Laura on camera, accusing her of killing her son, citing the discarded sonogram as evidence. Laura commits suicide after the interview. Baby is later found alive and well, completely exonerating Laura. Her death was a direct consequence of the public accusation. Stabler expresses regret but no formal apology shown.

quote_or_scene: Simon to Olivia: 'They're trying to frame me. I never even met this woman I'm supposed to have raped.' Later: 'I swear to you, Olivia. I swear. You know me... I could never lie to my big sister.' Captain Millfield reveals personal motive: 'after the night nothing happened with Simon Marsden, my sister flunked out, became an alcoholic, and has been in and out of psych hospitals ever since.'
tags: ruined_at_work; fabricated_claim; wrong_ID; family; custody_dispute; public_confrontation
notes: Captain Millfield has clear personal vendetta against Simon due to 16-year-old high school incident with her sister Carrie. Simon claims he accidentally tore Carrie's dress during consensual kissing; Carrie's father accused him of assault. Millfield 'coincidentally' targets Simon when his DNA (from unrelated 6-year-old murder investigation dragnet) stays in system due to 'bureaucratic snafu.' All 3 stalking victims and rape victim Donna Leonte attend pharmacy where Simon works. DNA hair match seems planted/suspicious given Millfield's demonstrated bias. Simon's juvenile record shows shoplifting women's clothes (claims it was for girlfriend on a bet). Episode strongly implies frame-up but ends ambiguously with Simon fleeing bail. Olivia's conflict of interest (family relation) clouds investigation. Riverpark police surveilled Simon's home and workplace. Girlfriend Lucy stonewalled Olivia. Public exposure at workplace (pharmacy customers/coworkers aware of police investigation). Arrested, then jumped bail - suggesting either guilt OR fear of corrupt prosecution.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Stabler forced me to go to my church... intimidated my client, manipulated him by using his faith. Reverend Curtis was threatened with the loss of his immortal soul in a house of God.
quote_or_scene: Here he comes! Reverend Curtis, are you a friend of Nick Benchley? Did you know he was a prostitute? Were drugs involved? What was the nature of your relationship? // Mrs. Curtis shoots Curtis after believing he murdered Richard Antrim // 'I shot my husband 'cause he betrayed me, our children, our church.'
tags: clergy; media_outing; perp_walk; public_confrontation; coerced_confession; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically
notes: Curtis confessed falsely to protect his son Paul, who was actually in relationship with victim. Confession obtained through psychological coercion in church. His DNA at scene was partial match, later understood as son's DNA. Curtis was publicly accused in front of media at his home after son's funeral. Wife shot him believing he was guilty. He survives. Trent Labette was actual killer.

quote_or_scene: Julia Millfield confesses: 'I convinced [Donna Leonte] that, if she didn't [identify Simon], he would rape somebody else.' The hair evidence is revealed to be telogen hair that 'was never yanked out of anyone's head' but rather 'somebody took it out of his comb and planted it as evidence.' Simon states: 'All I did to Carrie was kiss her. When she said stop, I stopped.'
notes: Simon was framed for rape by Captain Julia Millfield who planted his hair at the crime scene and coached the victim Donna Leonte to falsely identify him. He became a fugitive, jumping bail on stalking and rape charges. His DNA (hair) was supposedly found on the victim, but forensic analysis proves the hair was telogen (naturally shed) and planted, not pulled out during an attack. Millfield fabricated the case to punish Simon for an incident years earlier where he kissed her sister Carrie, who then had a traumatic flashback to being molested by her own father. Simon's actual conduct was stopping when Carrie said no. The exposure remained within law enforcement - FBI tracked him, but there's no indication of media coverage, workplace notification, or public confrontation. His consequence severity is rated 3 due to being a wanted fugitive with an arrest warrant, even though the public exposure was limited.

police_conduct_quote: Dense would be you thinking that you could get away with this. / My, what strong hands you have. Looks like you're digging into flesh there.
quote_or_scene: Neighbor at crime scene: 'I know who did it. Darren Tolson. He lives in that building at the end of the block... They say Darren Tolson is a convicted sex offender. Says he targets young boys.' Detectives confront Tolson at his workplace bakery where coworkers can observe. Later victim identified as Riley Cuskey, not Joey Briglund, clearing Tolson completely.
notes: Tolson is a registered sex offender who served time for CSA years prior. When a murdered teen is found, a neighbor immediately accuses him. His landlord mentions someone puts up fliers about him being a sex offender every morning. Sonia Briglund has been stalking him for 10 years, blaming him for her son Joey's disappearance. Detectives publicly confront him at his workplace bakery (coworkers present), using confrontational and demeaning language. He is later completely cleared when the victim is identified as Riley Cuskey, not Joey. The episode shows sustained community harassment (fliers, restraining order he has against Sonia) plus detective workplace confrontation.

quote_or_scene: Scott Heston initially tells detectives: 'Me, Riley, and Jake... He was a friend of Riley's from camp... He said we had to get out of there. I told him it was an accident... He said he would kill me if I told.' Detectives quickly determine this is false: 'Both fighters were bleeding. So DNA will tell us who the other guy was.' Scott then admits it was him wearing the mask.
notes: Scott fabricates 'Jake' as the masked fighter who killed Riley. However, this accusation remains contained to the interrogation room with no public exposure or consequences to any real person named Jake. Included for completeness but has minimal harm (severity 1, police_only exposure). Detectives quickly see through the lie via forensic logic.

police_conduct_quote: You execute her, Willis? / This is a mistake! / You're a lock for this. / And your sick obsession with an avatar made you kidnap its creator last night.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Willis at his residence: 'All right, Tobin, where'd you stay the girl?' Willis protests: 'What girl?' They accuse him based on avatar account and credit card records. Willis explains someone stole his card. Detectives arrest him and search his apartment and computer. He provides alibi: 'Last night? I was at Shea Stadium.' Video evidence from Jumbotron at 11:30pm confirms alibi. Computer scan by Taru shows 'clean bill of health.'
tags: wrong_ID; db_error; arrested; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; coerced_confession
notes: Willis was accused because Cooper stole his credit card information to create the 'Wit Billions' avatar account under Willis's name. Detectives confronted him at home, arrested him, searched his computer and apartment. He was cleared when alibi verified via stadium Jumbotron footage and computer showed no evidence. No apology shown. Severity 3 due to arrest and home search.

police_conduct_quote: Last chance, Smarty. Where is she? / You kidnapped an innocent girl! You're out of your mind. / You're nuts.
quote_or_scene: Detectives enter Cooper's Rare Books store where Nestor works. Boss Mr. Cooper is present. Detective: 'We're looking for Nestor Buchanan.' They confront Nestor at his computer in front of his employer: 'Nestor. Police. Stand up.' They arrest him: 'Nestor Buchanan, you're under arrest for the kidnapping of Rachel McGarrett.' Mr. Cooper witnesses entire arrest. Later proven innocent when Cooper (his boss) is revealed as the actual perpetrator who set him up.
notes: Nestor was accused as Willis's 'partner' based on avatar interaction data showing his 'Smarty Culottes' avatar meeting frequently with the 'Wit Billions' avatar (which was actually Cooper, not Willis). Arrested at his workplace in front of his boss. Later revealed his boss Julian Cooper was the actual perpetrator who framed both Willis and Nestor. Severity 3 due to public workplace arrest in front of employer.

police_conduct_quote: Maybe you got into a fight, huh? Get in fight, get out of hand, you kill her, dump her body... / Then you had to get rid of Kristi because she could finger you... / Maybe the precinct will jog your memory.
quote_or_scene: Dan claims medical condition (arousal parasomnia/sexsomnia): 'I did it in my sleep... I have this condition.' Attorney confirms: 'He had sexual intercourse with Kristi McGarrett while he was asleep... a real disorder.' ADA Novak: 'We can't charge him with the rape...
