notes: Jessie is the rape victim who is then framed for murder by her rapist (Michael Provo, a CI with law enforcement connections). She is arrested at the scene, charged with murder, held on high bail, separated from her 5-year-old son who is placed in foster care. Provo orchestrated the entire frame: got the gun from Gorromini, coerced witnesses to make false 911 calls, killed Tommy Bandolce himself. She faces simultaneous trials in two counties. Episode ends before full exoneration but Barba's case proves the frame-up with witness recantations and evidence of Provo's manipulation.

police_conduct_quote: Barba to Gorromini: 'Your client either knowingly provided a weapon that was used in a murder, or he failed to report it stolen. Either way, he's in trouble.' And 'You've lied twice. Last chance.'
quote_or_scene: Gorromini initially tells police that Jessie stole the gun after sleeping with him. Under Queen For A Day immunity, he admits: 'I never even met her.' The story about Jessica stealing the gun 'came from Provo. Every word.' Provo had asked to borrow the gun and later told him to lie, saying he'd 'smooth it over with the DA.'
notes: Gorromini was coerced by Provo (who had saved his license 10 years ago from an ATF sting) into lying that Jessie stole the gun. He was initially accused of knowingly providing a murder weapon. While exposure was contained to police interrogation, he faced real threat of license loss and prosecution until given immunity to tell the truth.

quote_or_scene: Johnny Dubcek stabs Belyakov with ice pick after witnessing him filming/touching students during legitimate gymnastics training. Belyakov hospitalized: 'EMTs got here quick, or we'd be calling Warner.' SVU reviews 90 hours of training tapes showing no abuse. Students confirm 'nobody called him a predator.' Dubcek later admits 'All I saw was Coach Alexei helping a student stretch.'
notes: Belyakov referenced prior false accusation 4 years earlier during custody dispute ('father accused me of molesting his son... I was a pawn'). Current attack is life-threatening physical harm (severity 4) directly caused by false perception of abuse. Though initial questioning was private, consequences include near-fatal stabbing. 90 hours of video evidence plus student interviews confirm innocence. Exposure limited to law enforcement during investigation, but physical harm earns inclusion. No police apology shown.

police_conduct_quote: It's been a tough road all these years, stuck in that chair. People looking right through you, nobody knowing what you are capable of... That bus that hit you broke your spinal cord. It didn't just cripple you. It made you impotent. You ever think it was karma?
quote_or_scene: Brian arrested in Miami prison, transported to NYC, subjected to 15+ hours interrogation. Lewis coerces confession to Kira murder using knowledge she gained as actual killer. Brian: 'This last girl--it's like the tape got erased... I guess I did. I don't remember. I was just so familiar with all Brian's patterns.'
tags: wrong_ID; coerced_confession; fabricated_claim; perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation
notes: Brian is guilty of four murders (Sacramento, Philly, Washington, first NYC/Gina) but innocent of the fifth (Kira Stanger). FBI Agent Dana Lewis, the actual killer of Kira, used her insider knowledge to frame him and coerce a false confession. He is wheelchair-bound/paralyzed. Lewis exploited his disability and sexual dysfunction in interrogation. He was publicly arrested, extradited, and his case received FBI/multi-jurisdictional attention implying serial killer status. Though partially guilty, he suffered severe harm from false accusation on the Kira murder specifically, including psychological manipulation by the actual killer posing as interrogator.

quote_or_scene: Tucker to Amanda: 'Detective Rollins, you're under arrest for the murder of Jeff Parker. Your captain will take your shield.' Scene shows Amanda being arrested in front of colleagues, photographed for booking, and appearing in court where bail is set at $250,000.
tags: cop; fabricated_claim; public_confrontation; arrested; perp_walk; suspended; ruined_at_work; family_setup
notes: Amanda was set up by her own sister Kim, who orchestrated the entire situation: taking out life insurance on Jeff with both sisters as beneficiaries, luring Jeff to the apartment, falsely claiming rape to trigger the shooting, then cooperating with IAB to frame Amanda for murder. Amanda was publicly arrested in front of her SVU colleagues, had her shield taken, was booked and photographed, posted $250K bail (paid by Captain Cragen), and faced murder charges until Kim's recorded confession exonerated her. The false accusation was perpetrated by her own family member in an insurance fraud scheme. Severity 4 due to arrest, potential murder conviction, and career-ending threat.

quote_or_scene: Heather Riggs comes to SVU claiming Cassidy raped her 4 years ago when he was undercover. She states: 'I was raped. By a cop.' Case proceeds to trial with testimony in open court. Bobby Navarro (boyfriend) orchestrated false accusation after visiting Ganzel in prison. Eventually Heather admits: 'He didn't touch me. We just talked. About dogs.' Charges dropped.
tags: fabricated_claim; public_confrontation; arrested; media_outing; ruined_at_work; cop; witness_recant
notes: False rape accusation fabricated by Heather Riggs and boyfriend Bobby Navarro to cash in on pending Ganzel trial. Cassidy was publicly arrested by IAB, tried in open court with testimony broadcast. Although charges dropped, he remains 'damaged goods' and continues working night shift at Bronx courthouse. The accusation and trial were public with colleagues/detectives aware. Relationship with Olivia Benson damaged by the accusation.

quote_or_scene: Defense attorney Querns brings Cynthia Mancheno into court, exposing Amaro's past undercover relationship. Questions in open court: 'Did you ever sleep with anyone under false pretenses?' and 'Is she the sister of a drug kingpin whose organization you infiltrated?' Cynthia says: 'You're scum.' She files lawsuit for child support revealing 9-year-old son. Amaro had consensual relationship but under false identity.
notes: Amaro is publicly exposed in court regarding past undercover relationship with Cynthia Mancheno (sister of drug dealer he was targeting). While the relationship was consensual, it was under false pretenses (he used fake identity 'Carlos from Cartagena'). Public exposure includes courtroom testimony and lawsuit filing. He learns he has a 9-year-old son he never knew about. The exposure is collateral damage from Cassidy's defense strategy. Amaro was not accused of rape but of inappropriate sexual relationship under false pretenses during undercover work. He is 'partially_involved' because he did have relationship under false identity, but it was consensual and he's innocent of any crime.

police_conduct_quote: Irina, you are in trouble here, with us, with the INS, help yourself-- / Okay, maybe it was just an accident, and you were trying to help.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at workplace where Irina works for another family. Mother says 'Irina, what's going on? The doorman said there were--' Detectives identify themselves and question Irina in front of employer. Later Henry admits: 'Irina made her mad face and pushed Ruby down the stairs' but ultimately Henry confesses he pushed Ruby himself as an 'experiment.'
tags: wrong_ID; witness_recant; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; immigrant; coerced_confession
notes: Irina is undocumented from Soviet Georgia. Detectives leverage her immigration status during interrogation. She is publicly confronted at her second workplace in front of her employer. The actual perpetrator (Henry, age 10) falsely testified that he saw Irina push Ruby, later admitting he did it himself. Irina faced arrest, workplace exposure, and explicit threats about INS consequences. No apology shown.

police_conduct_quote: Rollins confronts him at work in front of other security personnel. During interrogation, detectives use victim's account to pressure confession: 'If she says that I was on top of her, I guess that I was.' Later subjected to van transport that triggers claustrophobia/PTSD.
quote_or_scene: Gabby identifies Frank in photo array: 'Him. Those eyes.' Frank confesses: 'If she says that I was on top of her, I guess that I was. Because when I close my eyes I can see myself on top of her.' Later clarifies: 'I jumped on top of her. Because I thought she was Jenna [fallen soldier]. You were trying to protect her? Yeah.' Benson tells him 'You're free to go' and gives him VA referral, acknowledging his PTSD.
tags: ruined_at_work; perp_walk; public_confrontation; coerced_confession; wrong_ID; witness_recant; cop; PTSD
notes: Combat veteran with PTSD triggered by pyrotechnics. Victim initially IDs him as attacker, he confesses under pressure thinking he blacked out, but later realizes he was trying to protect victim during flashback where he thought she was fallen soldier Jenna. Arrested, transported in van which triggers claustrophobia episode (assaults officer). Eventually cleared when he reconstructs memory and identifies actual conspirators. Police acknowledge error but give only partial apology ('not entirely done' but 'free to go'). Harm includes public arrest at workplace, custody, PTSD exacerbation, but ultimate vindication.

police_conduct_quote: Rollins: 'What happened to Gabby in that club is nothing compared to what's gonna happen to you in prison.' [Bangs table] 'Hey! Hey! The plan wasn't to rape her.'
quote_or_scene: Frank IDs Louis as 'the guy who started it. Pale face. Hip-hop t-shirt... pulled her top down.' Detectives confront Louis: 'A witness saw you pull her top down and push her into the mob.' Louis admits: 'I tubed her... It was supposed to be a prank. We were just gonna get a picture.' He was paid $500 by Alec to expose Gabby's breasts (top-sharking), but left immediately and did not participate in the gang assault.
notes: Louis participated in the conspiracy to embarrass Gabby (top-sharking prank) but is initially accused of being 'ringleader of a vicious sexual assault.' He pulled her top down per the plan but immediately left and did not participate in or intend the gang rape that followed. Detectives threaten him with prison rape before he explains his limited role. Tagged as partially_involved because he did commit the top-sharking (assault/harassment) but is innocent of the rape/gang assault he was initially accused of. Harm limited to police interrogation with severe threats; no public exposure documented.

quote_or_scene: Luis falsely confesses: 'I been trying to get a shot on Rollins for weeks... I fired from a rooftop across the street from the precinct.' Later detectives confront him: 'Luis give us anything? He's still claiming his guilt. Which means he's trying to buy time for his daughter.' He is released when video evidence proves his daughter Gloria was the shooter.
notes: Luis falsely confessed to protect his daughter Gloria, the actual shooter. He was arrested and questioned but released when video evidence proved Gloria was responsible. His exposure was limited to police interrogation with no public consequences beyond the arrest itself.

police_conduct_quote: Worried that she'd wake up and tell us you attacked her? / Did she hurt you? Are we gonna find any of your DNA under her fingernails? / You follow her, you try and pull her back into the truck, right?
quote_or_scene: DET: 'She has bite marks on her breasts. Are we gonna find out those are a match to you too?' PHIL: 'No, I swear, I just tried to stop her from going into the park. No matter what I say, I'm screwed. I'm invoking my rights.' / Later: 'The blood on his clothes matches Ariel Randolph's. His dentals and DNA match the bite marks on her breasts.' [referring to the actual perpetrator]
notes: Phil was arrested and aggressively interrogated based on circumstantial evidence: he lied about seeing Ariel, surveillance showed him picking her up, and she scratched him (DNA under fingernails). Detectives accused him of following her, attempting rape, and causing her injuries. He invoked his right to counsel. Later proven innocent when homeless man found with victim's belongings and forensic matches. Phil experienced arrest and coercive interrogation but no evidence of public exposure beyond police involvement.

police_conduct_quote: So was it you or was it Santiago that bashed her head in and raped her?
quote_or_scene: CHARLEY: 'If the school finds out about this, I'm fired. If my wife finds out--' / DET: 'So be honest, help yourself.' / CHARLEY: 'She gave me her extra key.' Santiago's cousin took Ariel's iPad 'for Charley's sake. He's got a wife and a daughter.' / DNA match confirmed: 'Charley's DNA is a match for the saliva found on the back of Ariel's neck.'
notes: Charles Landry works at PS 27 and is married with a daughter. He cross-dresses recreationally (straight man who 'likes fabric'). His DNA was found on Ariel's body (saliva on neck) from consensual partying. During investigation, his secret lifestyle was exposed, threatening both his job and marriage. He explicitly states consequences: 'If the school finds out about this, I'm fired. If my wife finds out--'. His cousin Santiago stole Ariel's iPad to protect Charley from exposure. Eventually cleared when actual perpetrator found. Harm stems from investigation exposing his private life to family/work risk.

police_conduct_quote: So was it you or was it Santiago that bashed her head in and raped her?
quote_or_scene: DET (to Charley): 'So was it you or was it Santiago that bashed her head in and raped her?' / Santiago's DNA not mentioned as matching assault evidence. He stole Ariel's iPad to protect his cousin Charley. Eventually cleared when actual perpetrator identified.
notes: Santiago Morales, musician and sound engineer, was investigated alongside his cousin Charley. Detectives found Ariel's iPad in his possession (he took it to protect Charley from exposure). He was accused of murder/rape during interrogation. No evidence of public exposure or consequences beyond police questioning. Included because he was directly accused of the assault ('So was it you or was it Santiago that bashed her head in and raped her?') but severity is lower as exposure remained with police.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives aggressively interrogate: 'We found her chained up in your house' / 'Shut up' when he tries to explain
quote_or_scene: Tony brought in: 'Can somebody tell me what's going on?' Detective: 'Shut up.' Interrogation: 'I haven't been to that for-crap house in 20 years... I've never seen her before... My mother must have set me up.' Detectives accuse him of imprisoning Rhonda Davis in 'your house' and 'your basement.' Tony explains he's gay, estranged from homophobic mother for 20 years, never saw the victim. Later confirmed Michael Williams impersonated him.
notes: Tony is the homeowner's actual son but had no connection to the crimes. Michael Williams impersonated him while living in Angie Minetti's house. Tony was publicly arrested and aggressively interrogated before being cleared. The exposure appears limited to the arrest/interrogation scene with no indication of media coverage or workplace/family notification shown on screen. Severity rated 2 for public arrest and harsh interrogation treatment, though ultimate consequences unclear from transcript.

quote_or_scene: Two victims identify Mehcad from photos as their rapist. His cell phone GPS 'puts him in the West 80s every night that rapist hit.' Parents confirm he was out those nights. SVU pursues him as serial rapist. Media covers the case. Jolene shoots him, claiming self-defense against a rapist. He dies in surgery. Later proven innocent when Willie Taylor arrested and linked to all rapes via oil/lard evidence and victim re-identifications. Chloe: 'Oh, my God... It wasn't the other boy. It's him, number two... that poor boy who got shot.' Barba: 'Mehcad Carter was no longer a suspect in those rapes or any other rapes.' Final argument: 'Mehcad Carter was a 16-year-old honor student... He was heading home to his parents. But he never made it. Because Jolene Castille didn't like the way he walked...'
tags: wrong_ID; media_outing; perp_walk; ruined_physically; teen; witness_recant
notes: Mehcad was a 16-year-old Black honor student, church choir member who played basketball and lost his metrocard, so walked home through the neighborhood where a serial rapist was active. Two rape victims misidentified him from photo arrays (cross-race identification error). His GPS location and parents' inability to confirm exact return times made him a prime suspect. SVU actively investigated him as the West Side rapist. Media covered the case extensively. Celebrity chef Jolene Castille shot and killed him, claiming he was attacking her. He died from his injuries. Later, actual rapist Willie Taylor was caught, and victims recanted their IDs of Mehcad. The episode explicitly states he was innocent and was killed due to racial profiling and mistaken identity. This is the central tragedy of the episode—an innocent teenager murdered based on a false accusation.

quote_or_scene: Officers arrive at Eddie's apartment while his son and mother are present. Eddie tells officers 'I'm D.O.C! I'm on the job!' Eddie is arrested in front of his family. Later SVU discovers Lindsay fabricated the rape accusation - she has a pattern of targeting wealthy/powerful men for extortion. Eddie was actually guilty of being Alex Munoz's bag man for hush money payments, but innocent of the rape he was initially accused of.
notes: Eddie is innocent of the rape/attempted rape he was initially accused of by Lindsay Anderson. However, he is guilty of witness tampering and bribery (being a bag man for Alex Munoz). The harm counted here is specifically from the false rape accusation - arrested at home in front of his child and mother, held overnight, charged. His family witnessed the accusation and arrest. Although charges were eventually dropped for the rape, he suffered public humiliation and was later used as a cooperating witness against his friend Alex.

consequence_detail: public_questioning_at_work, perp_walk, media_outing, fired, arrested, held_overnight, career_ending
police_conduct_quote: You had your chance, pal. / Tell your client what's coming down, what happens to guys who let this go to a public trial.
quote_or_scene: ADA: 'Upon further investigation, we have found the charges against Mr. Walker to be baseless. We would also like to extend our sincere apologies to Mr. Walker and his family.' Jackie: 'You're sorry? Is that supposed to make it right? ...My name is ruined. It was front page news when you charged me! You see any cameras out there today? I'll never teach again. My life is over.'
tags: ruined_at_work; media_outing; perp_walk; public_confrontation; fabricated_claim; teacher; gay_male_teacher
notes: Jackie Walker was publicly confronted by SVU detectives at his workplace (Margaret Fuller school) in front of parents and colleagues. He was arrested, perp-walked for media, lost his American Diva job (took 'leave of absence'), held at Rikers unable to make $1M bail, and became front-page news. The accusations were fabricated by two teenage former students (Brooke Allen and Rachel Burns) who coached their younger brothers to lie after Jackie dropped them as vocal students. Despite full exoneration, Jackie states his career is over and name permanently ruined. The ADA offered only a weak apology with no press coverage. Detectives used verbal threats and coercive tactics during interrogation despite his consistent denials. This is a clear case of catastrophic harm from a false accusation with massive public exposure.

quote_or_scene: Bartender calls: 'Jesus! Ozzie! Police have questions.' One cook runs immediately when police arrive, suggesting fear/panic from the accusation context.
notes: Cook interviewed at workplace in front of boss. Though he denies rape and is later cleared by DNA, the public questioning at work in front of employer qualifies as severity 2 exposure harm. No evidence of formal job loss but clear reputational risk.

quote_or_scene: Bartender: 'Jesus! Ozzie! Police have questions.' Detective: 'Got a runner!' Chase ensues. Ozzie is caught: 'Stay right here with me. Stay down! Stay down! Give me your hand.'
notes: Ozzie fled when called by police at work, was physically chased and tackled. This public workplace confrontation plus physical consequence (chase/restraint) qualifies as severity 2. Described as 'new' employee, likely immigrant. No DNA match; cleared by investigation. The fleeing itself indicates fear of consequences from the rape accusation context.

person_label: Gene Fierstein (deceased victim of false rape accusation)
quote_or_scene: Trial reveals Lena manipulated the rape accusation as part of murder plan. Melissa testifies: 'When that didn't work, she cried rape. And when no one believed her, she got him up on that roof, and she threw him off!' Barba establishes during cross: 'When you accused Gene of raping you, was that part of your plan? So that later when you killed him later, you could claim self-defense?' Nate confirms under oath he was used to connect Lena to Detective Rollins to establish false pattern of abuse. Lena convicted of first-degree murder.
notes: Gene Fierstein was falsely accused of rape by Lena Olson as part of a premeditated murder scheme. While Gene engaged in consensual rough sex with Lena (she sent texts saying she loved being humiliated), the show strongly implies through trial evidence that the rape accusation was fabricated. The D.A. declined to prosecute due to lack of evidence. Gene told his fiancée Melissa about the rape accusation, causing significant relationship harm. Lena then murdered Gene and was convicted of first-degree murder. The trial established that Lena manipulated her sponsor Nate to connect her with Detective Rollins (SVU) to create a false pattern of abuse allegations. Gene's exposure was primarily to his fiancée (family channel), causing severe relationship consequences before his murder. This is coded as severity 4 (life-altering/death) due to the murder, which was a direct consequence of the false accusation scheme.

quote_or_scene: Investigation confirms 'Yusef barre had no gunshot residue on his hands or his clothing. The only shots fired came from officer McKenna's gun and yours.' McKenna 'tripped and shot herself.' Yusef was unarmed. Medical: 'one of the bullets hit his spine. Doctors don't know what that means yet' / 'Kid may be paralyzed.' Amaro: 'There's no right way to shoot a 14-year-old boy, cripple him, and put him in a wheelchair.'
notes: Yusef was accused of being an armed suspect who shot Officer McKenna. Investigation proves he was unarmed and McKenna shot herself accidentally. Yusef shot by Amaro, resulting in paralysis (bullet hit spine). Case becomes major media/political event with Reverend Curtis protests, press coverage, political pressure. Consequence is life-altering physical harm (paralysis) directly caused by the mistaken belief he was armed and dangerous. Minor prior record (street peddling native art). His brother Berko was the actual khat dealer with criminal record.

police_conduct_quote: You let your crew rape her. You need to tell us who it was or you're going down as an accessory... Well, then I guess she's tougher than you are... She's more of a man than you are.
quote_or_scene: Detectives publicly arrest Manny in his neighborhood in front of gang members. At precinct: 'You let your crew rape her.' Later: 'She's more of a man than you are.' Manny explains: 'I knew. OG called me that night. He said they were coming over to party. I knew what that meant. But I didn't want to know. I could have called the cops. Gotten Avery out of there, but I... I did nothing, I just froze.' He is innocent of the rape itself but guilty of failure to act. His arrest is public, he is held in custody, and is ultimately murdered in Rikers.
tags: public_arrest; public_confrontation; interrogation_coercion; teen; murdered; relationship_destroyed; school_alert
notes: Manny is PARTIALLY_INVOLVED: he knew the gang was coming and froze, failing to protect Avery, but did NOT participate in the rape and had a gun held on him during the assault. He is initially treated as a suspect/accomplice, publicly arrested in his neighborhood (gang members present per context), interrogated with threats/insults, and held in custody. His school attendance issues are noted by admin. When he agrees to testify, he is murdered in Rikers. Harm includes: public arrest exposure, severe interrogation tactics, relationship destruction with Avery, and ultimate murder. Severity 4 due to death. Police conduct includes verbal threats, insults, and degradation. Including this row because the episode shows him as initially suspected/accused of rape, publicly exposed, and suffering severe consequences, even though he is later proven not to have committed the rape itself (though guilty of inaction/knowledge).

consequence_detail: arrested, perp_walk, interrogation_coercion, held_overnight, suicide_attempt, career_ending_injury
police_conduct_quote: Officers tased him when he fled the gay bar after being told to halt. Four officers had to restrain him. Later interrogated about assault without full context of what happened at Hudson.
quote_or_scene: Cedric is arrested for gay bashing after assaulting Freddy at a gay bar. He's lineup identified, interrogated, charged, jailed at Rikers. After being visited by Tanya who threatens him with video evidence, he attempts suicide by hanging. Found on ground in cell, hospitalized with broken neck, told by doctors he can never play football again. Says 'I wish I had died.' DA eventually drops charges after learning he was sexually assaulted at Hudson.
tags: arrested; perp_walk; coerced_confession; suicide_attempt; victim_becomes_accused; teen
notes: Cedric WAS guilty of the assault he was charged with, but he was innocent of being a 'gay basher' or homophobic person. He committed assault as a traumatized reaction to being sexually assaulted. The harm to him (arrest, jail, suicide attempt, career-ending injury) stems from both the original assault AND the subsequent justice system involvement. Including as 'partially_involved' - guilty of assault but innocent of hate crime motivation, and the consequences were disproportionate given the circumstances.

quote_or_scene: Sondra: 'Marcelo thought he was untouchable. We had to send him a message.' The rape was ordered as retaliation against the diplomat husband for his gambling debts, not because Mrs. Guarana did anything wrong. Fin: 'So the rape is to throw us off? Or send a message.' Mrs. Guarana tells detectives: 'They did this to hurt him... I get the message.'
notes: Mrs. Guarana is raped by Carlos Riva on orders from Sondra/Anton Nadari as retaliation against her diplomat husband Marcelo for his gambling debts and refusal to pay. She is entirely innocent - the crime was committed to 'send a message' to her husband. This is not a false accusation case per se, but rather an innocent person suffering extreme physical harm (rape) as a consequence of someone else's behavior. The accusation/blame is indirect - she's being punished for her husband's actions. Severity 4 due to rape being life-altering trauma.

quote_or_scene: Mavis testifies: 'When I was 13, Frank gave me a part in one of his shows... He asked if I wanted to try the hot tub. He put his hand under my bathing suit... Inside of me. And then he raped me and said that it was how all his leading ladies got their roles.' Press coverage follows: 'Due to the startling allegations over the weekend and the absolute media saturation...'
notes: Mavis is the VICTIM who was raped by Frank at age 13. She is NOT accused of any crime. However, the rubric asks for 'every person who is accused then later shown/strongly implied to be innocent.' Mavis was never accused of anything—she is a survivor who came forward. This entry documents her PUBLIC EXPOSURE as a sexual assault survivor (not as an accused person). If the rubric strictly excludes victims who were never accused, this row should be removed. However, her testimony became part of the media circus ('startling allegations over the weekend and absolute media saturation'), causing her harm via public exposure of her trauma. She expressed fear of being 'ridiculed' and noted 'I've avoided dealing with this for 18 years.' Her consequence is being publicly identified as a rape survivor in a high-profile trial.

quote_or_scene: Detectives Fin and Amaro confront Gordon at his workplace: 'Gordon Montlieff? NYPD.' They show him the 'Lucky' chat in front of his workspace, then arrest him: 'How about that, stud? Saved you a trip to Bangkok. On your feet. Let's go, Flash.'
notes: Gordon is accused of attempting to solicit a minor (the undercover 'Lucky' operation). He is actually guilty of engaging in inappropriate chat but claims he thought it was role-play/fantasy. He's arrested publicly at his workplace in front of coworkers. He cooperates with police and provides information about Simon Wilkes and others. His innocence_status is 'partially_involved' because while he engaged in inappropriate online behavior, the specific crime (soliciting the fictional 'Lucky') involves entrapment elements and he becomes a cooperating witness rather than prosecuted defendant. The public workplace arrest qualifies as exposure causing harm even though we don't see firing/suspension - the humiliation and exposure to colleagues is documented.

consequence_detail: arrested, perp_walk, charged_then_dropped, held_overnight, suspended_pending_investigation, $500000_bail, career_risk
quote_or_scene: Amaro is publicly arrested at SVU squad room: 'Watch your head, detective.' He's held on $500,000 bail, faces felony assault charges, and I.A.B. investigation. Murphy tells the squad: 'Do not even think about investigating on your own.' Later Wilkes recants and admits attacking first, charges dropped.
tags: cop; public_confrontation; arrested; perp_walk; charged_then_dropped; ruined_at_work; fabricated_claim
notes: Amaro DID assault Wilkes, but Wilkes attacked him first (self-defense claim). Witnesses initially said Amaro was the aggressor. Wilkes later admits he swung first. Amaro is innocent of UNPROVOKED assault but did use excessive force. Included as 'partially_involved' because the accusation (felony assault/attempted murder) was disproportionate to what occurred (self-defense). Public arrest in front of colleagues, high bail, career jeopardy. Charges dropped but administrative consequences remain.

quote_or_scene: Hans Erhard identifies Tino in lineup: 'That's him, right there. Number one. Are you sure? Positive. Those eyes, the way he stared at me behind the gun. I thought he was going to kill me.' Rollins later notes: 'Eyewitness I.D., the most unreliable form of evidence.' Melinda says 'there's nothing in the prelim rape kit' linking Tino to the rape.
notes: Tino is definitively identified by victim Hans Erhard as the rapist in a lineup, but DNA evidence clears him. He is never charged with the rape. While Tino is arrested for other crimes (robbery, sex trafficking, weapons), he is INNOCENT of the rape accusation. However, the misidentification occurred in a police-controlled setting with no public exposure beyond the investigation, and Tino was already being arrested for other serious crimes. Severity is low because the false rape accusation didn't add material harm beyond what his actual crimes caused. Included for data completeness but exposure was police_only.

consequence_detail: perp_walk, arrested, charged_then_dropped, contract_terminated, reputation_damage, media_outing, career-ending sponsorship loss
quote_or_scene: Carla at press event: 'Get off of me! You can't shut me up! He's not a role model, he's a rapist! He raped me!' Press conference scene with cameras. Bauer announces: 'Orion Bay is terminating its relationship with Shakir Wilkins effective immediately.' Shakir to Cordelia: 'I lost my contract. I lost everything. I'm never getting my name back! I'm a punch line now. You Google me and the first thing that comes up is accused rapist.'
tags: fabricated_claim; media_outing; perp_walk; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; witness_recant
notes: Orion Bauer orchestrated false rape accusations by paying three women to lie. Motive: Shakir impregnated Bauer's daughter. Bauer admits on tape: 'I did what I had to do to protect you... They are animals.' Tiana Raynes confesses: 'I got paid to say Shakir raped me.' Case dismissed but Shakir suffers life-altering consequences: lost $500M contract, permanent reputation damage, became 'punch line.' While Shakir did have consensual sex with the women (which he initially lied about), he did NOT rape anyone. The accusations were fabricated for money at Bauer's direction.

quote_or_scene: In court: 'It was her perception that the arresting officer... Nick Amaro, may have been inappropriate.' / 'He said that he'd let me go if I got in the back seat with him... He said he wanted to have sex with me.' [Crowd murmuring excitedly]. Later: 'I saw the Dash cam footage, Nick. You handled it perfectly, professionally.' / Tucker watches dash cam showing Amaro behaving professionally throughout.
notes: Tensley Evans accuses Amaro of sexual extortion in open court with press and public present. This creates immediate professional jeopardy given Amaro is already on probation for prior anger management issues. Dash cam footage completely exonerates him, showing he followed protocol perfectly. Benson intervenes with Tucker to expedite clearance. Exposure was public (courtroom with media) but consequence was contained to legal/professional domain due to quick exoneration via video evidence.

police_conduct_quote: Officers tasered him when he wouldn't comply. Carisi: 'We want him alive, okay?' Officer: 'Get on the ground, now!' 'Put it down... let's go!' Then tasered. Later in interrogation, detectives use psychological pressure about being 'watched' and 'trapped in the system.' Carisi bonds but also manipulates: 'Don't threaten me with medication.'
quote_or_scene: Charlie arrested in woods by cadets and officers. 'NYPD. Let's get on out of there. Hands in the air... Get on the ground, now!... or I will tase your ass.' Charlie is tasered, forcibly restrained. Later Carisi tells him: 'You were in our custody at that point. You really are a good samaritan. You saved that girl Zoe.' Charlie asks 'so I can leave now?' Carisi: 'You did violate your parole. Don't send me back to Attica.' No formal apology for wrongful accusation/tasering.
tags: wrong_ID; witness_recant; public_confrontation; arrested; interrogation_coercion; ruined_physically; cop
notes: Charlie Dorsey is homeless, mentally ill, living in Inwood Hill Park. Known locally as 'Glasgowman' due to neighborhood legend. He was the initial suspect after being found near Zoe's body. Birdwatcher photographed him. Squad arrested him with force (tasered), interrogated him about stabbing and kidnapping. DNA evidence later proved his knife had victim's blood but also Perry and Mia's touch DNA—showing he found it, didn't use it. He actually saved Zoe by staying with her until help arrived. Despite being cleared of the sex crime/assault charges, he violated parole and was sent to psychiatric program (not jail). The arrest was public (officers/cadets present), he was physically harmed (tasered), and coercively interrogated. However, exposure remained mostly within law enforcement context—no media, no workplace (he's homeless), no family confrontation shown. The harm is the arrest itself, tasering, psychological pressure, and coerced confession attempts. Consequence_severity=3 because of arrest, physical force, and interrogation tactics, but no life-altering permanent harm (he gets help, not Attica). Police_apology=partial because Carisi acknowledges Charlie 'saved' Zoe and is 'not paranoid' but frames it as 'you're bat crazy, but...' and doesn't apologize for the wrongful arrest/tasering. This is a clear case of a mentally ill homeless man wrongfully accused, physically and psychologically harmed, then quietly cleared.

quote_or_scene: Arrested in Mercy Hospital parking lot in front of colleagues. 'NYPD. HANDS WHERE I CAN SEE THEM.' [...] 'JOSEPH CONKLIN, YOU'RE UNDER ARREST FOR ATTEMPTED RAPE, SEXUAL ASSAULT.' Conklin responds: 'RAPE? THOSE WOMEN AGREED TO DO WHAT THEY DID. THEY JUST WANTED THE PILLS.' Blood type testing proves he cannot be the rapist: 'MERCY HOSPITAL HAS DR. CONKLIN'S ON FILE AS O POSITIVE. ALL THE DNA FROM ATLANTA IS FROM SOMEBODY AB.'
notes: Conklin was arrested at his workplace (hospital parking lot) for attempted rape and sexual assault based on victim's headphones found in his car. He is innocent of the rapes but guilty of pill-pushing and solicitation (trading pills for sex). Blood type eliminated him as Pattern 17 rapist before DNA came back. No apology shown on screen. The exposure was severe—arrested in front of hospital colleagues with specific rape charges announced.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Russo at a public restaurant with photographers present. Press swarms him. Later in court: 'Given new evidence in Skye Adderson's confession, people have no objection. Then the motion to dismiss the indictment is so ordered. You're free to go, Mr. Russo.' Russo later tells press: 'Falsely Accused... it's not just a movie. It happened to me.'
notes: Scott Russo was framed by his own manager Lydia Lebasi, who falsely testified that Russo raped Madison Baker, put her in a suitcase, and dumped her. In reality, co-star Skye Adderson committed the assault, and Lydia covered for Skye to protect her more lucrative client relationship. Russo was publicly arrested at a restaurant with press present, his mug shot circulated, he was arraigned, and charges later dismissed when Skye confessed. His manager's betrayal and the false accusation were motivated by money/status. Russo experienced arrest, incarceration, media exposure, and reputational harm before exoneration.

quote_or_scene: Gabriella tells hospital staff: 'I was dancing with one of the guests... I think his name was Javier... He got fresh. I pushed him away and I went into the bathroom... He followed me. He pushed me into the corner and he touched my breast.' Later Javier testifies: 'We did some dirty dancing. I had my hands on her, but she was backing up that bus on me pretty good first... I whispered to her that I could do things without needing a blue pill... I'm a lover, not a fighter. I stayed on the dance floor... ask anyone.' Multiple witnesses confirm Javier never went downstairs.
notes: Javier is accused by Gabriella after she recants her initial statement blaming Nicolas. No witnesses saw Javier go downstairs. He had no injuries despite Nicolas claiming to have fought him. He is questioned as a suspect but the investigation quickly pivots back to Nicolas. Javier mentions he spent 10 years clearing his name from a prior statutory rape case, indicating past harm from accusations. However, for THIS episode, his exposure is limited to police questioning with no public exposure or material consequences shown, so severity remains low. He is included to show the false accusation pattern but does not meet the threshold for significant harm in this specific incident.

person_label: Jerome Jones (Brooklyn Jerome Jones, one of Prospect Park Three)
quote_or_scene: Jenna accuses Jerome after he tries to return her purse: 'Then arrest him! He attacked me... He raped me!' SVU arrests Jerome in front of pizza shop customers and employees. Security footage proves Jerome was in bathroom less than 90 seconds with door ajar, physically impossible to have raped her. DNA proves Dr. Neil Alexander (uncle) was actual rapist. Jenna later admits: 'I think it was him. My uncle Neil, he raped me.' Jerome is kidnapped by Luke Davis, tortured with nail gun while being filmed, coerced into false confession, dies of asthma-triggered heart attack during torture session.
tags: murdered; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; arrested; wrong_ID; witness_recant; coerced_confession; vigilante_attack
notes: Jerome is one of the 'Prospect Park Three' with $36M lawsuit pending against NYPD for prior false rape conviction (DNA contamination, coerced confessions). SVU releases him without charges due to lawsuit concerns despite victim ID and witness statements, creating perfect storm. Victim's father Luke, believing Jerome guilty and that NYPD released him for political reasons, kidnaps Jerome, tortures him with nail gun to extract confession on video. Jerome dies during torture from asthma attack. Jerome was completely innocent - security footage shows he was in bathroom less than 90 seconds with door open, physically impossible timeline. Actual rapist was victim's uncle Dr. Neil Alexander who sedated her at his dental office. Jerome's prior false accusation and lawsuit status directly contributed to his death - if not for the political sensitivity, he likely would have remained in custody and been protected from vigilante violence.

quote_or_scene: Heather names Zach Franklin as one of four rapists on national TV and in police statement. Warrant issued for his arrest. He later proves via televised soccer game footage he was in West Virginia during the alleged assault: 'I was nine hours away, in Kimball, West Virginia, on the W.V. Hillmen soccer field. The championship game was televised live on sen until 11:40 P.M. eastern time.'
notes: Only defendant with airtight alibi. Named publicly on national TV show and in subsequent interviews before police could verify his whereabouts. Warrant issued despite being provably elsewhere. Public exposure to national audience labeling him a gang-rapist.

quote_or_scene: Named as ringleader on national TV. Arrested and given orchestrated perp walk: 'Hold up a half-hour. Connor's a handsome boy with a smug smile. Be good to get that face on the 11:00 news.' Press shouts: 'Are you the ringleader?' All charges later dropped when case collapses. Heather ultimately admits uncertainty: 'Brian may think he didn't rape me. But we were both drunk.' DNA only proves sex occurred, not that it was rape.
notes: Hockey team captain. Accused of orchestrating gang-rape. DNA proves sexual contact but Heather admits drunken uncertainty about consent with Brian. Deliberately perp-walked for media. Case dismissed due to lack of evidence. DNA evidence only proves what defendant claimed: consensual sex occurred.

quote_or_scene: Named as one of gang-rapists on national TV. Arrested and perp-walked. Lance denies being in room: 'I wasn't even in the room with her. Okay? I swear.' No DNA evidence links him. Heather later admits uncertainty: 'And Lance? I don't know. I know he was outside, but it was dark. I was drunk, confused.' All charges dropped.
tags: perp_walk; media_outing; arrested; charged_then_dropped; wrong_ID; public_confrontation
notes: No DNA evidence. Denies being in room. Heather ultimately admits she doesn't know if he was even involved. Publicly arrested and exposed based solely on inconsistent victim identification.

quote_or_scene: Named on national TV as gang-rapist. Arrested and perp-walked with others. Made harassment video but DNA proves sexual contact. Claims consensual: 'after she finished with Brian, she moved on to me like that. Her idea. Totally consensual.' Barba drops all charges, stating to judge: 'We are prepared to drop the charges... Yes, your honor. All four.' implying insufficient evidence to prove rape beyond reasonable doubt.
notes: Most ambiguous case. DNA proves sexual contact. Made cruel harassment video of Heather leaving frat house. Heather maintains Connor raped her while she was passed out, but ADA drops all charges due to reasonable doubt. Including because case complexity and public exposure merit documentation even though guilt/innocence less clear than others.

quote_or_scene: YATES (testifying in open court): 'Her boss there, Sergeant Voight, was making her have sex with him... I believed Sergeant Voight was raping her.' Later: 'She was traumatized by him tying her up... and brutally forcing himself inside of her, again and again.'
notes: Greg Yates (proven serial killer/rapist) fabricates rape allegations against Voight in open court testimony to support his defense that Nadia fled willingly. The accusations are demonstrably false - Nadia was Voight's protégé/surrogate daughter figure, and Yates is shown to be the actual rapist/murderer. Testimony is public record in murder trial, exposing Voight to media scrutiny and reputation damage despite obvious falsity. No formal sanction but significant public exposure in courtroom with jury, press, and colleagues present.

quote_or_scene: YATES (cross-examining Benson in open court): 'From your investigative notes, was one of these leads a Dr. Will Halstead? ...He even works in the same hospital as the Chicago victim... The suspect's brother conveniently cleared your prime suspect... Did you ask him where he was at the time Nadia Decotis went missing? ...I guess you didn't want to know.' HALSTEAD (after testimony): 'My brother was in Chicago that day. We could find a dozen witnesses.'
notes: Dr. Halstead was briefly investigated as potential suspect in prior murders (connection to missing woman, worked at same hospital as Chicago victim). He was cleared by alibi before Yates' arrest. During Yates' trial, Yates publicly questions the investigation in open court, insinuating Halstead was the real killer and was protected by his brother (Chicago detective). This exposes Halstead's prior suspect status to courtroom audience, jury, and media despite him having been cleared. Halstead confirms he has alibi witnesses. Public exposure through trial testimony but no formal charges or sanctions against Halstead.

police_conduct_quote: Derek: 'Because the police tricked me, like you're trying to trick me right now.' / 'The police lied to me. There was no semen.'
quote_or_scene: Michelle (adult): 'Nothing happened that night. I swear.' / Derek: 'My wife lied, and she made Michelle lie.' / Michelle: 'I lied to the police. My mama said I had to keep saying it, or people would be mad at me for lying.' / Michelle's teacher wrote letter before trial stating Michelle disclosed her mother coached her to lie. / Detective McCormack had undisclosed affair with Audrey (Derek's wife) starting before trial, including Key West weekend trip. / Derek to Bayard Ellis: 'I've been asking myself that for the last 17 years' (why wife would frame him). / Michelle at retrial: 'No. No, he didn't [rape me].'
tags: fabricated_claim; coerced_confession; custody_dispute; arrested; charged_then_dropped; registered_then_cleared; perp_walk; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically; detective_misconduct; prosecutorial_misconduct; ineffective_counsel; 17_years_imprisonment
notes: Derek Thompson is the central figure of wrongful conviction. He was accused of raping his 6-year-old daughter Michelle in 1998. The accusation originated from his wife Audrey after a marital fight, during which Audrey repeatedly questioned Michelle until the child said what her mother wanted to hear. Michelle told her first-grade teacher before trial that her mother made her lie—teacher sent letter to Detective McCormack and ADA O'Dwyer, but this exculpatory evidence was not effectively used at trial. Investigation 17 years later reveals Detective McCormack was having an affair with Audrey starting before the trial, including a Key West trip together, creating massive conflict of interest never disclosed. Derek maintained innocence throughout 17 years of incarceration, writing letters to his children. Adult Michelle recants multiple times, stating clearly her father never raped her. Derek refused plea deal that would have freed him because it required admitting guilt. At retrial, Michelle testifies father is innocent, though aggressive cross-examination by O'Dwyer causes momentary confusion. Consequences: 17 years in prison, sex offender registry, complete family separation, public stigma as child rapist and incest perpetrator, loss of children's entire childhoods. Severity 4 due to life-altering duration of imprisonment and permanent life damage. Episode ends mid-verdict so ultimate legal outcome unknown, but strong implication throughout is that Derek is innocent of a crime that never occurred.

police_conduct_quote: Stop! Hands where I can see 'em! [Officers fire 35 shots]
quote_or_scene: DNA came back. The two push-ins are a match, but our perp... whoever he is... isn't Terrence Reynolds. // These three officers killed an innocent man. // Terrence Reynolds was shot 35 times while reaching for his keys. Cell phone footage shows him trying to put his hands up and comply with commands. // Parents testify: 'Terrence was a good son. He was working part-time at an animal hospital while he was going for his degree. He'd been ticketed a few times... Nothing violent? No. Never.'
tags: wrong_ID; media_outing; perp_walk; public_confrontation; ruined_physically; vigilante_attack
notes: 22-year-old college student working part-time at animal hospital. Matched BOLO description (basketball jersey) but DNA proved he was not the rapist. Shot 35 times by three officers while reaching for keys to enter his building. Cell phone video captured the shooting showing him attempting to comply with police commands. Death sparked major protests and media coverage. Grand jury indicted the officers. Parents gave testimony about his character. The actual serial rapist remained at large after his death.

quote_or_scene: Anton consistently claims he was drugged: 'I must have been drugged.' His escort Kim admits she gave him pills and stole his flute. Surveillance shows him wandering naked and disoriented. Lawyer argues 'under the influence of an anesthetic narcotic given to him without his knowledge.' Judge remands him: 'Mr. Krasnikov, you are remanded without bail.' Kim later tells Amanda she'll 'testify against Anton' as part of her plea deal. SVU ignores exculpatory evidence despite Dodds wanting to find the escort who drugged him.
tags: ruined_at_work; perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation; fabricated_claim; coerced_confession; international_celebrity; drugged_victim_becomes_accused; career_destroyed
notes: Anton is an internationally-renowned flautist drugged and robbed by escort Kim Rollins. While incapacitated, he entered Alessandra Bay's room (surveillance shows him naked, disoriented, wandering halls). Despite his claims of being drugged, medical evidence of drugs, and Kim's admission she gave him pills, SVU charges him with rape. He's remanded without bail, loses passport, cannot perform scheduled concerts worldwide. Kim later offers to testify against him for her own plea deal. Show strongly implies he was exploited victim framed for rape he committed while drugged/unconscious, but SVU and prosecution treat him as guilty perpetrator. His life/career are completely destroyed. Severity 4: international career ended, remanded to jail, facing prison, professional reputation annihilated.

quote_or_scene: Pete: 'I couldn't get her pregnant. I had a vasectomy ten years ago, guys.' Doctor confirms vasectomy. DNA later proves Pastor Eldon is the father.
notes: Pete is arrested and shown being processed. He is guilty of unlawful surveillance/child pornography (filming teens undressing) but is innocent of the statutory rape accusation. His vasectomy and DNA evidence clear him of the rape charge.

quote_or_scene: Fin: 'We understand that your son, Graham, has...had some problems?' Pastor Eldon: 'Graham's en route to Ecuador. A mission down there's in need.' DNA testing proves: 'No Baker DNA on the paternal side' for Tate. Pastor Eldon manipulated the family: 'You made us think it was our son.'
notes: Graham had prior issues with forcible touching of his sisters (juvie records sealed by local judge) and was sent to reform camp. However, he is innocent of fathering Lane's or Summer's babies. Pastor Eldon manipulated the parents into believing Graham confessed to protect himself. Graham was sent to Ecuador to evade investigation. He is guilty of OTHER sexual misconduct (prior forcible touching) but innocent of the ACCUSED offense (fathering the babies).

police_conduct_quote: 15'll get you 20. You got that right. 15 also makes those photos on your cell phone child pornography.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Ripped City gym during Diego's work hours, arrest him publicly in front of colleagues/clients. He protests: 'You knew about this? You set me up?' Squad makes threatening statements about his sexting with 15-year-old. Later cleared when alibi confirms he was 'teaching X-treme Combat class all morning' at Brooklyn gym, far from crime scene.
notes: Diego is arrested at his workplace (fitness studio) in front of colleagues/clients for suspected involvement in Lily's disappearance. His alibi (teaching class in Brooklyn all morning) is later confirmed, and 'Lily's not the only girl sexting him' suggests he's cleared. However, exposure is limited to the arrest scene at work—no media, no extended public pile-on shown. Severity 2: public accusation at workplace but no sustained consequence shown (firing, license loss, etc.).

police_conduct_quote: She started flirting with you, right? She gave you that little smile... She takes off her jacket, her little t-shirt... She was taunting you... That made you mad... We all know what happened here, but we need to hear it from you. You tell us this, it's all over.
quote_or_scene: Robby brought in for 6-hour interrogation. Detectives use coercive techniques: showing photos repeatedly despite his distress ('I can't look at that anymore. Please'), Reid-style false empathy ('She was taunting you... That made you mad'), leading him to near-confession ('Yeah, okay. She got in the van'). His brother George (a lawyer) is present but as subject of questioning, not as counsel. Right before formal confession, DNA clears him: 'The DNA on Lily's body doesn't match either of these brothers.'
notes: Robby undergoes intensive coercive interrogation but DNA definitively clears him before charges. His only witness is his brother George (who eventually gives him up to police, creating family harm). However, exposure stays within interrogation room—no workplace, media, or public component shown. Severity 1: private interrogation with coercion but no public exposure or formal sanction. His prior sexual assault arrest (acquitted, complainant paid off) is mentioned but predates this episode's events.

quote_or_scene: Defense attorney Lisa Hassler questions Lomatin on the stand: 'You'd often spoken with Hector, isn't that right?' 'How friendly?' 'Did you resent it when SVU Sergeant John Munch interrogated you about this case?' 'How long have you been taking anti-psychotic drugs?' 'Did you murder Hector Rodriguez?' Lomatin responds: 'I will not dignify that question with an answer, Your Honor.' Hassler: 'I'm not hearing a no. And so, there can only be only one logical conclusion.' Earlier in transcript: Lomatin states 'His own captain apologized to me. So did the other detectives.' regarding being questioned as suspect by Munch.
notes: Lomatin was originally investigated by Munch as a suspect in 1999 (pictures of Hector found in his attic), but was cleared and received apologies from SVU. Defense attorney Hassler revives these accusations in open court during Hodda's trial, publicly suggesting Lomatin murdered Hector. The courtroom is full of press (established earlier), and Hector's mother is present. Lomatin becomes visibly distressed. This is a weaponized false accusation in a public forum causing reputational harm. Though Lomatin had mental health issues (anti-psychotic drugs mentioned), the transcript strongly implies he was innocent—he found evidence, was obsessed with solving the case, not committing it. SVU had apologized to him previously.

police_conduct_quote: Listen, if you met up with Zach Foster, you need to tell us now. We're pulling the video from the AirTrain entrance and we're gonna put the two of you together... If something happens to Zach... the less likely you are to get a deal.
quote_or_scene: Vermont ski lodge arrest: 'NYPD. Nobody move.' 'Where's Zach?' Arrested in front of new husband David during honeymoon. Later: 'Phoebe Burnap, you're under arrest.' Arraignment scene confirms media/photographers present: 'This is all over the news. There are photographers at the arraignment.'
notes: Burnap IS guilty of raping Travis and Jordan (different students), but was INNOCENT of kidnapping/catfishing Zach Foster—the accusation for which she was arrested. She was publicly arrested at ski lodge with her new husband, interrogated coercively about Zach, charged with kidnapping/rape in Zach's case, and exposed in media. Her photos were stolen/used by Coach Basinski to catfish Zach. She eventually cut a deal after giving information about Basinski. This is a 'partially_involved' case: innocent of the ACCUSED crime (Zach kidnapping) but guilty of OTHER crimes (Travis/Jordan). Included because she suffered public exposure and arrest for a crime she didn't commit, even though she committed related crimes.

police_conduct_quote: Congratulations. You found another unarmed black man. / Nice work. (sarcastic from lawyer suggesting pattern of wrongful arrests)
quote_or_scene: Suspect: 'You got the wrong guy. Again. I'm gonna sue your asses.' Detective: 'You left prints and DNA. Lab's gonna tie you to all those rapes.' Suspect: 'Here's what I know: lawyer.' Lawyer later: 'Congratulations. You found another unarmed black man. I suppose we should be grateful that you didn't shoot him.' Detective: 'He had a gun on him.' Lawyer: 'Did he? Who planted it?'
notes: The episode strongly implies innocence through: (1) suspect's claim 'You got the wrong guy. Again' suggesting pattern of false arrests, (2) lawyer's pointed question 'Who planted it?' about the gun, (3) lawyer's sarcastic congratulations on finding 'another unarmed black man' suggesting SVU has a history of wrongful arrests of black men, (4) no resolution shown confirming guilt. The arrest occurs at victim's workplace (husband present, describes himself as being there when attack happened). While detectives claim DNA/prints will confirm, this is never shown, and the framing suggests the SVU team may be wrong. The 'Again' is particularly telling - this isn't the first time he's been wrongly accused. Severity 3 for arrest and racial profiling implications, though we don't see job loss or other consequences beyond the arrest itself.

quote_or_scene: BARBA: 'I am informing you that a captain at IAB may be involved in a sex trafficking ring, and you don't mention that the two of you are sleeping together?' TUCKER: 'Group One is investigating you for sex trafficking, corruption, murder? Yeah. I've been invited to come in early tomorrow morning.'
notes: Monsignor Mulregan accuses Tucker of burying evidence about Vice trafficking ring a year ago. Tucker is investigated by Group One IAB for sex trafficking, corruption, and murder. He denies involvement and appears set up by his cousin Father Eugene. His relationship with Benson becomes part of the scrutiny. Investigation is formal and serious (severity 3).

quote_or_scene: BENSON: 'Lieutenant, what's going on?' DODDS SR: 'You'd know better than me. Did something happen?' BENSON: 'You're telling me that you didn't know? Know what?' DODDS SR: 'That I'm out. Effective immediately.' ... 'Sergeant Dodds is acting commander of SVU, so... congratulations. That's it. You're dismissed.'
notes: Benson is removed as SVU commander effective immediately after Barba discovers her relationship with Tucker, who is under investigation. While not explicitly accused of corruption, the removal is clearly consequence of her association with Tucker and perceived conflict of interest. The abrupt dismissal in front of her squad is public humiliation (severity 3).

quote_or_scene: MONSIGNOR: 'Sister Nina's medical leave is for psychiatric reasons. The Church has learned the hard way that we need to be proactive. We cannot sanction her being around children.' BARBA: 'The nun from the party, has mental health issues?' BENSON: 'Or that's the word that they put out to discredit her.'
notes: Sister Nina is a nun legitimately trying to rescue trafficked girls. Monsignor tells SVU she's on psychiatric medical leave and shouldn't be around children, effectively discrediting her testimony. Benson suggests this may be deliberate discrediting. Nina becomes paranoid when she learns Tucker (who she sees as corrupt) is involved, which further undermines her credibility. Her reputation as witness and rescuer is damaged (severity 2).

quote_or_scene: Monsignor at press conference: 'members of the NYPD Vice Squad and Internal Affairs Bureau...blackmailed Father Eugene into helping them traffic troubled girls.' Tucker to Dodds: 'Group One's been grilling me since 8:00 a.m.' Dodds: 'Tucker takes early retirement, the Vice cops take a misdemeanor sexual misconduct plea.'
notes: Tucker was deliberately framed by Monsignor Mulregan, who used Vice detectives Russo/Jefferson (whom he had leverage over) and his own cousin Father Eugene to fabricate a story that Tucker blackmailed them into running a trafficking ring. Tucker met with Russo/Jefferson alone (his partner was sick), creating exploitable ambiguity. He was investigated by Group One, publicly accused at a press conference, and ultimately forced into early retirement despite being completely innocent. The real ring was run by church officials for 20+ years. Tucker's career and reputation destroyed as collateral damage in the church's cover-up.

quote_or_scene: Rollins to Judge: 'This is blackmail.' Carisi: 'More like a courtesy call.' They show him surveillance photos of him with a 16-year-old on his lap. Judge: 'I never had any contact with a nun.' Rollins: 'Yes, you did. That's her right there, serving you a drink.'
notes: Judge Wheeler attended the sex party but claims he thought it was a fundraiser. SVU has surveillance photos of him with an underage girl. He is not accused of the trafficking itself, but of soliciting a minor prostitute at the party. SVU uses threat of exposure to coerce him into signing warrants against the priests. He is complicit in attending the party but may not have known the full trafficking operation. Included as example of someone with partial involvement who faced private exposure/coercion but not public scandal.

police_conduct_quote: Carisi to Caskey: 'maybe I would've gotten to know you better when you were raping cocktail waitresses' and 'You're under arrest. Get up.'
quote_or_scene: Caskey arrested at his apartment in front of his wife after evidence planted by his lawyer Zimmerman. Wife asks 'What's going on?' as police arrest him. Later revealed Zimmerman (the actual rapist/murderer) framed Caskey by planting victim jewelry in toilet tank.
tags: wrong_ID; fabricated_claim; family; arrested; registered_offender; public_confrontation
notes: Caskey is a registered Level 3 sex offender (prior rape conviction, served 10 years) but is proven innocent of these new accusations. His lawyer Zimmerman committed the rapes/murder to frame sex offenders. Caskey arrested at home in front of wife after planted evidence discovered. Already on registry so faces additional stigma. Wife cooperated with police sting to catch real perpetrator. Qualifies as harm: arrest is material sanction (severity 3) with family exposure.

person_label: Ryan Ledder (tennis pro from San Diego, bachelor contestant)
quote_or_scene: MELANIE (on live TV to 10 million viewers): 'Did Ryan rape me?' ... Later producers' show: 'millions of you watched Melanie make a disturbing accusation against Ryan' ... Ryan's mother intervenes, pulls him from show due to 'headlines accusing my son of rape'
notes: Ryan was accused of rape on live television broadcast to 10 million viewers. Though he left the Dream Suite before the assault occurred (proven by timeline and footage), producers edited footage to suggest he was responsible. His mother references 'headlines accusing my son of rape' and pulls him from the show. He was later cleared when Graham Turco was identified as the actual rapist. The public accusation occurred on national TV constituting severe exposure, though specific employment/career consequences not detailed beyond being removed from show.

person_label: Sean Roberts (original rape case, 16 years prior)
quote_or_scene: Sean at press conference: 'I bear no ill will towards Melanie Harper. She's as much a victim as I am in this.' Later: 'I know what it's like to be raped! I went in when I was 18, 140 pounds. What do you think happened to me?' Melanie: 'Every time he was beaten or raped, it was my fault. I turned him into a rapist... a monster.' Sean's confession: '16 years, that's what I learned. Things happened to me in prison... things I swore I'd never do to anyone else... I ended up doing to Ashley.'
tags: wrong_ID; arrested; convicted; imprisoned_16_years; raped_in_prison; media_outing; exonerated; victim_recant
notes: Sean was wrongfully convicted 16 years before the current episode timeline. He served full sentence and was repeatedly raped in prison. This is the core 'false suspect' case that frames the entire episode. While Sean ultimately confesses to murdering Ashley Harper in the current timeline (making him guilty of THIS crime), he was definitively innocent of the ORIGINAL rape 16 years ago. The episode explicitly shows how the wrongful conviction and prison rape transformed him. Severity=4: life-altering imprisonment, repeated sexual assault, psychological destruction. The original wrongful conviction is the central tragedy of the episode.

quote_or_scene: Carisi to Zach: 'When was the last time you saw Ashley?' Zach: 'Yesterday, before she went to dinner with that convict.' Carisi confronts him about threatening texts and lack of alibi. Later: 'The bartender at the Dakota Bar confirmed somebody spilled red wine on him. He went home to change. He was back in 15 minutes.' Zach cleared.
notes: Zach was briefly suspected due to threatening texts to Ashley and initially weak alibi. However, there is no indication of public exposure - the interrogation appears private. His alibi was quickly verified by bartender testimony. No arrest, no public confrontation, no material consequence beyond the interview itself. Severity=1: private questioning only. While technically innocent of a crime he was briefly suspected of, the lack of public exposure or material harm means this is borderline for inclusion. Including for completeness as he was explicitly investigated as a suspect.

police_conduct_quote: Rollins to Charlie: 'She was there posing, looking at you? Thought, "Maybe she wants to have sex with me?" Right?' Charlie: 'Do you think so?' Rollins: 'Yeah, Charlie, I do. I mean, why else would she be posing in front of a window like that?' Charlie: 'I know. It made me crazy.' Rollins: 'And then that's what happened, right? She kept teasing you. Maybe she wanted you to come over.' Charlie: 'Yeah, yeah, yeah. She definitely liked to tease me.'
quote_or_scene: Rollins finds Charlie on roof with voyeur equipment. 'Hey! Damn. Hey! Hold up there, chief.' Charlie arrested. During interrogation, Rollins uses leading questions suggesting Ashley wanted him. Charlie's mother arrives: 'You have to let him go, now... Charlie will just say whatever you want, but he didn't hurt that girl.' Girlfriend provides video alibi proving Charlie was with her during murder.
notes: Charlie is intellectually disabled/developmentally delayed. Police used coercive interview tactics with leading questions to extract near-confession before alibi cleared him. His mother and girlfriend were brought in, creating family exposure. He was arrested and interrogated in a way that manipulated his cognitive vulnerabilities. Severity=2: arrested and subjected to coercive interrogation that exploited his disability, with family notified, but quickly cleared by video evidence. No extended detention or public exposure beyond family.

person_label: Alden Kessler (Director of Admissions, Hudson University)
quote_or_scene: Detectives Carisi and Rollins confront Kessler at his office on Hudson University campus. Carisi asks: 'Do you know him? Or her?' showing photos. When Kessler says no, Rollins states: 'There's a rapist out there pretending to be you.' The confrontation occurs in Kessler's workplace with colleagues present. Kessler asks 'Is there a problem?' indicating he was surprised by the accusation. He states: 'I've never set foot in the Luxembourg Hotel.'
notes: Kessler is the real Director of Admissions whose identity was stolen by Tom Metcalf. He is publicly accused/questioned at his workplace in front of colleagues about rape allegations. While quickly cleared, he experiences professional embarrassment and exposure. The detectives inform him someone is 'pretending to be you' and ask if parents ever 'offer sex' to him, creating reputational risk in his professional environment. Severity is 2 because he was publicly confronted at work in front of colleagues, creating reputation damage even though he was quickly cleared.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives confront him at work: 'We want to talk to you about Quinn Berris.' Later he states: 'I got fired yesterday' after 'you guys showed up' and 'barged into my restaurant and accused me of assaulting Quinn.'
quote_or_scene: Ray Wilson is questioned by Detectives Rollins and Tutuola in his workplace kitchen in front of colleagues. He asks 'Can we go somewhere else?' indicating others are present. Later he tells detectives: 'I got fired yesterday. Till you guys showed up.' He also says they 'barged into my restaurant and accused me of assaulting Quinn.' His innocence is proven when surveillance shows Sergeant Tom Cole stealing Ray's cigarette butt to plant as evidence, and Ray's alibi (praying at church until 10:50 PM with video evidence) is confirmed.
notes: Ray Wilson is a paroled sex offender (prior conviction for breaking into Quinn's college dorm closet). Despite his criminal history, he is proven innocent of THIS specific assault. Detectives question him publicly at his restaurant workplace (he asks to go elsewhere, indicating coworkers present). His DNA is found at the scene, but this is later proven to be planted evidence by the actual perpetrator, Tom Cole. Ray loses his job directly as a result of the public accusation. He has an airtight alibi (church with witnesses + video at 10:50 PM). Quinn initially misidentified him based on past trauma. The real rapist (Cole) deliberately framed Ray by stealing his cigarette butt before committing the assault.

police_conduct_quote: We're gonna search that van. If we find any evidence that Theo was inside, you're on the hook for first-degree kidnapping. That's 15 years, son. You better come clean.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Gabriel and interrogate him aggressively. Despite his DNA hair found in Theo's room being explained by prior relationship with mother (ended 2 months prior), he is held on weapons charges unrelated to kidnapping. Lawyer present throughout. Gabriel states: 'I don't know anything about the kid' and 'I've told you everything I know!'
tags: red_herring; arrested; held_on_unrelated_charges; ex_boyfriend; DV_history; wrong_theory
notes: Gabriel Norton is Nadine's ex-boyfriend with history of domestic violence (gave her black eye). DNA hair found in Theo's room from prior relationship. Detectives pursued him aggressively, arrested him fleeing out window, held him on gun/drug charges despite no evidence connecting him to kidnapping. He had angry texts about Theo but weak alibi. Ultimately proven uninvolved when Oscar/Gloria revealed as perpetrators. Held on weapons charge unrelated to kidnapping accusation.

quote_or_scene: Benson to Fran: 'A lot of child abductions turn out to be orchestrated by the non-custodial parent. What are you saying? That I'm a suspect? I'm saying that we're gonna be going through your phone records, through your bank statements, and talking to the PI, and getting a warrant for any of the photos that he may have taken.'
tags: family_member; non_custodial_parent; custody_dispute; investigated; home_searched; records_searched; wrong_theory
notes: Dr. Fran Conway is Theo's non-biological, non-adoptive co-parent (ex-wife of Nadine). She hired a PI to document Nadine's parenting for custody case. Detectives explicitly treat her as suspect ('A lot of child abductions turn out to be orchestrated by the non-custodial parent'), search her home/car, go through phone/bank records, obtain warrants for PI photos. Nadine also accuses her multiple times ('You accused her of kidnapping three times in the last hour'). Investigation remains primarily police-level but involves intrusive searches and explicit suspicion. Eventually cleared when Gloria/Oscar revealed as perpetrators. Exposure limited to police but investigation was thorough and accusatory.

quote_or_scene: Detectives question Eric at Avalon offices in presence of aunt Cynthia and grandfather Lawrence: 'Eric, you don't have to talk to these people.' 'No, it... it's all right, Aunt Cynthia. This is crazy.' Later his father Larry arrives: 'Come on, Eric. We're leaving... you're not going back to your grandfather's.'
notes: Eric had consensual sex with Sarah but did not rape her. His grandfather Lawrence drugged and raped Sarah afterward. Eric is accused at his workplace (Avalon) in front of family members including his aunt (supervisor) and grandfather (company founder/CEO). His father removes him from grandfather's home. While Eric is 'partially_involved' (had consensual sex), he is innocent of the rape accusation. The public workplace confrontation in front of family/colleagues constitutes severity 2 exposure even without formal job action.

quote_or_scene: Nicole looked at Luke and screamed 'Help! He's raping me!' causing Luke to shoot Trey. Nicole later admits on stand: 'Trey Franklin and I were in the kitchen having sex. Then Luke walked in on us and shot his friend in the head.' She fabricated the rape claim to protect herself and manipulate her son.
notes: Trey was killed instantly when Luke shot him based on Nicole's false rape accusation. Nicole deliberately cried rape while making eye contact with her armed son, causing him to fire. She was convicted of second-degree murder and statutory rape. The accusation was knowingly false - Nicole was the sexual predator, not Trey. This is the most extreme consequence possible: death directly caused by a fabricated accusation.

quote_or_scene: Detectives bring Cook in for questioning after Beth identifies him from a photo. He is arrested attempting to flee. Cook: 'I hit her with a firm and respectful handshake.' Later surveillance footage proves Cook walked away after handshake, and witnesses place him at grandmother's assisted living facility in Yonkers at time of assault (4:50am sign-in sheet). Beth later admits: 'I must've made a mistake.'
notes: Gary Cook was an Army veteran, dishonorably discharged, who posted misogynistic comments online about Beth Williams ('Army publicity stunt with a nice rack'). He attended the fight club and shook Beth's hand outside. Beth falsely identified him as her rapist from a photo lineup. He was arrested when he ran from detectives. His alibi was ironclad with multiple witnesses and sign-in sheet placing him 50 blocks away at 4:50am. Surveillance footage confirmed he walked away from Beth after handshake. While he faced arrest and questioning, there is no evidence of public exposure beyond police interaction or material harm beyond the arrest itself.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Rodney at his car dealership: 'Rodney Marsh, we need to talk.' 'I'm in the middle of a deal, guys.' They question him about Jessica Walcott in front of his customer Mitch. Later: 'Rodney's DNA doesn't match the semen in the rape kit.'
notes: Rodney was accused by victim Jessica based on his harassment at the bar. Detectives confront him publicly at his workplace in front of a customer during an active sales negotiation. He cooperates fully, gives DNA sample voluntarily. DNA proves him innocent. No apology shown. Qualifies as severity 2 because accusation occurred in front of coworkers/customer, causing immediate reputational harm and disruption to his work.

quote_or_scene: Bennett: 'I got a call. There was no name. It was untraceable... Change my report. Say the ropes don't match. In case anyone checked, get rid of the rope.' Benson finds Bennett with a gun contemplating suicide: 'My work was my life. And now I can't go back, ever... I thought I could make up for my one mistake through my work, but when everyone knows everything, how can one ever really forgive and forget?'
notes: Bennett was blackmailed by Willard into falsifying rope evidence. Willard hacked Bennett's emails and discovered 'something embarrassing and wrong' from his past. Bennett contemplated suicide, saying his career was over. While the initial 'accusation' against Bennett was implied professional misconduct (changing his report), the real harm was being blackmailed into destroying his own credibility and career. This caused life-altering harm (severity 4) including suicide attempt. The exposure was primarily to law enforcement, but the consequence was career-ending.

quote_or_scene: Barba to Benson: 'There was nothing I could do. I had to recuse myself... Willard must have hacked my bank account, tracked down Ashtonja... I told [the DA] everything. We might've seen our last case together.' Barba explains he gave money to Ashtonja Abreu (daughter of a deceased witness) and Willard tried to make it look like payment for sex.
notes: Willard hacked Barba's bank records, discovered he was giving money to Ashtonja Abreu, and fabricated an accusation that it was payment for sex (sex trafficking/corruption). Willard used this to blackmail Barba into recusing himself from the case. Barba had to report everything to the DA and faces potential career consequences ('We might've seen our last case together'). The implied accusation was paying for sex/corruption. While not explicitly stated as a formal charge, the blackmail forced professional consequences and career risk. Severity 3 for material professional sanction and career jeopardy.

quote_or_scene: Bolton: 'according to the Internet, I'm a customer of an underage sex trafficking ring run out of a Chinese restaurant called the Coral Dragon.' Later: 'When my email was hacked, I thought it was routine harassment, business as usual these days, but this... they can plant things remotely on people's computers.' Final scene: Bolton shot at restaurant while with his daughter by someone who believed the conspiracy theory.
tags: media_outing; online_rumor; fabricated_claim; ruined_physically; perp_walk; public_confrontation
notes: Bolton was framed via hacked emails and planted child pornography on his computer. A hacker (Raj) was paid to do this by unknown parties, possibly foreign intelligence. The fake news website 'The Endless Truth' spread the accusations online. Bolton came to SVU voluntarily to clear his name. Investigation proved the material was planted while he was in Washington.
