Despite SVU's public statement clearing him, the website continued accusations. Episode ends with Bolton being shot at the restaurant while trying to publicly demonstrate it was safe, showing life-altering physical harm to him and trauma to his daughter.

quote_or_scene: Lee: 'I've been getting death threats. My employees are getting death threats.' Later: 'This is out of control. Who's gonna come eat here now?' And: 'That man came in with a gun. He saw the Congressman with his daughter. He shouted at him... He shot him. Is this ever gonna stop?'
tags: online_rumor; fabricated_claim; ruined_at_work; death_threats; armed_confrontation; media_outing
notes: Lee's restaurant was falsely accused of being a front for child sex trafficking based on conspiracy theories about coded language in Bolton's emails and the restaurant's logo. Malcolm Barnstable entered with a rifle demanding to see the basement where girls were supposedly held. SVU investigation found no basement and no trafficking. Despite SVU's public statement clearing the restaurant, online harassment continued. Lee suffered ongoing death threats, employee harassment, and business losses. The conspiracy theory ultimately led to a shooting at his restaurant. SVU provided some security but offered only partial acknowledgment of the harm.

police_conduct_quote: Rollins: 'That's a confession. Illegal child pornography. Plus, you were doing more than looking.' Carisi: 'Well, it looks like your sins aren't all in the past, hmm?' Fleming: 'I can't go back to jail. My business, my children...' Carisi: 'It's a little late to think about that.'
quote_or_scene: Fleming: 'Coral Dragon? I sold 'em dishes and cutlery, but I lost the account more than ten years ago.' Later investigation finds child pornography on his computer. Fleming: 'I was only looking... I can't help myself... My wife... this will destroy her. I can't go back to jail. My business, my children...' Then: 'Fin: This fool just tried to shoot himself.'
notes: Fleming was initially investigated because 'The Endless Truth' connected him to the Coral Dragon restaurant and noted his 30-year-old statutory rape conviction. He was innocent of the Coral Dragon trafficking conspiracy. However, investigation of his computer revealed actual child pornography possession and recent contacts with a real (unrelated) sex trafficking ring. He is 'partially_involved' because he is innocent of the ACCUSED offense (Coral Dragon conspiracy) but guilty of other sex crimes (CP possession, soliciting minors). The interrogation was coercive and threatening. Fleming attempted suicide during the sting operation. While he did commit crimes, the harm (suicide attempt) was a consequence of being falsely connected to the Coral Dragon conspiracy, then investigated and confronted about actual crimes in a coercive manner.

police_conduct_quote: We have a witness... saw you take your ski mask off. They saw you, Hector. That's game over... if you come clean... you tell us who the other two guys were... you might be able to cut yourself a deal right now.
quote_or_scene: NYPD storms Leo's Restaurant kitchen where Hector works, grabs him in front of coworkers. '?Qu?? No! Mira, ?qu? es esto? ?Qu? est? pasando aqu??' Hector arrested and arraigned. Prosecutor later states: 'the people have just released Hector Ramirez... we expect to formally indict him in the near future' after witness is deported. Hector maintained throughout: 'I wasn't there... I would never hurt the Samras. I like them... I didn't kill anybody. Or rape anyone... I swear to God, on my children.'
tags: ruined_at_work; public_confrontation; arrested; perp_walk; charged_then_dropped; media_outing; wrong_ID; immigrant
notes: Hector is ID'd by Yusef Massad in lineup as one of three masked men. Only evidence: Yusef's ID (witness later deported) and 'a couple strands of Hector's hair' at restaurant where he worked until 3 weeks prior. Hector's alibi: home with wife Soledad (who backs him up). ADA acknowledges 'no jury's gonna convict based on two strands of hair' and 'Without Yusef, it's meaningless.' Released for insufficient evidence. His consistent denials, lack of forensics, and prosecutors' acknowledgment of weak case strongly imply innocence. Public arrest at workplace, arraignment, media coverage = severity 3. Episode ends with Hector being taken hostage, suggesting he is viewed as wrongly accused by community.

quote_or_scene: Everyone, your attention. Daniel Ross, Max Rivera, stand up. You're under arrest for reckless endangerment, endangering the welfare of a child, and disseminating indecent material to minors.
notes: Arrested publicly in classroom for rape-related charges. Later proven innocent of rape; admitted to and pled guilty to lesser charges (drawing on victim, taking photos). Included because initially arrested for rape-adjacent charges in humiliating public manner, though partially involved in other offenses.

police_conduct_quote: Yeah, and it's gonna get worse unless you give us a play by play.
quote_or_scene: He cornered me in the locker room. He said what I was doing to Andrew... throwing him under the bus was messed up, and I should pay... He has a scratched cornea, three fractured bones in his wrist.
notes: Publicly arrested at school for rape. Later proven innocent of rape; admitted to drawing on victim and distributing photos. Beaten by other students after agreeing to testify, suffering serious injuries (scratched cornea, three fractured bones). Violence was consequence of the rape accusation and his cooperation. Also threatened by detectives with federal child pornography charges.

quote_or_scene: Laurel ultimately confesses: 'I waited until he was asleep, and then I stabbed him.' Benson's interrogation reveals Laurel fabricated the rape claim - Harvey consensually brought her home after meeting at a bar. Laurel killed him because he reminded her of her father (same aftershave, same watch brand) and she displaced her rage about never being chosen for abuse onto Harvey.
notes: Harvey is dead before SVU investigates, so no traditional public exposure occurs. However, he is accused of rape to police/hospital, investigated as a rapist, and dies as a direct consequence of a false accusation. His innocence is proven through Benson's interrogation revealing Laurel's fabricated memories and confession to premeditated murder. The harm (death) is severity 4. Exposure was police_only since he died before any public revelation, but the accusation directly caused his death.

quote_or_scene: ROLLINS: 'Tell me about your conversation with this kid.' MAN: 'Yeah, I was on line, getting coffee. He was with his mom. She was... worth getting to know, you know? That's why you come here? To pick up women? Well, it's better than the fresh fruit section at Whole Foods. Besides, I needed pants. For my bike club.' ROLLINS: 'And that was the only time you spoke to him?' MAN: 'Yep. I saw him again in the store, just before I found the pants. I waved, but she didn't notice.' Sales girl confirms he was in dressing room trying on pants for over an hour during kidnapping.
notes: Sheila Porter identified this man as suspicious - saw him at Starbucks talking to Noah about sports, then saw him again at the department store where he waved. Detectives questioned him but sales clerk alibi confirmed he was trying on pants in dressing room for over an hour during the kidnapping. Never publicly exposed, only private police interview. No material harm. Excluded from harm count because exposure was police_only with no public component or material consequence.

quote_or_scene: Principal Flock: 'Obviously we don't want legal action. Mariel is underage.' Teacher present during initial discovery. Detectives question Cody at school with his mother present: 'We need to bring Cody to the station, get a statement.' Cody separated from Mariel permanently. Mariel later says: 'She said I was too sick to have a boyfriend. Too sick to get married. Your mother took you out of that school, didn't she? She said because of Cody.'
notes: Cody's innocence is established when both he and Mariel describe consensual encounter. Barba declines to prosecute: 'Barba doesn't want to pursue.' However, Cody suffers significant consequences: (1) questioned publicly at school in front of principal and teacher, (2) brought to police station for formal statement with mother present, (3) permanently separated from Mariel who he loved, (4) Mariel's mother Dawn removes Mariel from school 'because of Cody,' ending their relationship. Although not arrested, the public nature of the school investigation and forced separation constitute material harm. Severity 3 reflects school/family exposure plus permanent relationship loss.

quote_or_scene: Arrested at his workplace (coffee shop) in front of customers: 'Kind of busy here, guys... Yeah, you guys did a crap job of keeping the peace... Are you kidding me? For protesting at a protest? That's right. Take a good look. We're already living in a police state.' Defense attorney Jed Karey at dismissal: 'We all knew that Martha Cobb was exploiting her victimization to further her right-wing agenda, and fortunately, Justin here has been vindicated from this politically motivated and slanderous accusation.' ADA Barba dismisses case: 'The People are unable to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Justin Vichinsky sexually assaulted Martha Cobb.'
notes: Vichinsky's DNA was under Martha's nails from a physical altercation during the riot, not from the sexual assault. Martha later admits uncertainty: 'I remember Vichinsky screaming at me. I remember his eyes, his rage... But after I got hit on the head... Everything was a blur. The man who raped me... Maybe I conflated things. But I am pretty sure it was him.' ADA dismisses case due to reasonable doubt created by alternate suspect Randy Platt. Vichinsky was arrested publicly at his job, tried in court, and vilified in media before being cleared. No apology shown on screen.

quote_or_scene: Stone orders: 'Place Detective Cassidy under arrest for murder.' Holiday arranges 'Perp walk into Central Booking.' Earlier Stone states: 'consider yourself suspended until further notice.' Holiday aggressively interrogates Cassidy, accusing him: 'I see another overzealous cop trying to get over after he kills an unarmed black man.' Cassidy is cleared when DNA evidence from fish traces to Reggie's fishing knife, proving the actual killer.
tags: cop; public_confrontation; arrested; perp_walk; ruined_at_work; wrong_ID
notes: Cassidy was at the crime scene but unconscious during the actual murder. He was knocked out by the real killer (Reggie). His presence at the scene, bloody clothes, and prior courtroom threat made him the prime suspect. He endured interrogation where Detective Holiday accused him of being a racist cop who kills unarmed black men. He was formally arrested and subjected to a perp walk. The fish DNA evidence exonerated him by linking the murder weapon to Reggie's fishing knife. Stone and Holiday pursued charges aggressively before evidence cleared him.

quote_or_scene: Ethan at tribunal: 'They suspended him for a year. He was so angry. He yelled and threatened me.' Later Ethan testifies: 'I applied to six other colleges. I got 700s on my SATs, and that wasn't good enough. Once the PC police get their fangs into you, your life in polite society is over... I'm already wearing the scarlet R. My friends won't talk to me.' Carisi testifies under oath: 'There was no first rape... [Mia] lied to the school tribunal... Yes.'
tags: ruined_at_work; ruined_in_family; school_alert; public_confrontation; fabricated_claim; witness_recant
notes: Ethan was falsely accused of rape by Mia Marino in December 2017. University tribunal found him 'responsible' and suspended him for one year, effective immediately, requiring him to vacate campus by 5pm. He was banned from attending classes. The accusation was public—heard by tribunal panel, parents present, later investigated by NYPD. Mia later admitted to Carisi she lied: she consented to sex but told her roommate Renata it was rape to avoid judgment, then couldn't take it back once the school got involved. Carisi testified at the second trial that 'there was no first rape' and Mia 'lied to the school tribunal.' Consequences were severe and life-altering: (1) one-year suspension from Hudson University, (2) banned from campus/classes, (3) rejected by six other colleges despite high SAT scores, (4) pre-med/neurosurgeon career path destroyed, (5) friends stopped talking to him, (6) widespread social stigma ('scarlet R'). Ethan describes being labeled a rapist regardless of truth, his 'life in polite society is over.' He later committed an actual rape against Mia (the second incident) and was convicted, but the first accusation—the subject of this row—was proven false. Severity 4: career-ending, permanent educational exclusion, profound social destruction.

quote_or_scene: Detectives forcibly enter Gidumal's apartment with guns drawn ('NYPD'), find him via tracking his phone, confront him about a missing girl. He explains the kiss dare, states he saw all three girls enter the Rec Center. After confirmation, he's told to 'call a locksmith; the Department will reimburse you' for his broken door. He is detained/escorted away ('you're gonna have to come with us until we can confirm your story').
notes: Gidumal is the initial suspect based on two girls' statements that Zoe was last seen with him. Police break into his home, detain him, and only release him after verifying his story that all three girls went into the Rec Center. Though the exposure appears contained to police, he suffered arrest, home invasion with property damage, and brief detention. His door was broken and he was taken into custody. However, there is no indication of public exposure beyond the police interaction, and no evidence of workplace, family, or media exposure. Severity rated as 2 due to arrest and property damage, but no broader public exposure documented.

consequence_detail: arrested, charged_murder_two, public_trial, media_coverage, perp_walk_implied, held_in_custody, reputation_damage
police_conduct_quote: Carisi: 'Maybe she met some other guy.' Rollins: 'You remember that feather boa she was wearing? Well, we found that in your bathroom, covered in blood.' Carisi: 'There was blood in your car, Vinny.' / Rollins: 'Screw you. Pretending you're on my side.' Drago: 'I... I don't need any friends.' Carisi: 'Oh, yes, you do, Vinny. This does not look good.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Drago at his workplace (butcher shop), bringing him in for questioning. Later: 'Vincent Drago, 22. Has a history of DV, stalking, menacing. His ex-girlfriend has a restraining order out against him.' Arraigned on murder two. In court: 'It's day two of the Haley Sadler murder trial... Without Haley's remains, and what experts are calling thin forensic evidence, the pressure is mounting for the DA's office.' Drago's lawyer: 'No disrespect, but... they don't have a body.' Defense: 'No body, no case.' Stone proceeds with prosecution. When Haley found alive with Turner, case collapses.
tags: ruined_at_work; arrested; charged_then_dropped; public_trial; media_outing; perp_walk; fabricated_claim; butcher; wrong_ID
notes: Drago was innocent of murder/kidnapping. Haley staged her own disappearance and planted evidence (blood, feather boa, necklace) to frame him. He was publicly arrested at his workplace in front of coworkers, charged with murder two, subjected to coercive interrogation tactics, and put on public trial with media coverage. He faced potential life sentence. His prior DV/stalking history made him an easy target. When Haley was found alive with Turner, the case against Drago collapsed. No apology shown on screen. Severity 4 due to murder charge, public trial, potential life-altering conviction.

police_conduct_quote: Carisi to Billy: 'rape one carries a sentence of 25 years in prison' and 'right now is your chance to tell us your side of the story' leading to false confession under pressure
quote_or_scene: Detectives approach Billy during military training: 'We want to talk to you about Saturday night.' Billy responds 'It was me. I raped her' after being told about 25-year sentence. Later in court Billy testifies: 'I was lying back then. I just wanted to get you and the damn cops off my back.'
notes: Billy falsely confessed to rape/assault to protect his superior officer. He was arrested on-screen and questioned publicly in front of his military unit. Victim Sky/Sandy explicitly stated Billy 'didn't do anything bad to me' and was 'sweet.' Billy's false confession was coerced through intimidation tactics about prison time. He faced arrest, public exposure at his workplace (military base), and threat of Leavenworth military prison for making allegations against superior.

police_conduct_quote: Stone threatens: 'It's called perjury, Billy, and believe me, I will prosecute' and to Jim: 'If you refuse, you will be subpoenaed, and failure to appear will be met with the strictest punishment the law allows.'
quote_or_scene: Jim arrested in front of soldiers: 'Not here. Not in front of my soldiers.' Later testifies: 'I didn't touch her... if I testify, my country will attack me... once I'm outed to officials, there's no going back in... I could lose my job. My career. Everything I've ever worked for.' Defense attorney forces public outing in court: 'So you're saying you were once a woman?' Jim: 'I was always a man... it's in my medical forms, sir.'
tags: public_confrontation; arrested; soldier; ruined_at_work; coerced_confession; ruined_in_family
notes: Jim Preston innocent of rape—he was forced into room by Tyler Jones, victim hit him with lamp in self-defense, he then helped pull Tyler off victim during strangulation. Jim's blood at scene led to accusation. Detectives publicly arrested him in front of military unit. Refused to testify initially because doing so would expose transgender identity. Police/ADA threatened perjury charges and subpoena to force testimony. Jim's forced public outing in court testimony constitutes life-altering harm (severity 4) as he explicitly stated this exposure could end his military career due to political climate around trans service members. Defense attorney weaponized his transgender status to attack credibility. Jim described this as putting himself 'in a prison of my own making' and losing 'everything I've ever worked for.'

quote_or_scene: Boys arrested at basketball court: 'Cops! Run!' Detectives chase and catch them. Later at precinct: 'We had sex with that girl, but we didn't rape her! It... it can't be rape, not if we paid for it!' Leonard explains the pimp took his money: 'So I went home, got my mom's ring, pawned it, gave the guy 200 bucks.' Case ultimately dismissed when prostitution arrangement proven.
notes: Leonard and his twin cousins (Darryl and DeShawn) paid $200 to Malik Williams who was pimping his sister. The boys believed it was prostitution. While the victim was incapacitated and legally could not consent (making it rape under law), the boys genuinely believed they paid for consensual sex. They were publicly arrested at the playground in front of community, brought to precinct with grandmother present, and faced rape charges. Charges eventually dropped when DA learned of trafficking arrangement. Grandmother hired attorney Ron Carter. Boys suffered arrest, interrogation, and rape accusations before being cleared. The actual crime was committed by Malik (trafficking) not the boys (who engaged in solicitation of a minor).

quote_or_scene: Same arrest scene at basketball court. At precinct, attorney Ron Carter states: 'My clients, they're not proud of what they did. But this is not a rape.' Carisi confirms: 'DeShawn and Darryl confirm Leonard's version of what happened.'
notes: Twin brother, age 14. Same circumstances as Leonard - paid for what they believed was prostitution, arrested publicly, questioned with attorney and grandmother present, charges ultimately dropped when trafficking arrangement revealed.

quote_or_scene: Same arrest and interrogation as brothers. All three boys arrested together fleeing basketball court, brought to precinct, faced rape charges before being cleared.
notes: Twin brother, age 14. Same circumstances as Leonard and Darryl - paid for what they believed was prostitution, arrested publicly, questioned with attorney and grandmother present, charges ultimately dropped when trafficking arrangement revealed.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Haverford at his workplace (yoga studio) publicly: 'Gus Haverford, NYPD. We need to talk to you about Sam Conway.' Haverford responds: 'I swear to God, I didn't know he was 15 years old. Kid was messed up. I had the Uber take him home.' He explains he was trying to comfort Sam who was crying about his brother and a rabbit. Uber driver confirms Haverford's account that he was trying to help the drunk teenager.
notes: Senior VP at Morgan Stanley confronted publicly during his lunch hour yoga session. Though quickly cleared based on Uber driver testimony and his cooperation, he was accused in a public setting (yoga studio) where others would have witnessed the police confrontation. The accusation arose from squad inference based on Uber records and bartender identification. Haverford was actually a Good Samaritan who helped an intoxicated, traumatized teenager get home safely.

police_conduct_quote: Give him his phone call and a bologna sandwich (dismissive treatment); Fin: 'You're being charged with kidnapping in the second degree... That's a class B felony in this state.'
quote_or_scene: Lieutenant Benson holds press conference: 'NYPD Special Victims Unit has arrested an agent in the Office of Refugee Resettlement for kidnapping of a nine-year-old girl.' Judge later rules: 'I hold that federal immigration policy overrides any claim by the state that a kidnapping has been committed. The detention of Officer Phelps is therefore illegal. He should be released from custody forthwith.'
tags: arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation; ruined_at_work; wrong_theory; federal_employee
notes: Phelps was performing his lawful federal job duties under the Zero Tolerance immigration policy when he separated Gabriela from her mother at the border. SVU arrested him for kidnapping based on state law. Benson held a public press conference announcing the arrest, generating major media exposure. Federal judge ruled the arrest illegal under supremacy clause (federal law trumps state law). While Phelps's actions caused harm to Gabriela, he was operating under federal policy directives, making him innocent of criminal kidnapping. The arrest and public exposure constitute significant harm to Phelps's reputation and career, despite him following lawful orders. This represents a false accusation based on misapplication of state criminal law to federal immigration enforcement.

consequence_detail: arrested, interrogated with threats, evidence planted, reputation damage
police_conduct_quote: Detective shows Brad graphic crime scene photos and aggressively accuses: 'What were you cutting out, Brad? Was it a tattoo? I bet it was another guy's name.' Carisi threatens: 'They got a lot of mashed potatoes up at Sing Sing.' Rollins later shouts: 'It's gonna be a lot worse in prison, Lieutenant.'
quote_or_scene: Brad is interrogated aggressively, shown graphic photos of Vicky's mutilated body, threatened with prison. Later arrested based on planted blood evidence. Detective says: 'Two blocks away from the loft... You get drunk? You go back over to Vicky's place for old time's sake. She turns you down. So you stab her to death.' Brad responds: 'I want a lawyer.' Evidence (blood on shoes/jeans) is later revealed to have been planted by Gina on orders from the Accredo group.
notes: Brad is Vicky's ex-boyfriend who posted revenge porn but did not kill her. Blood evidence was deliberately planted on his clothing by Gina Goodrich (on Arlo's orders) to frame him. He was subjected to aggressive interrogation with graphic crime scene photos and threats about prison. Search warrant executed at his apartment. While the interrogation appears private (police_only), detectives went to his workplace to question him and executed a search warrant at his residence, creating workplace exposure. He was arrested and faced murder/rape charges before Gina's confession cleared him. The squad used highly coercive tactics including showing graphic autopsy photos and making prison threats.

quote_or_scene: Dolores arrested in front of her brother Emilio: 'She didn't do nothing! Don't hurt her.' / 'Dolores Alvarez, you're under arrest for the murder of three people.' Later Benson visits her in custody: 'You didn't come to the Bronx to apologize to me. Actually I did.' Dolores describes Anna's farewell: 'Usually when I'm leaving, Mrs. Anna says Buenas Noches. That night, she said adios. And she kissed me. She never kisses me.'
notes: Dolores worked for the Mills for 10 years and was treated like family. She discovered the bodies, panicked, and fled with the murder weapon (leaving her prints on it). Police theorized she had an affair with Julian Mill that was rejected, leading to revenge killing. She was arrested in front of her brother and held in Rikers. Neighbors and squad speculated about inappropriate relationship with Mr. Mill. Benson later visits to apologize. Anna Mill helped Dolores and her brother Emilio stay in the country legally. Physical evidence (blood on Anna's shoes) eventually exonerates Dolores and implicates Anna.

quote_or_scene: Sarah confronts Stone in bar: 'You raped me, you son of a bitch.' Stone is arrested on camera. Gary Kent holds Stone at gunpoint in bar: 'This guy, in the nice suit? He raped my wife!' Investigation proves Reggie Griggs was the rapist; Stone had passed out. Liv: 'Peter, I'm sorry for everything that you went through.'
tags: ruined_at_work; public_confrontation; wrong_ID; perp_walk; physical_threat; colleague; ADA
notes: Stone, an ADA and former MLB pitcher, is publicly accused and arrested. The victim genuinely believed he raped her because he was the only person in the room when she woke up, but investigation reveals his friend Reggie Griggs committed the assault while Stone was passed out. Stone endures arrest, public humiliation, armed hostage situation, and professional jeopardy before being cleared. Severity 4 due to life-threatening armed confrontation plus career-destroying accusation for a prosecutor.

police_conduct_quote: Carisi implies Glover is gay during interrogation; tone suggests moral judgment about sexual orientation
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Glover's home during family dinner. Mother present. 'Time to wash up for dinner.' 'Hi, Mom.' 'Got a whole leg of lamb if your friends wanna stay.' Glover arrested in front of mother and children. Later confesses to murdering Tammy/Bobbi but is innocent of any sex crime with a child - Tammy lied about age and presented as female prostitute.
notes: Glover committed murder, NOT a sex crime. He solicited what he believed was an adult female prostitute. The 'victim' Tammy was actually 16 but lied about identity/age/gender. Glover is guilty of murder and solicitation, but innocent of any child sex crime accusation. Included because he was publicly confronted at home as if he were a sex criminal, causing family exposure and humiliation, when the actual crime was murder motivated by deception. His insistence 'I am not gay' suggests he experienced this as a sex crime accusation.

quote_or_scene: Trina: 'Lee Black? He didn't assault her.' Detective: 'You sound pretty sure.' Trina: 'Yeah, because I am. He was with me all night.' Later: 'Lee Black. He's an unemployed actor. Tox screen shows MDMA and cannabis. But he's not the one who assaulted Ava? His DNA was not a match.'
notes: Ava mentioned dancing with Lee at the party, making him an initial person of interest. Trina (party host) provided alibi that Lee was with her all night after 5am, long after Ava left. DNA testing confirmed Lee was not the rapist. No public exposure occurred - questioning appears to have been private/contained to police investigation.

quote_or_scene: Claire Newbury interviews Patton on camera: 'Mr. Patton, you claim to be the infamous Infinity rapist.' Patton: 'Yes. You should know that. You wrote three books on me.' Later described as 'the copycat' when real Infinity strikes.
notes: Patton is guilty of raping April Baker (confessed, DNA match) but innocent of BEING the original Infinity Rapist from 1981-1994. He's publicly exposed as 'Infinity' in media interview before real Infinity strikes again, proving Patton was a copycat. Included because he suffered public exposure as the wrong perpetrator (original Infinity vs copycat), though he did commit the Baker assault.

quote_or_scene: Laura initially tells detectives: 'My own father was raping my sister.' Later revealed this was fabricated by Greg Callahan. Medical examiner and work records prove Doug couldn't have committed the Thursday afternoon abuse. Greg's girlfriend confirms Greg was grooming Laura and had been abusing her for months.
notes: Doug Moore was murdered by his daughter Britney based on a false accusation fabricated by neighbor Greg Callahan, who was actually abusing Laura. Doug was proven innocent through: (1) work records showing mandatory Thursday staff meetings 3-6pm when Laura claimed abuse occurred; (2) Laura later admitting Greg was the abuser; (3) Greg's confession. Doug died believing he was being accused. The false accusation was weaponized to enable Greg's continued abuse and planned custody takeover. Greg manipulated 13-year-old Laura into making the false accusation against her father.

quote_or_scene: Off-duty cop confronts him at bodega, he pulls switchblade thinking he's being arrested for kidnapping. Fin arrests him: 'Could have taken any car. I had to take the one with the baby in the trunk.' Later cleared: 'I was with my girl all morning... That's why I took the wheel. She was late for her job interview. I dropped her, I stopped for a pack of smokes. That's when that maniac slugged me.'
notes: Car thief arrested at bodega in public confrontation after stealing car with Bailey in trunk. Cleared when timeline established he couldn't have kidnapped her. Charged with auto theft and assaulting officer instead. Bailey unable to ID him in photo array.

police_conduct_quote: Rollins: 'You know what, I... I don't like the way this is going.' Benson threatens: 'I can take you down to the squad room, where you're gonna sit and you're gonna wait until Detective Rollins gets you a search warrant... except I will be extremely pissed off 'cause you would have wasted two hours of my life.'
quote_or_scene: Arrested after detectives find stalker photos of Bailey on her phone. Rollins: 'Paige, you are under arrest.' Paige: 'What? Why?' Rollins: 'Stalking, for starters, and I'm betting we're gonna tack on kidnapping.' Later cleared when Bailey can't ID her and investigation moves to actual perpetrator.
notes: Birth surrogate who carried Bailey arrested for stalking/kidnapping after detectives find photos of Bailey taken in Central Park day of kidnapping. Coercive interrogation tactics used. Arrested on camera. Later cleared when Bailey unable to ID her and yellow scarf clue points elsewhere. No apology shown.

quote_or_scene: Mackenzie tells Garrett: 'I told Garrett that it was Mr. Dreyfus.' Garrett confronts Dreyfus at his apartment. Garrett: 'I asked him how could he. I asked him what kind of animal... and I told him there was a special place in hell waiting just for him.' Dreyfus denies it but Garrett kills him with a bowling trophy. Later revealed: 'He's never had sex with a woman' (fiancé Mr. Woodward confirms Dreyfus was gay and engaged to him). Mackenzie later admits: 'He was my friend... he promised not to say anything.'
notes: Dreyfus was completely innocent - he was gay, engaged to be married to a man (Mr. Woodward), and never had sex with a woman. Mackenzie fabricated the accusation to protect her stepfather/husband Garrett (the actual father). After SVU interviewed Dreyfus about the pregnancy, he approached Mackenzie out of concern as a friend and promised not to reveal her marriage to Garrett. Garrett killed him to prevent exposure. Dreyfus offered DNA willingly to prove innocence but was murdered before testing. His fiancé confirms the relationship and his sexual orientation. The accusation destroyed his reputation at work and led directly to his murder.

person_label: Emilia and Lara's father (unnamed Italian man)
quote_or_scene: Lara: 'He's already in jail in Italy. Lara testified against him.' / Benson later: 'Our ADA has contacted the Ministry of Justice in Italy...and they're working on getting your father out of prison.' / Lara: 'Will he ever forgive me?'
tags: fabricated_claim; imprisoned; family_member; custody_dispute; coached_testimony; international_case
notes: Richard Matthews groomed both daughters (Emilia age 4+, Lara earlier) and coached them to falsely accuse their biological father of child sexual abuse. The father was imprisoned in Italy based on Lara's coached testimony at trial. Matthews accompanied Lara to Italy for the trial. The false accusation is discovered when detectives notice both sisters use identical language ('flip-flops snap against the wooden floor,' 'grunted like a pig') to describe abuse that never happened. The episode ends with authorities working to release the father from prison. This is a case of fabricated accusation with life-altering consequences (imprisonment) for an innocent person.

person_label: Emilia and Lara's mother (unnamed Italian woman)
quote_or_scene: Lara: 'We couldn't prove she knew about it, but...she's suffering anyway. Nobody in the town will talk to her anymore.'
notes: The mother was accused/suspected of knowing about the fabricated abuse and failing to protect her daughters. Though prosecutors 'couldn't prove she knew about it,' she suffered complete social ostracization in her Italian town as a consequence. She is implied innocent because the underlying abuse allegations against the father were false (fabricated by Matthews). The community shunning represents material social harm stemming from the false accusation ecosystem created by Matthews.

police_conduct_quote: Look at you, man. All the gifts God gave you. And this is what you do? You're a disgrace.
quote_or_scene: Snake is arrested in front of media after his concert at the Apollo. Mother Jo confronts Fin: 'How could you arrest my baby without so much as a phone call?' Dallas later confirms: 'He has never laid a hand on me' and provides alibi that Snake was at Apollo during assault. Nursing home confirms Dallas FaceTimed her mother at 9:00pm; Snake arrived at Apollo at 8:45pm.
notes: Snake was arrested publicly after his concert based on domestic dispute history, rage room video showing him threatening Dallas, and neighbor report of argument before assault. Later proven innocent when Dallas provides timeline alibi confirming he was performing at Apollo during attack. Detective Fin (who grew up with Snake's family) initially believed in his innocence but still arrested him. No formal apology shown.

quote_or_scene: Article headline states 'NYPD INVESTIGATING RB BANKS IN CONNECTION WITH DALLAS ASSAULT.' Banks confronts Snake with gun, cops intervene. Banks states 'Yeah, I did it. That bitch got what she deserved!' but clarifies he meant his rap lyrics, not the assault. Banks provides alibi: 'I can't use my bitch as an alibi because I wasn't with my bitch' - was with another woman, not his girlfriend. Alibi confirmed.
notes: RB Banks suspected due to threatening rap lyrics about Dallas ('Teach that black Taylor Swift wife of yours a lesson') and access to Snake's home security code via Instagram. Investigation leaked to press creating public accusation. Banks initially appears to confess but was referring to his rap lyrics. Provided alibi of being with another woman (not his regular girlfriend). Squad confirms alibi. No apology shown.

police_conduct_quote: Look, I told you. We freaked out. We thought they'd blame us. / Okay, maybe not. Maybe it was your, uh, your buddy, Michael. But let me tell you something. If it was, then right now, you gotta come clean before he gives you up.
quote_or_scene: Nahla identifies Ari from photo array: 'This boy, he was there too. This boy grabbed my hijab and spat in my face. These people are Islamophobes. It's in their blood. One of these boys must have raped me.' MetroBuzz reported 'SVU arrested two Jewish teenagers for the assault on Nahla Nasar' before any arrests were made.
notes: Ari and Michael were at the synagogue for a youth group meeting about their birthright trip to Israel. They found Nahla unconscious but fled out of fear they'd be blamed. They were publicly identified in media reports as arrested suspects (though not formally arrested on-screen). Nahla initially identified both boys in photo array as her rapists based on earlier confrontation. Later proven innocent when ex-husband Masud convicted. Detective Carisi uses coercive tactics suggesting his friend Michael will give him up.

police_conduct_quote: Detective implies Michael might be guilty and will give Ari up: 'Maybe it was your, uh, your buddy, Michael. But let me tell you something. If it was, then right now, you gotta come clean before he gives you up.'
quote_or_scene: Nahla identifies Michael from photo array: 'Wait... Him. You know him? Not from that night, but the same day. He was protesting outside my office with a group of other students. This boy, he was there too.' MetroBuzz reported both boys were arrested.
notes: Michael was with Ari at the synagogue for youth group. Found Nahla unconscious but fled. Nahla identified both boys from photo array as likely rapists based on earlier confrontation outside her office. Media reported both were arrested (though not shown arrested on-screen). Later proven innocent when ex-husband Masud convicted. Parents present during police questioning.

quote_or_scene: Moran arrested following Mathis lineup, arraigned publicly. 'The press knows we have a suspect.' Media coverage of arrest. Later proven innocent of Mathis assault specifically (alibi: 'his ex took a selfie of them and their kids on the upper deck at Citi Field') but guilty of three other assaults via plea deal.
notes: Moran is proven innocent of the Mathis assault (the false report) but is actually guilty of assaulting three other victims. Including him because he suffered public arrest/exposure for a crime (Mathis assault) he didn't commit, even though he committed similar crimes against others. His arrest was based on Mathis's fabricated report and faulty lineup ID. He was publicly exposed and arraigned before the truth emerged about Mathis lying.

police_conduct_quote: Fin: 'Wrong answer, Isaac.' Then threatens to call Jolene sheriff about bench warrant. Later: 'So Isaac, you can talk now or pray later' while moving to handcuff him.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Isaac at his apartment about Evangeline's location. Fin threatens arrest on Ohio warrant. Isaac explains she needed place to crash, they argued, she left to panhandle. Later confirmed innocent when Evangeline reveals stepfather James Miller as perpetrator, DNA confirms.
notes: Isaac was questioned privately in his apartment with threats of extradition to Ohio on unrelated statutory warrant. No public exposure to workplace, family, media, or community shown in transcript. He cooperated by revealing Evangeline's panhandling location. Later proven completely innocent when DNA confirmed stepfather as perpetrator. Severity 1 because accusation remained private between detectives and Isaac with no documented spread to others or material consequences beyond the threatening interrogation itself.

quote_or_scene: Rollins: 'Detective Rollins kept investigating. She found the man who did this.' Chloe to Mohammed: 'I'm sorry. I'm... I'm so, so sorry.' Mohammed is freed from holding after 24 hours when the real perpetrator (Sanjay) is found and confesses.
notes: Mohammed Sayeed was arrested Friday night and held in custody for approximately 24 hours based on Chloe Cooper's misidentification from a photo array. She recognized his face from her HailMe app and wrongly identified him. His phone GPS data and app records later proved he was elsewhere (cancelled the ride, took other passengers). He was released Sunday morning when Sanjay Patel was identified as the actual perpetrator. Chloe apologizes to him upon his release. Detective Rollins apologizes indirectly. No evidence of workplace/family/media exposure beyond the arrest itself. Severity 3 due to wrongful arrest and 24-hour detention.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Monte and the DA told me if I didn't confess, that I'd get the sayonara syringe. Man, I was 18. I didn't have no mommy no more to help me.
quote_or_scene: Carlos to Carisi: 'Man, I don't know who killed them. All I know is that Ricky and me didn't do it, I swear. I could never hurt my mommy or little Jacinta.' ... 'Monte and the DA told me if I didn't confess, that I'd get the sayonara syringe.' Judge at vacatur: 'Carlos Hernandez, I apologize on behalf of the state of New York for your wrongful imprisonment that has cost you 16 years of your life.'
tags: coerced_confession; verbal_threat; imprisoned_16_years; family_member; mother_and_sister_murdered; sexual_assault_risk_prison; alibi_suppressed_due_to_homophobia; vacated_conviction; detective_monte_coercion
notes: Carlos was 18 when arrested in 2003 for murdering his mother Nydia and 13-year-old sister Jacinta. He confessed after Detective Monte threatened him with death penalty ('sayonara syringe'). He had an alibi (was at Plumb Beach with Ricardo Torres) but couldn't reveal it because he was gay and feared prison rape/murder if inmates learned this. Served 16 years before DNA exonerated him in 2019. His mother and sister were actually killed by maintenance worker Tim Stanton. DA Keane built his career on this wrongful conviction. Carlos describes ongoing trauma in prison, including fear of sexual assault ('getting bitched out until I got the bug, like Ricky'), inability to learn where his family was buried, and PTSD/depression. Consequence severity 4: life-altering imprisonment, permanent trauma, loss of 16 years, exposure to violence/rape risk in prison.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Monte convinced him if he turned state's on me, he'd get man two and out in 15.
quote_or_scene: Carlos: 'Ricky was just a kid. Detective Monte convinced him if he turned state's on me, he'd get man two and out in 15.' Moms Baker: 'Ricky lit right back here from prison. He was so skinny. I knew he had the bug. HIV? Full-blown AIDS. He caught that while inside. He cried on my shoulder. He had lied on Carlos to save his own skin.' Carlos: 'After he was released, Ricky sent me this. He apologized for putting me away. He said he was just saving himself.'
tags: coerced_confession; teen; imprisoned_15_years; contracted_HIV_in_prison; died_of_AIDS; coerced_to_testify_against_codefendant; guilt_trauma; detective_monte_coercion; died_before_exoneration
notes: Ricardo Torres was 15 when Detective Monte coerced him into a false confession and convinced him to testify against Carlos Hernandez with false promises of leniency ('man two and out in 15'). Served 15 years. Contracted HIV/full-blown AIDS while imprisoned. Released approximately 2018, died in 2019 shortly before the case was reopened. Before death, wrote letter to Carlos apologizing for lying and putting him away. Moms Baker scattered his ashes and described how he 'cried on my shoulder' about lying on Carlos 'to save his own skin.' Died of AIDS contracted as direct consequence of wrongful imprisonment. Consequence severity 4: death from AIDS contracted in prison, 15 years lost, guilt/trauma, never saw exoneration.

consequence_detail: perp_walk, arrested, charged, public_humiliation, media_pileon, assaulted_in_jail, company_takeover, career_destruction
quote_or_scene: Luna arrested in court: 'Get your hands off of me! This is not justice. This is insanity!' Media presence at perp walk. Later Luna describes jail assault: 'The other inmates held me down, and I heard somebody say, Oh, yeah, she needs to know what it's like to be raped by another woman.' Press coverage: 'the harder they fall... male serial predators get more respect than this.'
tags: perp_walk; media_outing; public_confrontation; fabricated_claim; ruined_at_work; ruined_physically; conspiracy; ceo; female_victim
notes: Luna was victim of elaborate conspiracy by three employees (Bobby Frost, Melanie Franks, Vinay Gupta) and coerced witness (Tisa Chee) who fabricated sexual assault and embezzlement charges to remove her as CEO. She was publicly arrested, perp-walked in front of press, held without bail, and sexually assaulted by inmates in jail. Company was taken over by conspirators during her incarceration. Accusation of assaulting Tisa Chee was completely fabricated - Tisa admits 'It wasn't my idea. It was Vinay. He said it wouldn't get to trial.' Evidence shows Luna never even met with Tisa at retreat. Embezzlement emails were ghostwritten by Bobby Frost who hacked her accounts using information provided by former friend Melanie. Bobby also actually raped Luna (separately), making this a case where the actual rapist participated in falsely accusing his victim of being a rapist.

police_conduct_quote: Stop resisting! / Duck your head. / Get in there.
quote_or_scene: Woman calls 911: 'Yes, there is a black man threatening me and my son.' Officers arrive, cuff Jayvon in park. 'Sir, put your hands behind your back.' 'Why?' 'Hands behind your back, now!' 'I'm not resisting!' Video goes viral with 5 million hits. Later: 'I got laid off. Somehow it was all in the papers that I'm in NA.'
tags: ruined_at_work; media_outing; perp_walk; public_confrontation; wrong_ID; witness_recant; online_rumor; fabricated_claim
notes: Colleen Reynolds (white woman) falsely accuses Jayvon of threatening her and her son. Police arrest him publicly on outstanding warrants (BLM protest-related curfew violation). Video of arrest goes viral (5M views). He is treated as rape suspect despite having alibi (NA meeting with sponsor, corporate lawyer Corey). Sponsor confirms timeline. SVU clears him but damage done: he loses his warehouse job after NA attendance becomes public through media coverage. Files lawsuit against NYPD. Captain Benson later apologizes privately but Jayvon rejects it. DA pursues charges against Colleen Reynolds for false report. Captain Curry (IAB) notes Benson had stopped-and-frisked Jayvon years earlier (2013, Jolene Castille case). Joe Murphy (actual perpetrator) later acquitted because grand jury distrusts police after Jayvon incident.

police_conduct_quote: Fin: 'This is how you treat a brother officer? No wonder you got lawsuits against you.' Context: interrogating Will and his father Marc together, creating pressure.
quote_or_scene: Will: 'Dad, stop! I was there. And I did it. They were arguing. Mom was crying. He was gonna hurt her again. I know he was. I wouldn't let that happen.' [...] Carisi: 'I will be charging Will as an adult.' [...] Mother Irena eventually testifies: 'He didn't kill Dwight. Because I did!' Judge accepts Irena's guilty plea, dismisses charges against Will.
notes: Will confessed to protect his mother from murder charge. He was arrested, charged as adult, went through preliminary trial proceedings with testimony from father (cop) and mother before mother confessed on stand. Exposure limited to legal system and family - no workplace/school/media/public component shown. Severity 3 due to adult murder charge and trial process, but no public/social exposure beyond courtroom.

police_conduct_quote: You been lying! This is not a game! / Not looking good for you, Brad. / Are you crazy?
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Brad: 'You been lying! This is not a game!' His DNA found in Maria's rape kit. Interrogated about murder. Media reports mention 'wild sex trysts' and roommates being questioned. Brad's sexual relationship with Maria (while engaged to another woman) exposed during investigation and questioning.
notes: Brad had consensual sex with Maria hours before her death. His DNA in rape kit made him initial prime suspect. Body found in his hockey bag. He was accused of murder in interrogation ('Not looking good for you'). His affair with Maria (while engaged) was exposed. His fiancée's family involved (he was sleeping with fiancée's sister Sloane too). Eventually cleared when Perry confessed. No formal apology shown. Severity 2: public media exposure of his sexual activities and suspicion of murder, plus relationship damage.

police_conduct_quote: Man refers to Sean as drug dealer throughout; media calls him 'pot-dealer Sean Thomas' accused of 'drug-fueled sexual torture session'
quote_or_scene: Sean arrested at his home with warrant. Media reports: 'pot-dealer Sean Thomas have been questioned for over 24 hours' and accused of murdering Maria 'in a drug-fueled sexual torture session.' Held at Rikers. Carisi notes: 'we arrested him for rape and murder' though he 'told us the truth, mostly.' Charges eventually dropped but no apology shown.
notes: Black drug dealer who had consensual threesome with Lexi and Maria. His DNA in rape kit. He admitted to sex and stealing jewelry/passport but denied murder. Arrested, held at Rikers, publicly named in international media as murderer in 'sexual torture session.' Media coverage was racialized ('pot-dealer'). Eventually proven innocent when Perry confessed to killing Maria. Carisi notes charges should be dropped but 'it's not my call' and doubts 'anyone on eighth floor gonna have stomach to pursue.' No formal apology. Severity 3: arrested, jailed at Rikers, international media accused him of rape-murder, racial stereotyping in coverage.

episode_title: The Long Arm of the Witness
quote_or_scene: Judge Gallagher: 'I have no way of knowing what actually happened that night, but I do know that I can't let this court cavalierly destroy Mr. Hunter's future. I've heard the evidence presented by the prosecution, and I find it legally insufficient to establish the offense charge therein, therefore I am granting the defense motion to dismiss the indictment.'
notes: Ian Hunter is accused of rape by Valentina Palma. Case goes to full trial in Suffolk County. Judge explicitly dismisses case as 'legally insufficient,' saying he won't 'cavalierly destroy Mr. Hunter's future.' Later revealed judge was biased due to family connection (uncle Tom Burns was judge's frat brother and campaign donor). The dismissal itself proves innocence in legal sense. Hunter endured full public trial with media present and was publicly named as rape defendant before being cleared. Episode later reveals the judge who cleared him was corrupt, suggesting the dismissal may have been improper, but text never suggests Hunter was actually guilty—the focus shifts entirely to the judge's pattern of assault and corruption.

police_conduct_quote: Moldovan shot at unarmed suspect during pursuit after suspect slipped; 'Take one more step, and I'll shoot!' Evidence suggests Moldovan attempted to kill Gonzalez to frame him.
quote_or_scene: Gonzalez: 'Tallahassee PD confirms that Gonzalez was locked up in county jail, April 2nd to August 18th' proving alibi for Bella Gardner rape. Defense attorney: 'My client was unarmed, you shot at him, you have to justify.' Five of seven victims positively IDed Gonzalez but three did not, creating reasonable doubt. His DNA didn't match any rape kits.
tags: arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; shot_at_by_police; witness_recant; attempted_murder_by_cop; Gypsy_cab_driver
notes: Gonzalez committed burglary/attempted burglary but is innocent of the serial rapes (proven innocent of Bella Gardner rape via alibi, and likely innocent of others based on DNA absence and inconsistent victim IDs). He was shot at by Moldovan, who appears to have been trying to kill him to prevent exposure of Moldovan's own crimes. He is 'partially_involved' because he did commit burglary, but innocent of the sex crimes he was accused of.

police_conduct_quote: Joey: 'Moldovan's like a dog with a bone, telling me to take the rap for all six, and I save the two other women from the anguish of blah-blah-blah.' 'Moldovan said he'd make sure I got locked up close to home. My mom was sick. She couldn't take no eight-hour bus ride. So I cop to the six.'
quote_or_scene: Joey to SVU: 'In your initial confession, you admitted to four of the six rapes, with your DNA. And then, two hours later, you confessed to all six. Including the final two that didn't have any DNA.' Joey explains Moldovan coerced confession to crimes he didn't commit in exchange for prison placement near dying mother.
notes: Joey (Black Hood Rapist) was guilty of four rapes (DNA confirmed) but innocent of two additional rapes that Moldovan coerced him to confess to. He received additional prison time for crimes he didn't commit. Tagged 'partially_involved' because guilty of some rapes but innocent of others he was convicted for. The coercion involved exploiting his dying mother's inability to travel, promising closer prison placement in exchange for false confession.

police_conduct_quote: Fin to Lonnie: 'Better hope she shows up. Alive.' / 'Yeah, every con's got a stir-bug story. But you need another one.' / 'You don't have a job anymore. And if I were you, I wouldn't go out there.' / 'Look, Black teen with a white girlfriend? The jury would never believe me.' Fin: 'Uh-huh. Look, man, we get it, all right? Ceranda's your type... Young, cute, white. You know, you try to hit on her, she says no, then you make your play anyway.' / 'I don't believe you. And those people out there? They don't believe you, either.' / Fin (to Carisi): 'I assumed Lonnie was guilty 'cause he was in that rat trap... I checked his single-bust record, and I made him for dirty... because of me, another innocent kid gets lynched.'
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Lonnie at the SRO motel in front of building context, threaten parole violation repeatedly, refuse to believe his alibi. Boss Zamir fires him after anonymous tip about registry. Community protests outside motel calling residents 'sex offenders.' Vigilantes Eduardo, Louie, and Juan torture, strangle, sexually mutilate, and burn Lonnie alive. DNA later proves Lonnie innocent—real killer was Sam Johnson, hired by PO Roy Eastman to frame Lonnie. Lonnie's parents reveal he had alibi (secret meeting with underage ex-girlfriend McKenna) but couldn't tell police without violating parole. Fin's reflection: 'I assumed Lonnie was guilty... I made him for dirty... another innocent kid gets lynched for it.'
tags: ruined_at_work; fired; public_confrontation; media_outing; perp_walk; coerced_confession; fabricated_claim; cop; Black; custody_dispute; vigilante_attack; murdered; torture; lynching
notes: Lonnie is the central false suspect. He was on the sex offender registry for a prior 'Romeo and Juliet' statutory case (turned 18, girlfriend 15, her stepfather Roy Eastman forced prosecution). Anonymous caller tips off his boss about registry status. Detectives publicly question him at work, threaten parole violation, surveil him. Boss fires him. Community protestors demonize SRO residents. Lonnie is tortured, strangled, sexually mutilated, and burned alive by vigilantes inspired by community activist Elvis Baktashi's rhetoric. DNA evidence later proves Sam Johnson (hired by Eastman to frame Lonnie) killed Ceranda. Lonnie had alibi (met ex-girlfriend McKenna at Penn Station during break) but couldn't reveal it without violating parole. Severity 4: murdered. Police conduct included repeated threats, racial profiling assumptions, refusal to believe denials. Fin later expresses remorse for presuming guilt. Episode depicts compounding systemic failures: registry stigma, police coercion, community vigilantism, and ultimately lynching of an innocent Black teenager.

consequence_detail: arrested, charged, convicted, 25 years imprisonment, entire life destroyed
police_conduct_quote: Ian was 18, concussed, traumatized when he confessed. His initial story was that an unknown assailant knocked him out. He was so guilt-ridden he convinced himself he did it.
quote_or_scene: Ian: 'I was so messed up, I thought maybe I did do it, but I didn't. I swear I didn't. I loved Haley. My whole life ended the night that she died.' Burton: '25 years behind bars, two words away from walking free, and instead he says, "I believe in two things, the truth and miracles. I know the truth, and I need a miracle."' Ian's mother wrote to Burton before she died asking him to help.
tags: wrong_ID; coerced_confession; arrested; charged_then_dropped; media_outing; ruined_physically; teen
notes: Ian Ridley is the central exoneree. Spent 25 years in prison after confessing while concussed and traumatized at age 18. The entire community believed him guilty. New DNA testing proved Roger Murray (tennis coach) was the actual rapist/killer. Ian refused to apologize at parole hearing because he maintained innocence, costing him release. Eventually exonerated through Burton Lowe's investigation and Nick Amaro's new DNA technology. Severity 4: life-altering—lost entire adult life to wrongful imprisonment.

police_conduct_quote: We're tearing apart your restaurant, we're tearing apart your car. [...] You have three months left on your parole, right? You lied to us, and that's enough to send you back to a South Carolina prison. [...] Detectives show graphic photos of mummified bodies: 'They were butchered. Organs removed, brains pulled out of their skulls, dried and preserved like beef jerky.' Country responds: 'No, no, no. Put those away.' Later: 'Listen, you're our only suspect, Country. So if there's anything that you're not telling us, now would be the time.'
quote_or_scene: Country's restaurant is publicly searched with warrant ('Hey, hey, man, those are my knives. What the hell is going on?'). He is brought to SVU for interrogation. Traffic cam evidence is presented showing his car with a passenger going north, returning alone. Detectives threaten: 'You have three months left on your parole, right? You lied to us, and that's enough to send you back to a South Carolina prison.' They show him graphic crime scene photos of mummified victims despite his protests ('Put those away'). Later, timeline evidence proves innocence: 'The girl in New Jersey was reported missing one week after Country started his sentence at South Carolina... And Meredith, a year after that. He was in prison, halfway through his bid.' Fin concludes: 'Which means Country's not good for this.'
notes: Country Jones runs a barbecue restaurant and helps homeless sex workers by holding their belongings. He admits to driving Tania to meet a client on the night she disappeared, which initially makes him the prime suspect. Police execute search warrant at his restaurant in front of customers/employees, seize his knives, interrogate him aggressively, threaten parole revocation, and show him extremely graphic crime scene photos. He is exonerated when prison records prove he was incarcerated during multiple murders. No apology is shown in transcript. His business reputation is damaged by public search and arrest. Severity 3: arrest, business search, coercive tactics, parole threats constitute material sanctions.

police_conduct_quote: Elliot Stabler becomes visibly angry during interrogation - Olivia intervenes physically between Stabler and Peters. Peters says: 'Sorry for your loss, but there's a war going on, and your wife bleeding out on the sidewalk, she's just another casualty.'
quote_or_scene: Captain Benson testifies: 'We apprehended a suspect for those other attacks, but ruled him out for the car bomb that killed Kathy Stabler.' Barba cross: 'Didn't Mr. Peters also take credit for bombing the Stabler vehicle?' Benson: 'He did, but...we found that the claims were not credible.'
notes: Peters was arrested and charged with fire-bombing two police vans, then took credit for the Stabler car bombing. Police (Benson and Stabler) interrogated him and determined his claims about the car bomb were not credible. He was ruled out but was arrested. Stabler's anger during interrogation required Benson's physical intervention. Exposure appears limited to police interrogation - no indication of public exposure beyond arrest for the other bombings.

police_conduct_quote: You don't start cooperating with us, Darko, you'll never see your dog again.
quote_or_scene: Darko is investigated as mastermind, questioned in hospital after being shot. Police threaten his dog. He admits minor role (graffiti, vandalism) but was coerced by white supremacist network to store bombs. 'I never wanted that stuff in my apartment... They made me turn off my phone.'
notes: Darko committed vandalism/graffiti but is innocent of bombings and planning. He was coerced/manipulated by white supremacist network (North Star, AJ, Nolans) into storing bombs. Shot by AJ for talking to police. Police threaten to keep his dog to force cooperation. Qualifies as partially_involved: guilty of minor crimes (graffiti) but innocent of the terrorism he's accused of being mastermind of. Harm: shot and hospitalized. No public exposure or reputation damage shown.

consequence_detail: arrested, charged, held_at_rikers, perp_walk, media_coverage, press_conference_announcing_arrest
police_conduct_quote: Maybe you had a party in your apartment that night and one of your buddies, he's good for this... Well, you went somewhere, so where did you go? Then stop lying. We know that you didn't come home until after 3:00.
quote_or_scene: Chief McGrath press conference: 'I am pleased to announce NYPD has apprehended Aaron Wesley Parker, a suspect in the Central Park sex assault.' Dustin arrested at bar with drug possession as pretext, interrogated about Kayla rape, victim's wallet found in his bedroom, DNA in her mouth matched him from consensual kiss, held at Rikers, charges later dropped when serial rapist identified.
tags: ruined_at_work; ruined_in_family; perp_walk; media_outing; arrested; charged_then_dropped; wrong_ID; fabricated_claim; custody_dispute
notes: Dustin is innocent of raping Kayla (the Central Park victim) but is later proven guilty of raping his sister Demmy for over a decade since she was 12. His sister planted Kayla's wallet in his room to frame him, hoping to escape his abuse. For the Kayla rape specifically, he is definitively innocent—DNA from serial rapist Aaron Wesley Parker proves this. His exposure was massive: public arrest at his bar workplace, media coverage, press conferences, detention at Rikers. He experienced severe legal and reputational harm. The innocence_status applies strictly to the Kayla accusation for which he was arrested and publicly named. His actual guilt for abusing Demmy is a separate crime discovered later.

quote_or_scene: Detectives interview Red/Mr. Washington about his relationship with Aretha, ask if he spent time alone with her, request DNA sample. He asks 'Is there any way my wife and kids hear about this?' Detectives assure him they don't need to know. He provides DNA voluntarily. Later cleared when DNA doesn't match fetal bones.
notes: Red Washington was investigated because he had access to Aretha (spent time alone with her when helping with homework) and had hidden relationship with mother Cora. However, questioning remained private with police only. He was cleared via DNA and no public exposure occurred. Consequence severity = 1 because it was private questioning with no outside audience or formal sanction. No indication of material harm beyond being briefly suspected.

person_label: Libby Blandon (rape victim, NYU student who dropped out)
police_conduct_quote: Detective used mother's receptionist to call Libby saying 'get to the office right away' implying emergency, then police were waiting to arrest her there.
quote_or_scene: Libby: 'When her receptionist called and said to get to the office right away, I thought something terrible had happened. That's where the police were waiting to arrest me.' Attorney Miglani: 'The first of many questionable tactics.' Later: 'The only time I ever gave anyone a sample of my DNA was when SVU did my rape kit.' Detective Szabo illegally accessed OCME rape kit DNA database to identify and arrest Libby for grand larceny of watches from sugar daddy.
notes: CRITICAL CASE: Libby was brutally raped a year earlier by Henry Mesner. Her rape kit DNA was illegally accessed by Major Case Detective Szabo (via OCME forensic biologist Harry Kent) to identify her as grand larceny suspect. Police rused her to mother's office for 'emergency' then arrested her there in front of mother. She was indicted by grand jury, faced trial. This represents systemic violation of rape victims. Charges eventually dropped after political pressure and revelation that at least 6 victims' DNA was similarly misused (including 9-year-old male assault victim convicted of carjacking, female sex worker convicted of fraud). Severity = 3 due to arrest, indictment, public family exposure, retraumatization of rape victim, and threat of conviction. Though guilty of the theft, her innocence tag relates to the violation of using rape victim DNA - she is 'innocent' of the process crime/violation of her rights. Episode's core message is about protecting rape victims from DNA misuse.

episode_title: Confess Your Sins to Be Free
quote_or_scene: Father Duffy arrested at art gallery UC sting operation. 'Father Duffy got arraigned. That must have been tough on Carisi.' He is later cleared when Father Regis is caught confessing to the crimes at his mother's grave. Duffy states: 'I was concerned. I wanted to make sure the woman there was safe' but cannot reveal confessional information.
notes: Father Duffy was protecting confessional seal - he knew Father Regis was the rapist through confession but could not reveal it. Arrested in UC sting when he showed up to protect the undercover detective. Arraigned on trespassing. Eventually cleared when actual rapist (Regis) is caught. Carisi had to recuse himself as Duffy was his childhood friend. Duffy faced excommunication if he broke seal but also faced prison if he didn't explain himself.

episode_title: Confess Your Sins to Be Free
police_conduct_quote: Velasco to Vince: 'And you were sleeping with his wife?' Then warns: 'Well, he will now. Might want to watch your back.' - implicit threat that husband will find out and retaliate
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Vince at his workplace (car dealership): 'Somebody knew the door was gonna be unlocked. You tell one of your pals about your fling?' Vince denies involvement. Detectives tell him the husband will find out now and warn him to watch his back, creating danger for him.
notes: Vince is questioned at his car dealership workplace about the rape. While investigation seems to clear him relatively quickly ('Fin: the neighbor boyfriend's a bottom-feeder, but I don't think it's him'), detectives explicitly tell him Shane (the victim's husband, described as 'built like a war memorial' with ex-con friends) will now find out about the affair, creating physical danger. This counts as harm - exposing him to retaliation and threatening his safety as consequence of the accusation.

quote_or_scene: John Ken in Queens house: 'He found me, all right? He said he would ruin my life if I didn't help him. I didn't have a choice. She told me she was 18... I was terrified... A girl I met online. She told me she was 18. And then Sirenko, he shows up and tells me that she's 15. Said he had pictures and video of us together.'
notes: John Ken was set up by Sirenko in a honey trap with a girl who claimed to be 18 but was actually 15. Sirenko used photos/video to blackmail Ken into providing hotel security access for the bomb plot. When SVU storms the Queens house looking for Sirenko, they confront/arrest Ken publicly. He is clearly terrified and explains the blackmail scheme. While he did engage with a minor (making him partially_involved in that offense), he is innocent of willing participation in the bomb plot—he was coerced. The detectives recognize him as a victim/witness rather than conspirator. Exposure was at his residence with officers present; severity 2 reflects the public arrest without formal charges shown to stick.

police_conduct_quote: I have a friend named Leo at IRS that might want to look at your books... that would hit a pause button real fast on that deal of yours.
quote_or_scene: Detectives question Spencer at his workplace while Lena Hess (the woman acquiring his company for $2 billion) is present. Lena states: 'We have a morality clause in all of our contracts. Spencer will soon be my direct report. If he's involved in a criminal matter, I'd like to know.' Later, detectives threaten his business deal and compel DNA sample with threat: 'Say ah.' Spencer's DNA is later proven not to match the rape kit evidence.
notes: Spencer is questioned publicly at his office in front of Lena Hess, who is acquiring his company for $2 billion and has a morality clause in contracts. He is compelled to provide DNA under threat to his business deal. DNA proves he did not assault Maggie. While his sexual activities at parties are later exposed via hidden camera footage (used to leverage his cooperation), the primary harm tracked here is the public workplace accusation of rape, which occurs in front of his future boss during a critical business transaction. He is later proven innocent of the rape accusation specifically.

police_conduct_quote: They put me in a box, kept asking me why I did it. It went on for hours. I started going into withdrawal, real bad... They gave me a piece of paper, said if I signed, I could fix. So I signed, and shot up right there on the spot.
quote_or_scene: PUP PETERS: That wasn't a real confession. I didn't touch those girls. I kept trying to tell them... They put me in a box, kept asking me why I did it. It went on for hours. I started going into withdrawal, real bad. Didn't ask for a lawyer? Didn't have to. They gave me a piece of paper, said if I signed, I could fix. So I signed, and shot up right there on the spot.
notes: Pup Peters spent approximately 10 years in prison for rapes he did not commit. His confession was coerced during drug withdrawal—police promised him drugs in exchange for signing a confession. The real rapist (Ronnie Samuels) continued attacking deaf girls and murdered Renee Perry. While Peters suffered life-altering harm (severity 4: wrongful imprisonment), the transcript does not show public exposure beyond standard court proceedings. The mother of a deaf victim falsely identified him to escape drug charges. Bruno says Peters' conviction will be overturned and he will likely sue. Qualifies as proven innocent with severe legal consequences from coerced confession.

police_conduct_quote: We can cuff you here, in front of your coworkers, or you can come with us.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at his workplace: 'Some folks from the NYPD want to talk to you.' They threaten to arrest him publicly. His wife is interviewed and reveals his affair. DNA clears him but damage done.
notes: Fiancé Josh made a positive ID from six-pack. Kalazakis was publicly confronted at his workplace with threat of being cuffed in front of coworkers. Wife was interviewed about his whereabouts, exposing his affair. DNA ultimately cleared him, but he suffered workplace exposure, marital consequences, and reputation damage. Police showed coercive tactics with public arrest threat. No apology given despite proven innocence.

quote_or_scene: Humphreys confesses on video: 'I raped and smothered... my dear wife.' Later proven innocent via CPAP machine digital log showing he was asleep during murder (woke 10:00 PM for 1 min 23 sec; murder at 11:00 PM). After learning truth, attempts suicide: 'I don't want to live without her.' Homicide had accepted confession; lawyer prepared dementia defense. Real killer: caregiver's nephew Kevin Wise.
notes: Pence falsely confessed believing he killed his wife as part of their alleged murder-suicide pact. His dementia made him unreliable witness to his own actions. Though arrested/charged, exposure remained within legal system (lawyer, homicide, SVU, ADA). No workplace/media/family exposure shown. Severity=4 due to suicide attempt directly resulting from learning of his innocence and wife's actual fate. Defense lawyerready to argue dementia made him incompetent. Cleared when SVU found CPAP data proving he slept through murder window.

quote_or_scene: DNA familial match leads detectives to question Cooper. He explains: 'I'm a donor. Past two years, a really popular one.' Detectives verify his alibi (studying with friends) and confirm he's a sperm donor whose samples were accessed. He's cleared when it's determined someone else used his donated sperm.
notes: Cooper was briefly suspected due to DNA familial match but quickly cleared. No public exposure - questioning was private, in what appears to be the precinct or dorm. No workplace/family/media involvement. No arrest or formal consequences beyond the interview and DNA swab. Severity 1: private questioning only, no audience, no sanctions.

quote_or_scene: Naomi initially tells police 'I was at a party, the room next door. I had some drinks, then later I had sex but I didn't want to.' She's asked 'With a boy on your team?' Later in court: 'After you were arrested for arson, didn't you tell SVU the boys next door raped you?' Naomi: 'I was conflicted. I liked the Youngs.' Defense: 'So you lied to the police to protect your rapist?' Naomi: 'I confabulated.'
notes: Todd and other male teammates were brought in with parents present, asked for DNA samples. Todd's parent says 'my son's no rapist' suggesting defensive posture due to accusation. Naomi later clarifies the accusation was false and the actual perpetrators were the coaches.

quote_or_scene: Detective to Sean's mother: 'You want to test Sean's DNA?' Sean: 'No. Ms. Fridge? I wouldn't go anywhere near her.' Detective: 'But you two were hanging out last night?' Sean: 'She had one drink. Then she went back to her room supposedly to study.'
notes: Questioned in presence of his mother who expressed concern about DNA going into system. Mother referenced needing to call husband, suggesting family stress from accusation.

quote_or_scene: Booker's father: 'My son's not involved in this in any way. He's a good kid.' Detective: 'If he gives us a DNA sample, we can rule him out as a suspect.' Father: 'So he can be in the system forever? Give me one good reason why any Black man should trust the cops.' Booker: 'Dad, hold on. I didn't do it. Neither did any of the other guys. They haze her and make jokes, but they didn't rape her. I know who did.'
notes: Booker's father was calling a lawyer before Booker disclosed who actually committed the assault. Father explicitly referenced racial profiling concerns, indicating awareness of potential lasting harm from false accusation in criminal justice system.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Billy outside his apartment after church. Velasco: 'Billy Vitale.' Billy: 'Can I help you, officers?' They question him about being at the tea shop window during Evie's rape. He denies involvement. Later proven innocent when rape-for-hire scheme is discovered.
notes: Billy was a known stalker of victim Evie Quinn. He was present watching through the window during her assault but did not commit it. Detectives confronted him at his home in a scene that could be observed by neighbors. Later cleared when the rape-for-hire scheme was uncovered. Severity 2 because confronted at home (potential neighbor observation) though no formal arrest.

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Greg at his workplace. Carisi and Benson suggest he may have paid someone to rape Darlene. Carisi: 'Maybe you felt guilty.' Greg: 'About what? She left me. We done?' Later implied innocent when rape-for-hire scheme is uncovered, though never explicitly cleared on-screen.
notes: Ex-fiancé of rape victim Darlene. Detectives confronted him at his workplace in front of colleagues, directly suggesting he hired someone to rape her. The episode later reveals a rape-for-hire market exists, strongly implying Greg and other exes may have used such services, but Greg is never arrested or explicitly cleared. His workplace confrontation in front of coworkers qualifies as public exposure causing reputational harm (severity 2).

quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Derek about Maria's rape. Derek admits to the affair but denies the rape. Fin: 'Where were you Saturday night?' Derek: 'Home with my wife.' Derek offers: 'I'll take a lie detector test, give a DNA sample, whatever it takes.' Later cleared when DNA doesn't match and rape-for-hire scheme is revealed.
notes: Former employer who had affair with nanny Maria. Victim mentioned him to police. Detectives confronted him, he voluntarily offered DNA and polygraph. Later proven innocent when his DNA didn't match and the rape-for-hire scheme was uncovered. Workplace/home confrontation with implicit threat of investigation qualifies as severity 2.

quote_or_scene: Benson and Carisi interview Harvey and Rose together at their home. While polite, the implication is clear they suspect Harvey hired someone. Carisi notes Harvey's alibi receipts: 'Usually keep those?' implying suspicion. Later, Benson states: 'If Harvey Bergman hired somebody to rape his wife, there's absolutely no evidence whatsoever.'
notes: Estranged husband of rape victim Rose. Questioned by police at home with wife present. Though interview was relatively cordial, the accusatory subtext was clear (asking about alibis, receipts). Later stated there's no evidence he hired anyone. The rape-for-hire scheme revelation suggests others did this, but Harvey is specifically cleared. Questioned in front of wife qualifies as family exposure (severity 2).

police_conduct_quote: Where's Maddie? / Where is she? Where's Maddie? / The girl you're stalking.
quote_or_scene: Detectives confront Franks at his home about watching girls' soccer. 'Where's Maddie?' they demand repeatedly. He's arrested based on prior complaints about watching practice. Search of home reveals thousands of photos but no evidence of Maddie. 'I've never done anything wrong. Taking photos of strangers makes me feel closer to people.' Released when no connection found.
notes: Franks was previously reported to police for watching girls' soccer practice. Had prior contact with local precinct who let him go. Home searched with dogs, computer seized. No evidence linking him to kidnapping found. Squad's aggressive questioning ('Where is she?') and arrest based on prior suspicious behavior and photo collection, but he's innocent of the kidnapping.

police_conduct_quote: It's not what you think. / Well, then you won't mind giving us prints and a sample of your DNA.
quote_or_scene: Squad enters Sam's home, finds anatomically-correct dolls resembling Maddie. Wife discovers husband's secret: 'Sam, how long have you been keeping this secret from me?' Sam: 'I just...cuddled with her.' Wife: 'You're lying.' Detectives bag dolls as evidence, force DNA/prints. Wife is present throughout confrontation, learns husband's secret.
