notes: Sam's marriage is destroyed when detectives reveal his sex doll collection in front of his wife. She discovers his secret during the police investigation. He's innocent of kidnapping but faces severe family consequences from public exposure of his private activities. Wife's reaction ('You're lying') shows relationship damage.

police_conduct_quote: OK, so just tell us where the doll is. / Or we can tear this house down to the studs looking for it.
quote_or_scene: Hal runs when police arrive, tries to escape across rooftops. 'You're gonna hurt yourself. It's over.' Admits he paid $8,000 for kidnapping but 'changed my mind. I called him. I told him to cancel. But it was too late.' Asked 'Can I go home now?' Answer: 'No, Hal. That's not how this works.' Arrested.
notes: Hal paid for the kidnapping but attempted to cancel before it occurred. He's guilty of solicitation/conspiracy but did NOT kidnap Maddie himself and tried to stop it. He's innocent of the actual kidnapping act but faces legal consequences for his role. This is a 'partially_involved' case - wrong about the specific crime executed but guilty of related criminal intent.

police_conduct_quote: Chief McGrath: 'If I find out that you did this, I'll kill you.' Detectives also used confrontational language: 'You're a tutor. Do the math. She's 15, you're 18.'
quote_or_scene: Chief McGrath walks into squad room, confronts Saagar: 'I trusted you. Shea trusted you. We let you into our home. If I find out that you did this, I'll kill you.' Benson: 'Get out of my squad room now.' Later detectives tell Saagar: 'When you do verify his story, it'll be the last see of us. At least one of you.' His lawyer: 'My client and his family will be pursuing legal action against the NYPD.'
tags: wrong_ID; arrested; public_confrontation; coerced_interview; teacher; teen
notes: Saagar was arrested, brought to precinct, questioned, and publicly threatened with death by Chief McGrath in the squad room. His alibi (being with Claire Oswalt studying) was later verified, and DNA excluded him. Detectives said 'at least one of you' suggesting the family faces consequences even after clearance. His lawyer announced plans to sue NYPD. Apology coded 'partial' because detectives apologized ('we're sorry') but chief's threat was never formally addressed on-screen to Saagar. Severity 3: arrested, death threat from senior officer, reputation damage at school (detectives went to his home, spoke to parents, classmates aware), plus legal/family stress.

police_conduct_quote: Maybe you're just a loser... They probably do cheat. I've seen them. Getting girls drunk, treating them like sluts.
quote_or_scene: Detective to Frederick: 'The question for you, Frederick, is what kind of man do you want to grow up to be? You might want to start spending less time with machines and more with people.' Earlier: 'We're not charging him.' Frederick expelled along with announcement: 'three students who have been expelled pending the conclusion of the police investigation.'
notes: Frederick was innocent of raping Leah Tan (actual rapist was Dustin). He participated in the unethical 'game' and is guilty of that misconduct, but was falsely accused of the specific rape. Detectives confronted him in his dorm with girlfriend present, insulted him during interrogation, and he was expelled. School president made public announcement about expulsions. Detective offered partial acknowledgment at end ('We're not charging him') but framed as moral lecture rather than apology for wrongful accusation.

police_conduct_quote: Word gets out that you're a person of interest in an active rape investigation? How long before your school's in the news? What happens to your future?
quote_or_scene: Velasco: 'Well, here's the thing, there's a law and then there's ethics. I wonder what color you are, Frederick.' (said to Frederick but in context of comparing him to Hayden). School president: 'this institution in no way condones the actions and behaviors of these three students who have been expelled pending the conclusion of the police investigation.'
notes: Hayden was innocent of raping Leah Tan specifically (Dustin did it), but confessed to raping Nikol Rakovsky on New Year's Eve, so his innocence_status is 'partially_involved.' For the Leah Tan accusation that drove the episode investigation, he was wrongly accused. He had consensual sexual contact with Leah (she performed oral sex on him consensually) but did not rape her. Expelled from school. Detectives threatened reputational harm during interrogation. Transcript shows lawyer present ('Hayden, stop talking' / 'Take as many as you need') suggesting formal interrogation. No apology for misidentification regarding Leah, though he was guilty of other rape.

person_label: Cal Markham (cousin of victim Gwen Markham)
quote_or_scene: Cal confesses: 'I did it. I killed Gwen. So I raped and killed my own cousin.' He is Mirandized and taken into custody. Later: 'Carisi says he'll ROR Cal Markham by end of day.' DNA evidence excludes him: 'Excluding Cal...' when lab results come back.
notes: Cal deliberately fabricated a confession to force exhumation of his cousin's body to find the real killer. He was arrested, processed through the legal system, and held at Brooklyn House of Detention. DNA evidence from the exhumation proved his innocence and identified the true killer (Richard Kincaid). While he orchestrated his own false accusation, he still suffered arrest and detention as consequences. The detectives did pressure him to produce 'new evidence' which led to his strategic false confession.

consequence_detail: arrested, charged, held in Rikers, coerced guilty plea (7-year minimum), public court appearance, son traumatized to point of violence
police_conduct_quote: Detectives pressured him during interrogation: 'Maybe you met her at a bar last night. Maybe she invited you back to her place. You opened the sliding door for some air. How's that sound?' 'That sounds very plausible to me.' His lawyer also pressured him to plead guilty despite maintaining innocence.
quote_or_scene: Hedges in interrogation: 'I don't understand... I wasn't with her last night. No way. No way.' Later pleads not guilty in court but is pressured by public defender to accept 7-year plea deal. While in Rikers, another attack with identical MO occurs, proving his innocence. Real perpetrator Glenn Duncan is caught with DNA evidence from all victims.
tags: wrong_ID; coerced_confession; arrested; charged_then_dropped; perp_walk; ruined_in_family; ruined_physically
notes: Hedges' fingerprint was legitimately at the scene, but he had handled the glass door months earlier when he worked at Home and Hardware Direct (April 2022) where he stocked sliding doors that were later installed in victim's building. Victim Ariel made mistaken ID. He was coerced into guilty plea by incompetent public defender. Spent time in Rikers. His son Toby became so traumatized he confronted Fin with a gun, accidentally shooting him. ADA Russell resisted releasing him even after new attack occurred while he was in custody. Eventually released when real perpetrator (Glenn Duncan, ex-Marine) was caught with DNA evidence from all six victims.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Teddy: 'That's exactly what we think' [regarding murdering Shelli, raping Elodie]. Accusatory questioning about being 'pissed off' and feeling 'left out' of threesome.
quote_or_scene: Detectives question Teddy intensely about his feelings after seeing roommates' threesome without him, directly accuse him: 'You think I hit Damon over the head, killed Shelli, raped Elodie, and then pretended to find them?' Detective: 'That's exactly what we think.' Later cleared by chess player alibi witness who confirms Teddy was playing chess until after 3 a.m.
notes: Teddy was the initial primary suspect due to jealousy motive (excluded from threesome). Detectives brought him in for questioning and directly accused him of the crimes. However, exposure remained at police level only - no evidence of workplace, family, school, or media exposure. His alibi with the chess player in the park cleared him. Consequence severity is 1 because interrogation was private and accusatory but did not result in public exposure or formal sanction. Excluded from main analysis as exposure_channel is 'police_only' with no material harm beyond the interrogation itself.

quote_or_scene: Bruno and Silva confront Danny at his workplace (bar) about the spit found in Ellie's hair. 'You won't mind us swabbing your mouth for DNA.' Danny admits to spitting on Ellie after she left without paying for free drinks. 'You're under arrest, dummy.' Danny protests: 'It's just a little spit.' Detective responds: 'Well, actually, in the state of New York, it's considered assault.'
notes: Danny is innocent of rape/assault on Ellie. He did spit on her (separate minor assault), but detectives initially pursue him as the sexual assault suspect based on DNA evidence (saliva) and his admission to giving Ellie free drinks. He is arrested at his workplace in front of colleagues. While his arrest was technically for the spitting (assault), the context makes clear he was being investigated for the sexual assault/attempted murder. Rockland County later 'kicked him loose' after his alibi checked out. No apology shown. His workplace exposure and arrest qualify as severity 3 harm.

quote_or_scene: COTTLE: 'You just got me fired from my teaching job. Asking about my record?' / CARISI: 'Because we were following up.' / COTTLE: 'On what? That you think I was staring at your daughter?' / Later: COTTLE: 'I am sexually attracted to young girls... But I swear, I swear I have never once ever acted on any impulses. I... I never touched anyone. I... I never looked at child porn.'
notes: Cottle admits to sexual attraction to minors but explicitly states he has never acted on it (no touching, no CP). ADA Carisi and Captain Benson's investigators contacted Board of Ed HR about a year-old unsubstantiated complaint ('ick vibes'). This investigation directly led to Cottle losing his substitute teaching job. While Cottle's attractions are concerning, no actual crime occurred. The accusation/investigation was based on Carisi's observation of Cottle looking at his daughter and the prior unsubstantiated complaint. This represents predictive/preventive policing that resulted in job loss without proven criminal conduct. Episode acknowledges moral complexity ('morally gray area of predictive policing' per Benson). Cottle seeks help and enters therapy at episode's end.

quote_or_scene: Detectives arrest Tommy at his workplace: 'You have the right to remain silent... How dare you embarrass me at my place of work? ...I got two kids. How the hell am I supposed to pay the mortgage?' Wife Annette tells detectives: 'I'm really sorry, Mrs. Gallagher. I really am.'
notes: Tommy was manipulated by Harris Vernon into believing Katharine wanted the encounter. He participated in what he thought was consensual activity arranged by the husband. He's innocent of rape (the woman was drugged without his knowledge) but participated in the sexual encounter. His arrest was public at his workplace. Eventually took a deal for 7 years, testifying against Harris. His innocence is partial - he didn't rape an incapacitated person knowingly, but did have sex with someone who couldn't consent due to Harris's drugging.

police_conduct_quote: Velasco: 'You're talking to two SVU detectives. What do you think?' Defense attorney in court: 'The DA agreed to drop your own rape charge in exchange for your testimony here today.'
quote_or_scene: Derek to detectives: 'Look, what happened between me and Katharine, it was all Harris's idea... He asked me if I wanted to hook up with her while he watched. It was a fantasy of his, evidently... Dean Harris raped her. Not me.' Detectives find him on campus and question him about the 'possible sexual assault.'
notes: Derek was a young professor coerced by his boss (Harris Vernon) into having sex with Katharine at a conference in Boston while Harris watched. Derek stopped when he realized something was wrong. He avoided tenure-track pressure and feared retaliation from his boss. Initially faced potential rape charges before being given immunity to testify against Harris. The detectives' approach ('You're talking to two SVU detectives. What do you think?') was threatening. He was manipulated by Harris, not a willing rapist. Partially involved in that he participated but stopped when he realized Katharine was incapacitated.

police_conduct_quote: Silva posed as 14-year-old 'Amy' online, asked Matthew to bring condoms to hotel room, establishing false intent. Silva: 'Did you bring everything you asked? / Matthew: 'Condoms. I asked the guy behind the counter at the deli. I did what you asked. Did I do good?' Matthew was arrested despite showing clear signs of cognitive disability throughout interaction.
quote_or_scene: Matthew sobbed through entire booking. At arraignment: 'I didn't do anything bad.' Officer Chilton to Silva: '50 pedos in one sting? Good job, Detective.' Matthew to his mother after release: 'I just made myself a wood elf in Skyrim.' His mother: 'My son is 32 years old. He's never spent a night away from me in his entire life. He can't go to jail.' Medical file shows 'Matthew Daly has the cognition of a fifth grader.'
tags: coerced_confession; arrested; perp_walk; held_overnight; public_arraignment; special_needs; entrapment; ruined_physically
notes: Matthew is a special-needs adult with fifth-grade cognition who was deliberately entrapped by SVU Detective Silva posing as a 14-year-old girl named 'Amy' on gaming platform Wish Crafter. He thought he was making a friend. Silva coached him to bring condoms to 'show intent' for prosecution purposes. He was arrested, booked (sobbing throughout), held overnight in a cell with actual pedophiles, and arraigned on attempted rape charges before Captain Benson got DA Baxter to dismiss all charges. This is one of the clearest cases of police-created harm to an innocent person in the series. Matthew's cognitive disability was evident throughout but initially ignored to reach Carisi's quota of 50 arrests. Case ultimately dismissed with Benson's intervention.

quote_or_scene: Bruno and Silva approach Oliver at school: 'You know a girl named Leah Hayward? She said she sent you this a couple months ago on an app called Ghost Letter.' Oliver: 'Yeah, but I don't have an account. I wish I could talk to a girl like that, but there is no way that Leah Hayward would ever be into a guy like me.' TARU confirmed: 'No nude photo of Leah, and no Ghost Letter app on Oliver's phone.' Leah to Benson: 'He seemed safe. Well, he's also shy.'
notes: Oliver was falsely accused by victim Leah Hayward of soliciting nude photos via Ghost Letter app. He was publicly questioned by detectives at school (Ellsworth Academy) in front of other students. TARU forensics proved he never had the app and never received the photo. The actual culprit was Adam Parker impersonating Oliver. Oliver is described as shy and shocked that Leah even knew he existed. While quickly cleared, he was publicly questioned at school about receiving underage nude photos, which constitutes exposure harm even without formal sanction.

quote_or_scene: Vigilante mob led by Danny Rocha confronts and beats Soto in the street based on resemblance to police sketch. Scene: 'Stop! NYPD! Yo! Hey! Hey, hey, hey, hey! NYPD! Stop! Yo, let go of me. Velasco, you know this guy? Yeah, he's my neighbor. Yeah, we got you, punk. We got you! That's the sicko from the sketch. He raped that girl. I didn't rape anyone.' Soto is then arrested and hospitalized with concussion. Later cleared when DNA doesn't match: 'That was the lab, and his rape kit came back. It's not a match for Eddie.' Victims don't ID him in lineup.
notes: Eddie Soto has a prior forcible touching conviction from two years ago, so his DNA was already in the system. He was beaten by vigilantes in a public street confrontation, hospitalized with a concussion, arrested by police, and later fully exonerated when rape kit DNA didn't match and victims failed to ID him. The sketch was based on witness description and circulated on social media/news feeds, leading to community exposure. Though he was only held briefly and charges were voided, he suffered severe physical harm (hospitalization) and public exposure as 'the rapist' before being cleared.

consequence_detail: arrested, arraigned_in_open_court, public_family_confrontation, marriage_crisis, career_jeopardy_as_teacher, registry_threat, media_exposure_at_arraignment
quote_or_scene: Arraignment scene: Ryan's stepmother shouts 'She's a pedophile!' and Ryan's father yells 'My son is a minor!' while Stacey's husband shouts back 'He took advantage of my wife!' Stacey is arrested on drug-facilitated rape charges, faces sex offender registry ('I'm a teacher. I'd lose my whole life'), and her marriage is collapsing ('Our marriage is still in trouble'). Case goes to trial with jury deadlock/mistrial.
tags: teacher; public_confrontation; arrested; perp_walk; media_outing; ruined_at_work; ruined_in_family; registry_threat; coerced_confession; wrong_ID
notes: Stacey is accused of statutory rape of Ryan (16) but evidence strongly suggests she was the victim: (1) toxicology shows MDMA in her system that Ryan admitted putting in vodka without telling her; (2) Ryan texted friends pre-encounter about wanting to 'tag' older women; (3) Ryan admits Stacey grabbed the drugged vodka herself (he didn't offer it) but he never warned her; (4) Ryan admits he wouldn't have come forward if stepmother hadn't found the underwear; (5) defense presents compelling case she was incapacitated/drugged; (6) jury deadlocks and mistrial declared, suggesting reasonable doubt about her guilt. She suffers catastrophic harm: public arrest, arraignment with families screaming accusations, threat of sex offender registry as a teacher (career-ending), marriage in crisis, legal fees. Husband testifies on her behalf. The show presents this as a case where the 'victim' (Ryan) was actually the predator who drugged an older woman, but legal system initially treats her as rapist due to age differential.

police_conduct_quote: Detective to Sam: 'Now is the time to come clean, Sam.' 'Why was he calling you nonstop?' 'I think Upshaw was surprised you even quit.' 'Making little mistakes is part of learning. And you know what isn't? Clubbing your boss in the head with some metal or something. And carving a date in his back with an angle grinder.' 'Are you lying to us right now?'
quote_or_scene: Sam is brought to precinct with his father Nate. Detectives confront him about lying regarding his girlfriend alibi and not returning Eddie's 10 phone calls. They accuse him directly: 'I think Upshaw was surprised you even quit... Making little mistakes is part of learning. And you know what isn't? Clubbing your boss in the head... And carving a date in his back with an angle grinder.' Sam denies involvement repeatedly while father watches. Father asks 'Do I need to call a lawyer?' Sam is cleared when park camera footage confirms his alibi.
notes: Sam was publicly accused in front of his father in interrogation room. The detectives used aggressive questioning tactics and directly accused him of the assault ('clubbing your boss in the head'). While Sam was actually a victim of Eddie's sexual abuse, he was treated as a suspect first. The accusation was contained to the precinct and his father, but this constitutes public exposure (severity 2). He was later proven innocent via surveillance footage showing him in Tompkins Square Park during the crime. The interrogation also led to disclosure of his abuse to his parents, though this was ultimately necessary and handled sensitively by Detective Bruno.

police_conduct_quote: Velasco to Miguel: 'We did find your DNA on a murder victim.' Implied threat of being charged with murder.
quote_or_scene: Velasco: 'This isn't personal. But we did find your DNA on a murder victim.' Miguel: 'I already told you guys, I never even met that girl.' Later revealed Gomez planted his DNA by having sex worker steal condom and deliver it to Gomez who planted it on Ana Machado's body.
notes: Miguel Pinto's DNA was found on murder victim Ana Machado. He was arrested and questioned multiple times. Later proven that Lieutenant Gomez hired sex worker Charisse Johnson to steal used condom from Miguel after his cousin allegedly hired her for him. Gomez then planted Miguel's DNA on Ana's body to frame him. Miguel cleared when investigation revealed Gomez was actual killer. ADA Price's team confirms 'Guy was in Staten Island' with alibi. Working theory established that 'somebody framed him.'

quote_or_scene: Brady: 'What about the Catholic shelter? Father Alberto's place? I don't know. Maybe he knows something. Look, he's a nice guy, but he wouldn't be the first priest with a secret.' Benson to Gomez: 'We're going to do our best to link it to the Father's [DNA].' Later Benson realizes: 'the fear that I saw in Father Alberto's eyes' and 'I think that he sent somebody to threaten Father Alberto the morning that he shot him.' Father Alberto while struggling over gun: 'I can't!' [drop the weapon]. Died in struggle with Gomez who shot himself while both had hands on weapon.
notes: Father Alberto ran Catholic shelter. Squad suspected him based on witness seeing him with crying woman late at night in his room. When Benson and Gomez arrived to question him, he fled in terror. Church was 'pretty banged up' beyond what ICE raid would cause. During struggle over Gomez's gun in catacombs, Father Alberto said 'I can't' when ordered to drop weapon—both men's hands on gun when it discharged. Father died. Later investigation reveals Gomez (actual killer) sent someone to threaten Father Alberto before the confrontation, causing him to flee. Benson realizes Father was innocent victim threatened by Gomez. Captain acknowledges 'professional courtesy' issue around testing Father's DNA against evidence, implying she later understood he was innocent. Episode strongly implies Father was murdered by Gomez to silence potential witness.

quote_or_scene: Atlas attacks Derek with baseball bat after learning police questioned him about exploitation photos. Derek hospitalized with 18 stitches. Later proven Atlas orchestrated the entire assault scheme and took the photos himself.
notes: Derek was arrested 2 years prior in Bahamas for exploitation photos of Josie (then 16) found on Atlas's broken phone. Derek claimed Atlas took the photos and hid them. Police suspected Derek of orchestrating the kidnapping/assault due to: (1) prior arrest, (2) alimony being cut off, (3) resentment over Natalie leaving him. Derek was brought from Bahamas for questioning. His son Atlas, believing Derek was responsible, attacked him with metal baseball bat requiring hospitalization. Atlas later revealed as actual perpetrator who took the photos and orchestrated entire assault. Derek proven completely innocent of both the old photos and the kidnapping scheme.

quote_or_scene: Highway pursuit scene: Velasco and Fin pursue Fierro in traffic. 'Both: Gun! Stay in your car! Stay down!' Fierro says 'I didn't go near her!' before pulling gun and jumping, later dying. Wife's statement confirms hotel alibi: 'At the hotel, I assume. I have the receipt.' Fin reports: 'Anthony Fierro is not the man who attacked you' confirmed by 'camera footage confirming that he was there the entire night of your attack.'
notes: Fierro was Dr. Stewart's patient in couples therapy. His wife took out restraining order after therapy. He had DV arrests and ketamine-induced paranoia. Squad pursued him based on threat history and access to victim. High-speed highway confrontation witnessed by multiple civilian drivers. He denied involvement ('I didn't go near her!') before pulling gun and jumping from elevated highway, dying from impact. Later proven innocent via hotel surveillance footage and purchase receipts showing he was at hotel entire night of attack. Severity 4: death (suicide) directly caused by accusation and pursuit.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives falsely claim they already have his DNA from fertility clinic and that Detective Bruno is testing it, using deception to coerce confession. Later they trick him into drinking water to steal DNA from bottle.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Simons' workplace with trash truck, confront him publicly in front of coworkers. Later interrogate using false evidence claims: 'Detective Bruno's already testing that sample as we speak.' He initially denies knowing Katie Wilkins, then under pressure admits 'Maybe I did sleep with the girl.' Arrested and sent to Rikers. Later cleared when murder investigation reveals he had nothing to do with bombing.
notes: Simons is accused of rape (separate case) and bombing. He admits to sexual contact with Katie Wilkins under coercive interrogation but is innocent of the bombing. SVU publicly confronts him at work, arrests him, and uses deceptive tactics. Tagged as 'partially_involved' because he may have committed the rape but is innocent of the bombing charges that drove the public workplace confrontation and arrest in this episode. The bombing accusation is what brings public workplace exposure and arrest shown on-screen.

police_conduct_quote: Detectives aggressively question him: 'She cucked you. You should get the lion's share, right?' Imply he's guilty and pressure him about his auger tool.
quote_or_scene: Detectives arrive at Clemente's workplace to question him about his wife's murder. They reference his bar fight history, ask about auger tool, pressure him with accusations about being cuckolded and wanting money. His auger is seized and tested but comes back clean. Cleared when pattern doesn't match and no evidence found.
notes: Clemente is questioned at his workplace as murder suspect but exposure remains private (no colleagues shown present during accusation). He is cleared when forensics don't match. Included because detectives arrive at his job site to accuse him, creating at minimum workplace disruption and implied stigma, qualifying as severity 2 public exposure at work even without confirmation of wider knowledge.

police_conduct_quote: Detective Velasco engages Young in conversation pretending to bond over pursuing young women for sex, implying Young is a predator who uses activism 'for the girls' rather than the cause.
quote_or_scene: Young is pursued and tackled at public protest at Astor Place. Arrested for murder of Dr. Mukherjee. Interrogated where Benson states 'I don't think you care about activism... I think that you like 'em young. I think that you're in it not for the cause, but you're in it for the girls.' He's later arrested for murder of Autumn Diaz (a different crime he actually committed). His alibi for Mukherjee murder checks out - he was in Beacon with girlfriend Lauden when Mukherjee was killed.
notes: Young is innocent of the Mukherjee murder (the crime SVU is investigating in this episode) and is publicly arrested at a protest. He is actually guilty of murdering Autumn Diaz but that's a separate crime. For the Mukherjee investigation, he's a false suspect who is publicly arrested and humiliated before being cleared by alibi. The public arrest at the protest and the degrading interrogation about being a sexual predator qualify as public exposure and harm.
